fields.headline: Trail of death taints 'saintly' nurse
fields.standfirst: A champion of euthanasia once praised by the Health Minister is in court accused of being a serial killer, reports  Stuart Jeffries  in Paris
fields.trailText: Two years ago, she was hailed as an angel of mercy; a courageous nurse who struggled with her conscience before putting elderly, terminally ill patients out of their misery. She won praise from her patients' relatives, and even from the Health Minister.
fields.body:
Two years ago, she was hailed as an angel of mercy; a courageous nurse who struggled with her conscience before putting elderly, terminally ill patients out of their misery. She won praise from her patients' relatives, and even from the Health Minister.

But last week in a French court Christine Malèvre was described as a megalomaniac with a morbid fascination for illness and death who should be treated as a murderer.

The astounding story of Malèvre and her alleged transformation from saint to serial killer started at the hospital she worked in at Mantes-la-Jolie, near Paris, where she was nicknamed 'The Black Widow' by colleagues because so many patients died in her care. In May 1998, the hospital's director became suspicious and reported the case to the public prosecutor.

When questioned, Malèvre initially admitted assisting 30 terminally ill cancer patients to die between February 1997 and May 1998. She later changed her story, and claimed she had helped only four to die by administering lethal doses of morphine.

Soon afterwards the Malèvre affair became public, making the nurse a focus for a debate over the ethics of euthanasia in France. She was condemned by the Catholic Church, but hailed by campaigners seeking a change in the law on mercy killings.

MPs demanded a parliamentary debate about euthanasia as a result of her stance.

But last week Malèvre, 30, was accused of seven counts of murder and committed to stand trial next year. If convicted, she could face 30 years' jail.

Olivier Morice, the lawyer representing four families of patients who died in Malèvre's care at the François-Quesnay hospital between 1997 and 1998, said: 'She was not the champion of euthanasia, as she wanted to be seen. She should be regarded as a serial killer rather than someone motivated by compassion.'

Her lawyer, Charles Libman, said his client should be cleared on all counts since the link between her actions and the patients' deaths had not been established.

It was the decision of families of the deceased to file suit against the nurse that brought the case before a court in Versailles last week. Until last year it was widely believed that Malèvre had acted at the request of the patients' families or the patients themselves.

At that time, no relatives had accused the nurse of any wrongdoing. The investigating magistrate had shown that she was not acting for money, in her own interests or at the behest of any pro-euthanasia association.

As a result, the magistrate ordered the nurse to be freed. She subsequently received psychiatric treatment in a sanatorium west of Paris before leaving the region to try to rebuild her life as a packer in a remote part of Normandy.

The bereaved families' suspicions were only aroused several months after their relatives' deaths. Alain Le Maout, whose wife Denise died at Mantes-la-Jolie in 1997, recounted how Malèvre had telephoned his home on the morning of 9 November,1997, and said he must come to the hospital urgently.

He claims that the nurse then called the hospital's resuscitation unit, described Denise's symptoms, and was told to administer an injection to ease a small epileptic fit.

'At 10 o'clock, when I arrived, Denise had just enough energy to turn to me and smile before she died in my arms,' said Le Maout, who now believes Malèvre may have administered a lethal injection of morphine to his wife.

After his wife's death, Le Maout said he received an invitation to Malèvre's wedding. He claims he was then contacted by a friend whose husband had died at the hospital under suspicious circumstances. 'When she told me that she had also been invited to the wedding, I asked myself, "Since when have nurses invited to their weddings widows and widowers of people who died in their care?" '

He was also told that Malèvre was writing a book about euthanasia called My Confession . This made him suspicious about what had happened at the hospital on the morning of 9 November. Malèvre has not commented on the circumstances surrounding Denise Le Maout's death.

He said he was pleased the nurse would stand trial for his wife's murder, but added: 'Knowing she is still at liberty, after admitting involvement in four deaths and being accused of seven murders, revolts me. webTitle: I spy the signs of a secret life

fields.headline: I spy the signs of a secret life
fields.trailText: There are about 20 bottles of Heineken in the fridge, and the cupboard opposite is even better stocked, with 10 bottles of Buitoni napoletana sauce, jars of cassoulet, tinned cocktail sausages and an impressive collection of spices. The apricot jam has mould on top, but let's not quibble: this is one well-appointed gaff.
fields.body:
There are about 20 bottles of Heineken in the fridge, and the cupboard opposite is even better stocked, with 10 bottles of Buitoni napoletana sauce, jars of cassoulet, tinned cocktail sausages and an impressive collection of spices. The apricot jam has mould on top, but let's not quibble: this is one well-appointed gaff.

It's hard not to try to work out the personality of the previous tenant. Who would have Daddies sauce, mesquite and a nearly empty bottle of Pastis in their kitchen? The answer: a francophile, a Middlesborough fan and a renegade spy. In short, David Shayler.

I've just moved into Shayler's former flat in the 11th arrondissement in Paris, and would like to thank him for leaving so many non-perishables behind. It's here that he holed up until last month when he decided to throw himself into the clutches of the British authorities - the spy who returned to the cold.

How difficult it must have been to leave this one-bedroom apartment. Yes, there are some horrible portraits whose eyes seem to follow one around the room, and it's not hard to imagine that the empty eye sockets of the Modigliani nude print above the fireplace were only a short while ago filled with the darting pupils of a counter-espionage officer.

And yes, there is an occasional rogue click on the phone which has prompted me to yell into the receiver: 'He doesn't live here any more, you clowns!' But this elegant flat is just the sort of home where one might write a novel. Or a stirring apologia for breaking the Official Secrets Act.

What is most extraordinary about this quartier, though, for someone who has just come from Finsbury Park, is the sheer density of the population. Vast terraces rise up from the front and back of our apartment, and on hot September evenings I look out across to the balconies and see a vertical beach of sun bathers.

I'm fast becoming the Parisian equivalent of James Stewart in Rear Window . And yet, despite this, Parisians are all discretion and social diplomacy. At 22.00 hours, music - be it Whitney Houston, Youssou N'Dour or a Mozart choral work - ceases abruptly and neighbours tiptoe up and down the stairs as stealthily as a spy escaping a grisly Lubianka cell.

That said, the apartment above ours was destroyed by a blaze on Wednesday and the firefighters broke into our flat on their way to extinguishing it. It turned out to have been ignited by a dropped cigarette, rather than (as I first suspected) an MI6 officer setting alight the wrong flat at the wrong time. Apart from the opportunities the fire created for my partner to flirt with the firemen, this has been an unpleasant intrusion into our sanctuary.

Smoke and dust have stained the entire flat and now we face months of hammering repairmen playing Celine Dion at high volume. Perhaps Shayler got out at just the right time.

This quartier must have appealed to him while he was here, though, since it teems with people hiding from oppressive authorities and has a proud history of standing up to the state. Shop after shop sells wholesale clothes, while out the back thousands of sans papiers (illegal immigrants), most of African or far east Asian origin, work over sewing machines away from the gaze of French authorities. In 1996, 300 such sans papiers took refuge in the nearby St Ambroise church. Police broke in and arrested the lot. Such was the local outcry, though, that two years on 90 per cent of them had been granted residency.

One item of local history may have been particularly piquant to Shayler. A plaque on the street round the corner tells the story of the Malet conspiracy. While Napoleon was in Russia in 1812, the renegade General Claude-François de Malet attempted a coup d'état.

At 4am on 23 October, he went to the barracks on the Rue Pasteur, told the commandant Napoleon was dead, and took charge of Paris.

But his power was short-lived. He was taken prisoner by loyal Bonapartist soldiers, and, on 29 October, Malet was shot. That's what they did with traitors in those days.

webTitle: Don't rely too heavily on harried Hector

fields.headline: Don't rely too heavily on harried Hector
fields.trailText: The official deadline for completing your tax return is just 12 days away if you want the Inland Revenue to calculate your bill for the year 1999-2000. But don't panic if there's no chance of getting your return in by 30 September.
fields.body:
The official deadline for completing your tax return is just 12 days away if you want the Inland Revenue to calculate your bill for the year 1999-2000. But don't panic if there's no chance of getting your return in by 30 September.

The Revenue prefers tax returns to be submitted by this date because it allows sufficient time to deal with all the forms before the second payment is due on 31 January. But the Revenue will still do the calculation for you if the return is late - even by a matter of weeks.

Tax experts say that it is much more important to ensure that your return is correct than on time. Many people assume the Revenue will check the form for mistakes. But your tax liability is calculated by a computer that simply crunches the numbers fed in by a Revenue employee. If that employee is experienced, he or she may spot your errors. But there is no guarantee.

Likewise, you should check the resulting bill. The National Audit Office checked 3,400 calculations last year and found that 6 per cent were incorrect because Revenue staff had introduced errors. As about 9 million people are expected to file returns this year, 540,000 could find their tax bills are wrong through no fault of their own.

Eight per cent of 'corrections' made by Inland Revenue staff to obvious errors in returns were also wrong. Worryingly, the amendment of PAYE tax codes to collect balancing payments were dealt with incorrectly in 27 per cent of cases.

However, don't put off paying your tax bill until the sums have been checked. The Revenue will charge you 8.5 per cent interest on any amount that is found to be outstanding.

It would be easy to place all the blame for this scrappy service on the Inland Revenue. But the Government must share the criticism. At a time when the Revenue should be concentrating its efforts on making self-assessment work smoothly, the Government has burdened it with responsibility for running the complicated Working Families Tax Credit and for policing the national minimum wage. The Inland Revenue needs more staff, better training and an urgent review of its systems.

If you are having problems with your tax return and cannot afford professional advice, the charity TaxAid may be able to help. Call 020 7624 3768.

webTitle: Nasal spray could offer cure for MS

fields.headline: Nasal spray could offer cure for MS
fields.trailText: Scientists have developed a way to vaccinate people against crippling immune disorders that include multiple sclerosis.
fields.body:
Scientists have developed a way to vaccinate people against crippling immune disorders that include multiple sclerosis.

If early trials are successful, researchers say nasal sprays could soon be used to provide protection against MS as well as illnesses like diabetes, severe allergies and arthritis.

'We are on the brink of tackling immune disorders in a new, highly specific manner,' said David Wraith, whose Bristol University team is about to begin trials of an MS vaccine. 'This is a very exciting time.'

A similar vaccine, against cat allergens, has been developed by Barry Kay and Mark Larche, at Imperial College, London, and has already proved successful in early trials. 'We have now completed a larger clinical study and early analysis of results again look very promising,' said Kay.

The key to the new approach involves re-educating the body's immune system so that it no longer attacks its own tissue or triggers disruptive counter-attacks when it encounters relatively harmless chemicals or microbes.

'This technique is the exact opposite of normal vaccination, which involves using pieces of protein from a microbe to stimulate the body's immune defences in anticipation of a future invasion by complete bacteria or viruses,' said Jonathan Lamb, of Edinburgh University.

'Instead, we are using protein pieces - called peptides - to convince the body's immune system that it is dealing with something harmless and doesn't have to arm itself or launch an attack.'

Lamb, working with Gerry Hoyne, has used a peptide isolated from the faeces of dust mites. 'These creatures are ubiquitous,' said Hoyne. 'They live in our homes and beds, eat flakes of our skin and then leave faecal particles all over the place. We breathe these in, and in about 10 per cent of the population they trigger an allergic reaction, sometimes a very severe one.'

This allergic response is initiated by immune defenders called T-cells, which decide how the body should respond to invasion. In nine out of 10 people, no discernible response is made to dust mites. In the remainder, a cascade of actions, initiated by the T-cells, causes mast cells in the bronchial tube to release histamine, which makes their throat and windpipe muscles tighten dangerously.

'What we are trying to do is make sure a person's population of T-cells do not set off inappropriate reactions,' said Lamb. 'They are the Fat Controllers of our immune systems and we want to make sure they stick to the right tracks.'

To achieve this goal, he and Hoyne took one of the proteins found in dust mite faeces, and extracted a couple of peptide fragments. These were then administered as nasal sprays.

'The T-cells encounter only one bit of dust mite protein and do not react against it,' said Hoyne. 'Essentially they learn to associate these fragments as being harmless, so when they encounter an entire dust mite faecal package, they do not overreact and set off an attack that leads to histamine release and closed windpipes.'

The technique - alternatively known as allergen vaccination or peptide therapy - has led the Edinburgh group to create a dust mite vaccine in the laboratory. The team now hopes to use it in early clinical trials in the near future.

A similar approach has been adopted by Wraith, who has isolated several peptides from the myelin sheaths that cover our nerves and which are attacked by a person's own immune system. This is the cause of MS.

'We have used these fragments to create a protective treatment for the disease, although we have only done so in the laboratory,' he said.

fields.headline: Dial-a-minder saved my life
fields.standfirst: Fighting a losing battle against the clock with a mountain of tasks piling up ahead of you?  Maureen Freely found the help she needed by calling on a phone coach who could point out the mistakes she was making and rescue her from falling into a workaholic 'black hole'
fields.trailText: Fighting a losing battle against the clock with a mountain of tasks piling up ahead of you?  Maureen Freely found the help she needed by calling on a phone coach who could point out the mistakes she was making and rescue her from falling into a workaholic 'black hole'
fields.body:
It began in the early Nineties, when an American accountant noticed a gap in the market. To fill it, he founded Coach University, which now has 3,000 students and graduates in the US and a further 300 here. It is not doing badly, either, in Hong Kong, Canada, Japan and Australia.

All instruction happens electronically - through teleconferencing and the internet. It takes up to three years to complete the course and it costs thousands of pounds, but apparently it is worth every penny. Every life coach I know swears by it.

A life coach, in case you have never heard this term before, is someone who helps you with your work, stress and time-management problems. Some go into companies and work with groups, but most are phone coaches. They work with their clients one by one, on the phone, from home.

Most have niche markets that make good use of skills they picked up in their former lives. Thus, coaches with City backgrounds specialise in corporate nightmares, coaches who were made redundant but survived to become their own bosses help others making the same transition, coaches with spiritual leanings counsel people who have discovered their lives are empty. But almost all their clients seek them out in the first instance for the same reason: they are having a terrible time adjusting to life in the new go-with-the-flow, 24-7, flexible workplace.

Oh, how grand that sounds. Oh, if only I could say it with a straight face. My own reasons for seeking out a phone coach are a lot less dignified. My problem, you might say, is that I am the problem.

I am the perfect global worker: owned by no one, making it up as I go along, and never not working. Last year I wrote more than a hundred articles, for more than 10 papers. I live in Bath, but spent two days a week in Coventry, teaching creative writing. And I wrote a book, and there was only one joke in it.

People were always telling me how awful I made them feel for doing less. They said they could not work out where I found the time. This was something they stopped saying if they got a glimpse of my study, my briefcase, or the black hole that was my handbag.

My excuse was that I never intended to live this way, and certainly have no training for it. When I was in my twenties I was a stay-at-home mother who wrote novels on the side. I only took up journalism in my mid-thirties, when I got divorced and needed to supplement my income.

I found I loved it. It helped me overcome a crippling case of writer's block and was the perfect antidote to the lonely back room where I was still writing my novels. I started teaching at around the same time, and I loved that too. But I did not have to push myself very hard. My shift into overdrive happened in my early forties, when I woke up one morning to find I was the main breadwinner for a family of six that expanded to eight on alternate weekends.

That was about eight years ago. I have kept things going by working on what you might call an emergency basis. An assignment came in, and I dropped everything until it was done. The moment it was done, there was another emergency, and then another. The non-emergencies I would leave for a day when I had no emergencies, but that day hardly ever arrived. I could go for a year without filing. I did go for years without an address book, relying on six diaries which were never where I remembered putting them. I seemed to spend half my life looking for an important piece of paper. I failed to pay my taxes on time because I could not find the bill.

Three things bothered me a lot more than living in financial chaos. One was that I was having so little time with the family in whose name I was supposed to be doing all this. The other was that I was losing friends, because many of them could not believe I had not been in touch for nine months because I had not had time to find the notebook with their number in it. Then there was my study. I would walk into it in the morning and survey the overstuffed drawers and overloaded power points and bulging accordion files, the leaning towers of unfiled paper, the stacks of unread books, and I would feel as if I was looking at the inside of my head.

So you can understand why my ears perked up when a friend who had had similar problems told me she had been 'sorted' by a phone coach. I decided to give it a try.

The first coach I went to decided we were not a good match. After hearing my tragedy, she said that if she took me on the first thing she would want to do was change my attitude to work, 'and I sense you don't want that'. She was right, the very idea terrified me. She suggested I try a man named Mark Forster, who liked to 'get his teeth into time problems'. So I rang him and told him about mine.

The preliminary session was a cross between vetting a shrink and going to confession, except that all we talked about were my work problems.

That was fine with me. I enjoyed every minute of my work-related whinge, and I was very pleased when, at the end, he said, yes, there was 'a lot to be getting on with' and suggested we set a time the following week for our first session. Then came my homework, which was to make a list of all the things I hoped to achieve if we continued to confer for three months and email it to him.

webTitle: Be prepared - the Guides get a makeover

fields.headline: Be prepared - the Guides get a makeover
fields.trailText: Olave Baden-Powell, the wife of the founder of the Girl Guides and a woman of resolutely conservative taste, would be shocked. The 90-year old Girl Guide movement, whose most famous members were once the Queen and Princess Margaret, is to be kitted out in designer gear as part of a radical overhaul of a group which once knitted socks for First World War servicemen.
fields.body:
Olave Baden-Powell, the wife of the founder of the Girl Guides and a woman of resolutely conservative taste, would be shocked. The 90-year old Girl Guide movement, whose most famous members were once the Queen and Princess Margaret, is to be kitted out in designer gear as part of a radical overhaul of a group which once knitted socks for First World War servicemen.

From next month, embroidery will be gone forever. In come circus skills and faith awareness. New training will focus on music, fitness and fundraising.

Special information on current issues like healthy eating and bullying is to be included in guiding literature. And leaders will encourage girls to help design their own activity programmes rather than simply following instructions.

Badges will be attached with Velcro to a string of new uniform items, created by the catwalk designer Ally Capellino. Capellino has been a favourite of high-profile clients including actress Jane Horrocks and Cherie Booth.

The new look for Britain's 700,000 Guides can be worn to Guide meetings with badges or worn badge-free to discos or parties. The designer range will be unveiled this week.

'We're well aware that we're now in competition with home entertainment and multi-media activity,' said Terry Ryall, chief executive of the Guide Association. 'We want to deliver what girls want as well as educational objectives. That has meant a redevelopment of our entire programme.'

Even Guide patrols, once called Forget-me-not or Swallow after favourite flowers and birds, are to be renamed. Guides will be able to choose the names of countries of origin or endangered animals instead. A team leader badge will require girls to demonstrate communication skills, including how to deal with conflict and how to give appropriate feedback.

In circus skills, girls will have to master three activities from a list which includes acrobatics, juggling and unicycling. A film lover's badge will require an understanding of what a storyboard is and what a 'best boy' does on a film set.

In a departure from the once overtly patriotic history of the Guide movement, girls will also carry out activities designed to foster international understanding. 'Peace can be the end of war,' says one promotional poster. 'If we all make an effort, the world could be a more peaceful place.'

Lynnie Hutchison, a Guide leader from East Sussex, said: 'We are already much more modern than many people think. But some of my Guides admit that they don't use the G-word at school. They just say they went on a mountain-biking weekend, but they don't say who with.

'That means other girls miss out on what they could be doing. That should change if our new programme succeeds in changing perceptions. It's a great shame that teenage peer pressure sometimes puts girls off.'

Radio 4 presenter Jenni Murray, a former Guide, said: 'Guiding was the best thing that happened to me in my teenage years. It taught me how to be a really responsible, sensible leader. I didn't even mind the marching. If Guides are demonstrating that they are modernising their image, that's great. Anything during the teenage years which means that girls can meet and have a common aim is good. I was able to be brave and strong and climb trees, all things I would never have done with boys around.'

The number of Guides has grown as the organisation has experimented with new ranges of outdoor activities during the last decade, but the number of Scouts has stayed at 450,000 since girl Scouts were first admitted in 1991. Just 6 per cent of Scouts are now female.

Hutchison, a farmer by trade, said: 'Nowadays at school girls are under more and more pressure to do what boys want and wear what they think they should.

'They have said that they want their own time together. They still want somewhere to go where they don't have to worry about boys. They will sometimes invite boys to events, but they want to do it on their own terms.'

Lord Baden-Powell, legendary hero of the siege of Mafeking, founded the Guides in 1910, after girls had tried unsuccessfully to join his fledgling Scout Association. The first Guide Handbook - How Girls Can Help Build Up the Empire - was published shortly afterwards.

Just over half of all women in the United Kingdom have been Girl Guides during their childhood. The movement's former members include Kate Adie, Emma Thompson, Julie Burchill and Mo Mowlam. Cherie Booth was once a Guide leader.

The Guides will also launch a recruitment programme this week for new leaders to join their current 70,000 adult helpers.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Arrest over tourist murder
Two men have been arrested in connection with the murder of British tourist, Wendy Sullivan, 26, who was found strangled on the island of Rhodes. They were named as Denis Pavlenko, 22, from Ukraine, and Roman Maximov, 19, from Moldova.
fields.body:
Arrest over tourist murder
Two men have been arrested in connection with the murder of British tourist, Wendy Sullivan, 26, who was found strangled on the island of Rhodes. They were named as Denis Pavlenko, 22, from Ukraine, and Roman Maximov, 19, from Moldova.

Surgeon arrested over death
Pravin Patel, 50, a surgeon from Harrow, was arrested and bailed on suspicion of manslaughter after the death during a routine operation of Andrew Ryan of Durham, in Shotley Bridge Hospital, Consett, in 1997.

Women drown in Wales
Two women in their twenties died after being swept out to sea while walking with friends in the early hours on the promenade at Colwyn Bay, North Wales.

Poet makes his mark at 86
Retired Oxford window cleaner Frederick Simpson, 86, has had his first book of poetry published, after writing from the age of 18. 'Threads', the achievement of a lifetime's ambition, contains 150 poems.

The hoopoe has landed
Birdwatchers at an Oxfordshire lake have sighted the hoopoe, a brightly coloured bird normally seen around the Mediterranean.

Eddie's splash
Formula One team owner Eddie Jordan has bought the biggest luxury yacht made in Britain, the 150ft Sunseeker 105, priced at £5 million.

Romance ends
Nicosia police have confiscated the French film 'Romance' because of the Cypriot censors' fears about its explicit sex scenes.

Turkey gets metro line
Istanbul's first metro line has opened, linking two business districts. It can carry up to 140,000 passengers an hour and is built to withstand earthquakes of 9.0 on the open-ended Richter scale.

Chechen rebels kill soldiers
Four Russian soldiers were killed when rebel fighters ambushed a military unit in Chechnya, the second attack in two days. Twelve died in an earlier assault.

webTitle: Was hunger striker the inspiration for Lloyd Webber's latest musical?

fields.headline: Was hunger striker the inspiration for Lloyd Webber's latest musical?
fields.standfirst: Ulster row as West End show imitates gritty real life story
fields.trailText: It is billed as an epic story of love and hate, contains catchy tunes and is set to run in the West End for years. So far, so Andrew Lloyd Webber. However, his new musical is different: set in Belfast just as the Troubles are exploding, it has young footballers as its central characters and sectarian strife as its backdrop.
fields.body:
It is billed as an epic story of love and hate, contains catchy tunes and is set to run in the West End for years. So far, so Andrew Lloyd Webber. However, his new musical is different: set in Belfast just as the Troubles are exploding, it has young footballers as its central characters and sectarian strife as its backdrop.

Complete with knee-cappings, The Beautiful Game's gritty themes are a far cry from fantasy-based Lloyd Webber productions such as Cats, Starlight Express or The Phantom of the Opera .

But controversy surrounds Lloyd Webber's unlikely foray into Northern Ireland's recent past. The composer insists The Beautiful Game is 'an original story' by his collaborator, Ben Elton - 'a story that could just as easily have been set in Kosovo, Beirut or Jerusalem'. However, surviving members of Belfast's only non-sectarian team of the late Sixties claim they were the inspiration for the composer's latest creation.

The similarities between fact and fiction are striking. The team of teenagers in The Beautiful Game are both Protestant and Catholic; so too was the Star of the Sea team from north Belfast.

Some players in the musical get involved with paramilitary violence; so too did vari ous Star of the Sea players who ended up in jail for terrorist activities. Among them was the IRA icon Bobby Sands, who died on hunger strike in 1981.

In the Elton-Lloyd Webber creation a Protestant player has a love-affair with a Catholic girl. And one of the Star of the Sea's team, Sammy Blair, who did time for illegal activities with the loyalist UDA, had a similar relationship - with Sands's sister.

Raymond McCord, a Protestant, played centre-half in the Star of the Sea side in the late Sixties which won almost every trophy in Irish junior football. 'I'm sure the Star of the Sea is the inspiration for the Lloyd Webber musical,' says McCord, who is now 46. 'We were the only mixed, non-denominational team in Northern Ireland at the time.' Michael O'Neill, the Catholic who coached the team at the time, has no doubt either. 'I'd like to think it was a tribute to the non-sectarian nature of Star of the Sea.'

Lloyd Webber acknowledges in his programme notes for The Beautiful Game that it is loosely based on an unnamed BBC documentary 'about a kids' football team in Belfast in 1969 and what had become of the youngsters in later life'.

Taken with their story, he showed it to Elton who quickly produced a 40-page synopsis about just such a team. Lloyd Webber and Elton had been talking about collaborating on a gritty, real-life drama just before this.

Yesterday the songwriter said he 'couldn't really remember much' about the documentary he had seen, its name or what it was about.

Aides say the programme was an episode of Fergal Keane's Irish Journeys in 1999 called The Boys of Summer about how the highly successful Holy Cross football team of the late Sixties in the Ardoyne in north Belfast was ripped apart by the violence that arrived soon after.

However, the Holy Cross team played Gaelic football, not soccer, and its members were all Catholics.

The Star of the Sea have also been the subject of a BBC documentary, called Old Scores. Lloyd Webber's programme notes could almost be describing Old Scores. Promotional notes which accompanied it when it was shown back in 1983 read: 'In the summer of 1969 a group of teenagers living on the outskirts of Belfast played together as a football team for the last time. Northern Ireland was about to erupt into sectarian violence.' Some later joined the loyalist UVF, others the IRA.

The Beautiful Game centres around two teammates, Del and John, one Protestant and the other Catholic.

Del's girlfriend is Christine, a Catholic. McCord says Del and Christine could easily be Sammy Blair and Majella Sands. 'Around the time we were doing so well in the late Sixties - we only lost two games in two years - they went out together for a while when they were both at school. Different schools, obviously, as they were different religions.

'He ended up in the loyalist paramilitaries and she was the sister of a republican hero. It's unbelievable how things turn out.'

When McCord knew Sands, he was 15 and known as 'Sandsy'. Worse names would follow. 'He wasn't an IRA man then. He was our left-back who just lived for football and didn't talk about politics or religion.' Nobody at Star of the Sea did.

Under the stern direction of Liam Conlon, a Belfast doctor, the team was stridently non-sectarian. 'There was friendly banter when Rangers or Celtic won or lost, but nothing more,' recalls O'Neill.

One of Sands's fellow defenders was Michael Atcheson. Within a couple of years, though, the onset of the Troubles had ruined their on-field partnership.

Increasing sectarian violence saw Sands's family intimidated out of their mixed estate. They fled to a Catholic ghetto in west Belfast.

The Star of the Sea team began to disintegrate and became almost entirely Catholic.

Soon after, Atcheson became a UVF terrorist. In 1974, as an 18-year-old, he machine-gunned a minibus full of workmen, injuring three Catholics, and was given 22 years in jail.

Atcheson's finger on the trigger signalled the death of Star of the Sea as an example of how football could bring people together. The beautiful game had failed to live up to its name.

Different schools, obviously, as they were different religions. 'He ended up in the loyalist paramilitaries and she was the sister of a republican hero. It's unbelievable how things turn out.' When McCord knew Sands, he was 15 and known as 'Sandsy'. Worse names would follow. 'He wasn't an IRA man then. He was our left-back who just lived for football and didn't talk about politics or religion.' Nobody at Star of the Sea did. Under the stern direction of Liam Conlon, a Belfast doctor, the team was stridently non-sectarian. 'There was friendly banter when Rangers or Celtic won or lost, but nothing more,' recalls O'Neill. One of Sands's fellow defenders was Michael Atcheson. Within a couple of years, though, the onset of the Troubles had ruined their on-field partnership. Increasing sectarian violence saw Sands's family intimidated out of their mixed estate. They fled to a Catholic ghetto in west Belfast. The Star of the Sea team began to disintegrate and became almost entirely Catholic. Soon after, Atcheson became a UVF terrorist. In 1974, as an 18-year-old, he machine-gunned a minibus full of workmen, injuring three Catholics, and was given 22 years in jail. Atcheson's finger on the trigger signalled the death of Star of the Sea as an example of how football could bring people together. The beautiful game had failed to live up to its name. denis.campbell@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Reduce speed now
fields.standfirst: Slow down. The way you eat is as crucial as what you eat. And wolfing down your food is the quickest way to make a pig of yourself
fields.trailText: Slow down. The way you eat is as crucial as what you eat. And wolfing down your food is the quickest way to make a pig of yourself
fields.body:
At a dinner party last week, I was asked to tell the other guests more about my work. Although I tried to skirt around the subject, not wishing to monopolise the conversation, my fellow guests insisted that I at least tell them what my patients most commonly see me for. You may guess that I primarily see people who are overweight, but this isn't so.

I actually spend more time treating people who have a whole raft of health problems, largely resulting from the fact that they simply don't eat properly, and not just in terms of the foods that they consume - something like 90 per cent of the people I see have problems because they eat too quickly, and in a manner that prevents them from gleaning the maximum benefit from food.

More often than not, meal times are rushed affairs: a croissant is bought while running for the bus, a sandwich is devoured at the desk, while a TV dinner or bowl of pasta downed before crashing into bed are the most likely evening scenarios. Society seems to collude in encouraging such unhealthy eating patterns, too, with schools that urge their pupils to consume lunch in 10 minutes flat and our long working hours forcing us to ignore our hunger pangs to the point of having to eat as soon as possible after arriving home at the end of a punishing day. All in all, eating has become a joyless procedure that we tend to rush rather than savour.

Before taking you through the physiological aspects of the appetite mechanism, it's important to note that changing how you eat is not an easy task (I compare it to learning to ride a bike: you'll get the hang of it for a few seconds and then you'll fall off, discouraging you from trying again). But if you're determined to conquer bad eating habits, you will reap immeasurable rewards. As soon as you start eating in a way that assists your body in knowing when it's had enough, and also helps it to digest food efficiently, then the final part of the puzzle - eating health-giving foods - will slot smoothly into place. If you eat well in the basic sense - that is, chew food properly and in a manner that aids digestion - nutrients will be enabled to begin to work on improving your general wellbeing. But do remember, in the majority of cases, abandoning the habit of wolfing down food without really registering what you're eating will take weeks rather than days, so give yourself time.

Your body initially takes in valuable information about food through the nose and eyes. Aromas from cooking and the inviting appearance of food on a plate - say fresh figs wrapped in their individual paper, or cheese nestled in an enticing box - all encourage your sensory organs to send anticipatory signals to your hypothalamus (the part of the brain that recognises hunger and satiety), which prepares your body for the prospect of feeling satisfyingly full. Present food in an appealing way, because if it looks tempting, you'll derive maximum satisfaction from it. Rather than grabbing a chunk of unappetising food as you pass the fridge, make yourself stop what you are doing and take the time to appreciate food, lay the table and arrange some food on an attractive plate, even if you're only having a snack.

Both the taste and feel of food in your mouth will stimulate your appetite and encourage greater satiety. If you regularly eat similar foods, or have more than a couple of consecutive mouthfuls of the same food, the hypothalamus will register very little satisfaction. By contrast, if you mix interesting flavours with varying temperatures and textures within a meal (by following a mouthful of chicken with one of salad or roasted vegetables, for example), your brain will respond to these multiple stimuli and will tell you when you've eaten enough. The foods that offer the highest satisfaction value are therefore those that have several organoleptic properties - in other words, they stimulate more than one sense: they smell good, look good, feel good in the mouth and taste good.

If you eat quickly, your digestive system has very little time to manufacture the enzymes and acids that are needed to break down the food that it receives into easily absorbed particles, making you prone to indigestion and other digestive disorders. Chewing your food too rapidly also means that you are depriving yourself of another means of judging whether you are full or still hungry. When you chew, stretch receptors within the jaw send their responses to the brain, so the more you chew, and the more time you take over eating, the greater your brain's perception of satiety. Take short breaks during the course of a meal and have small mouthfuls of food, punctuated by sips of water to refresh the palate, all of which will intensify the next flavours that your tastebuds detect, resulting in a significant impact on your hypothalamus.

Some interesting research recently suggested that the bodies of some obese people may be deficient in leptin, a protein that assists the brain to recognise when it's full, with the result that they carry on eating because they don't feel satiated. This theory doesn't appear to stand up, however, as not only do the bodies of other overweight people produce significant quantities of leptin, but in my professional experience, confirmed by letters that I have received from readers, the majority of people can train themselves to change their eating habits for the better and are then to feel full when they should.

Because my Bodyfoods healthy-eating lifestyle enables you to eat the foods you love, but also to know when you've had enough, you shouldn't put on weight or develop digestive problems. Given time, most people will find that they will derive greater satisfaction from their food, as well as from the eating experience as a whole, if they understand the physiological aspects of their appetite mechanisms and adjust their eating habits accordingly.

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ...saving the planet
fields.trailText: ...saving the planet
fields.body:
With the news that the hole in the ozone layer now embraces the tip of South America, and evidence that global warming is melting polar ice packs, it is not too late to think about doing your bit for the environment.

Certain green habits are cost-free. Start a compost with all your household's organic waste, from teabags to eggshells. Glass, paper, plastic and aluminium should all be recycled. Conserve water by taking showers instead of baths (consider sharing with a companion, for extra eco-friendliness).

However, to take this planet-saving business seriously you are going to have to open your wallet. The key is reducing energy consumption: around 13 per cent of UK electricity output is used to wash clothes - and if electricity is not produced by inefficiently burning fossil fuels, it is produced by a possibly more dubious nuclear power plant. So spend a little more on a low-power 'Ecolabel' washing machine (from £420).

Then choose an energy-efficient refrigerator - one that uses less than 150 kilowatts per hour annually. Hydrocarbon refrigerants (HC) have little effect on the ozone layer and global warming, unlike CFCs and HFCs (hydrofluorocarbons), and only add about £50 to the cost of a fridge.

Lightbulbs have not changed much since Edison's day - an electrical current is passed through thin metal wire and just 10 per cent of the energy is converted to light (the rest becomes heat). Unless you buy a £15 Compact Fluorescent Lamp (CFL) which uses 75 per cent less electricity, lasts 10 times longer than a standard bulb and pays for itself after 2,000 hours of use.

The most environmentally sound mode of transport remains the bicycle, which is not only cheap but will also keep you fit. The average car produces 4.4 tonnes of carbon dioxide, 32.5kg of carbon monoxide and substantial quantities of sulphur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide each year.

Optimists should also consider a solar-powered water heater (installations from £800 to £3,000), while a photovoltaic power supply for your house's energy demands will be £20,000.

Perhaps the most effective way to save the planet is to set about buying it: you can protect an acre of rainforest for £25 with Rainforest Concern.

webTitle: Plots for sale on the moon - whose loony idea is that?

fields.headline: Plots for sale on the moon - whose loony idea is that?
fields.standfirst: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: Fancy a slice of pie in the sky? Newly launched website MoonEstates.com is 'selling' land on the moon at the bargain rate of £10 an acre, plus £5 for VAT and registration.
fields.body:
Fancy a slice of pie in the sky? Newly launched website MoonEstates.com is 'selling' land on the moon at the bargain rate of £10 an acre, plus £5 for VAT and registration.

The company claims to have secured exclusive rights in the UK to legally sell land on the moon, thanks to a loophole in the Outer Space Treaty of 1967, which bans nations from owning territory in space but neglects to do the same for individuals.

Francis Williams, one of the two Cornwall-based 'entrepreneurs' who set up MoonEstates and self-appointed UK lunar ambassador, says: 'The concept of owning a piece of the moon is such a cool one, especially when it is so affordable, that it simply captured our imagination. The moon represents huge potential - we're looking into using it as a tax haven and opening the first lunar bank.'

The company, which is selling land only on 'the lit side of the moon visible to us here on Earth', believes buyers could benefit from growing demand for space travel. 'Research shows potential demand for space tourism in the UK to be 58.3 per cent, with 45.4 per cent of the British public believing that space tourism will begin by 2015.'

In addition to the acre of land, the company says the £15 package includes deeds, a map pinpointing the property, the Lunar Constitution and Bill of Rights, and a document confirming the owner's mineral rights.

The company claims 5,000 people have already spent £65,000 on plots and moon-related merchandise.

Williams says land on the moon has been on sale in the US since 1980; owners include former presidents Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, John Travolta, Christopher Reeve, Harrison Ford, Tom Cruise and a number of Nasa employees.

Tempted? Don't be.

The British National Space Centre says the whole concept is cheesy: 'MoonEstates can't sell property on the moon because it isn't theirs to sell. The legal principle of res communis applies to outer space - which means it belongs to everyone. Not only can it not be appropriated to the sovereignty of individual states, neither can it be bought and sold by individuals: they simply don't own it in the first place. The 1967 Outer Space Treaty makes this clear,' it says.

If this isn't enough to deter you, just think about the neighbours: to promote the scheme, MoonEstates has given plots to Chris Tarrant and Chris Evans.

webTitle: Can they gain their degrees without too much pain for us?

fields.headline: Can they gain their degrees without too much pain for us?
fields.standfirst: Des and Julie ask  Margaret Dibben how best to use a £22,000 inheritance to put their sons through university
fields.trailText: A few years ago, Des and Julie Browning decided that they no longer needed two cars and planned to get rid of one. They used the money from a redundancy cheque to repay the debt but, before they had sold the vehicle, changed their minds and kept two cars after all. Without the loan, they were saving £250 a month in interest charges but found they were no better off. Des says ruefully: 'We should have invested the money immediately in something like a Pep but we have two sons and teenagers are an expensive item.'
fields.body:
A few years ago, Des and Julie Browning decided that they no longer needed two cars and planned to get rid of one. They used the money from a redundancy cheque to repay the debt but, before they had sold the vehicle, changed their minds and kept two cars after all. Without the loan, they were saving £250 a month in interest charges but found they were no better off. Des says ruefully: 'We should have invested the money immediately in something like a Pep but we have two sons and teenagers are an expensive item.'

Now Des is about to inherit £22,000 from his late mother. This means he could pay off his current car loan of £11,000 which runs until 2004 but is reluctant to do so because of his previous experience. He will, though, pay off the £2,000 debt on his credit card.

Mainly he wants to use the inheritance to help his two sons, Andrew and David, with the huge expense of university. Andrew could go to university next year and David four years later: 'We want them to get through university without having too big a millstone round their necks at the end. But we also want to avoid having to cut our cloth a bit tighter.'

He does not know how much the university education might cost but would like advice on where to invest for it: 'I don't think we can tie the money up for five years in stock market investments but putting it in a savings account doesn't seem very efficient.'

Des started work as a civil servant in the DSS but says: 'I could see where the money was.' He did a year's IT training course and stayed in the civil service for a while but then moved out: 'IT civil servants are better paid than most but they are not as well paid as in industry and commerce.'

He has been in a money purchase pension scheme since April, to which he makes Additional Voluntary Contributions of 5 per cent, and has 24 years contributions in another final salary scheme.

Until two years ago, Des and Julie had a endowment mortgage but, when they heard there might be a £3,000 shortfall, switched to a £70,000 repayment loan which ends in 12 years. The endowment policy will give them about £43,000.

Their investments are £4,000 in a building society, £1,000 in Premium Bonds and 200 shares in Manchester United which, says Des, is more of an emotional investment than a financial one. 'I might as well have bought 10 shares, or one, if I wanted to be a shareholder but at least they have gone up about £1.30 a share since I bought.'

Adviser 1: Neil Bailey

Des and Julie should repay the credit cards and the car loan from the inheritance. The car loan costs 8 per cent net and they would need 10 per cent from a deposit account to justify not repaying it. I suggest they set up a standing order to a deposit account, earmarked for university costs, to save the amount that they would have spent on credit payments so the money will not be available to spend. Saving £390 a month gives them £4,680 plus interest by the time their first son goes to university. With the balance of the inheritance - £9,600 - they have a total £14,280 plus interest. It is vital that they establish a budget for the cost of educating both sons . They can expect to pay £8,000 a year each if they study in London and £6,500 elsewhere, before extra costs such as paying for an active social life.

Assuming the elder son studies outside London, he will need, say, £6,500 a year. If he takes a Student Loan of £3,445, this leaves a shortfall of £3,055 for the parents to find. They could save £3,960 from repaying the loans so they should be able to cover the further education costs without a negative impact on their current standard of living.

They could use a combination of cash and investment ISAs investing in corporate bond funds to put their savings into a tax shelter. Corporate bond funds do not guarantee protection of the capital but they can provide high yields - headline yields of 9 per cent are available.

Neil Bailey works for The Sensible Financial Planning Co in Winslow.

Adviser 2: Carolyn Corless

Paying for university will take priority over saving for Des and Julie's retirement for the next few years and, with only a modest capital sum, most of the education costs will have to be met from current income. They should avoid investments that tie up their capital for the long term and go for cash investments. Des might think this inefficient but their options are limited by the short timescale.

They should repay the credit card debt and the car loan, providing there are no penalties. I understand their reasons for not repaying the loan but the interest payments could be better used to fund education. If they divert the loan costs into an instant access account by standing order, they should avoid being tempted to spend the cash.

Nationwide's Internet account pays 7 per cent; Bristol & West's post/ phone account 6.85 per cent. The Brownings should calculate how much they can save over the next year and then use part of the inheritance to top up this account to cover the first year's university cost. They could also invest in a fixed rate bond; Northern Rock is paying 7.25 per cent gross.

They should both invest £3,000 in a cash ISA. Smile pays 7.25 per cent on its internet-based ISA account; Alliance & Leicester pays 7 per cent gross on its phone/postal ISA.

The existing savings should be retained as an emergency fund.

Carolyn Corless works for Sully's Financial Planning, Bideford.

Advice is for guidance only.

fields.headline: Setting the maisons in order
fields.standfirst: A further instalment of her French property diary finds  Natalie Sutton with a roof over her head, but 'bifteks' walking out the door
fields.trailText: After three weeks of working on our hamlet, things are beginning to take shape. Two habitable houses have been wired up in the hope that we will soon be connected to the power mains. For reasons particular to our property, this is taking longer than we expected.
fields.body:
After three weeks of working on our hamlet, things are beginning to take shape. Two habitable houses have been wired up in the hope that we will soon be connected to the power mains. For reasons particular to our property, this is taking longer than we expected.

On the positive side, however, the plumber has devised a clever system of bringing water from the spring outside directly into our house without the use of a single bucket. We now have an impressive collection of pipes and tanks, and a water pump in the basement. Rather than relying on a hill to provide pressure for a shower, we now have a water pump that springs into action when pressure is low and keeps the tank full. We also have two splendid flushing loos which work . Having encountered groups of five or more sangliers (wild boar) snuffling around the terraces and gardens at night, their tusks glinting in the moonlight, I'm very relieved that the khazi al fresco is no longer a necessity. Boars can be dangerous if cornered, and running with your trousers around your ankles is not the best way to escape.

We now even have a big shiny water heater in the basement, which will give us 300 litres of piping hot water. But for the whole plumbing system to work properly, we need constant electricity.

And while keeping warm is a worry in winter, refrigeration was a necessity this summer, when temperatures reached about 40 C in the shade. Tins don't suffer so much, but any fresh produce was crawling out of the door within a few hours of leaving the market.

I made the mistake of buying some meat; it lasted a day before turning into a seething mass of white maggots. This encouraged us to dabble with vegetarianism, but I can't see that as a long-term solution.

Lack of electricity is our major stumbling block. We got into a quasi routine of running a generator for a noisy couple of hours a day in an attempt to keep the hot water hot, the fridge anything cooler than lukewarm and the water tank filled. But it had a habit of breaking down, usually when I was showering and had a headful of shampoo.

The subsequent silence was deafening. After a few breakdowns, we learnt how to check the spark-plug, oil and fuel, but inevitably an embarrassing call to the electrician would follow, with us begging him to fix the recalcitrant machine.

A mason is starting work soon to save the wall of the fourth house. The lack of a roof means water gets into the mortarless walls: the stones give up the unequal struggle and fall away. The mason needs to take down the wall completely and rebuild it. He was going to construct some sort of ledge to prevent future rainfall damaging the wall, but, since he is there and the scaffolding will be in place, it seems wiser to go the whole hog and have a new roof put on now.

Our budget wasn't quite prepared for this, but in the long run it will be cheaper than asking the mason and his team to make a return visit. We will therefore have one more habitable house.

Plans are afoot to replace another roof - one our predecessors misguidedly modernised in a rather ugly material called 'shingle', adding three dormer windows that don't really fit with the 300-year-old look. Although this gave it more light, aesthetically it's a total disaster. Monsieur le Maçon is therefore going to replace it with old terracotta tiles to match the other roofs.

On each of his visits we have asked his advice on all the walls, roofs and buildings in general. One wall seems a strange shape, a leak persists here, and there is a missing window there. He looks at the problem in question, sighs heavily and says: 'It's not a priority, but we'll have to sort it out.'

I have a suspicion that we shall get to know him rather well as time goes on. He instigated the first stage of this friendship by arriving one night with a box of sausages and several bottles of good wine for us all to share. All we were able to offer in return was a look at the moon through the telescope but he seemed quite pleased with that - especially when the mayor's children, who had joined the party, convinced him that they could see a Martian on a bicycle.

Never a dull moment on our mountain.

Shuttered up at the end of the holidays, when the weather had the courtesy to cloud over for the first time, the houses looked vulnerable - open to the elements and to all kinds of intruders.

I can't help feeling that I should be there full-time to look after them.

fields.headline: Whatever you do - don't panic
fields.trailText: Oil prices close to their all-time high, rationing of bread and milk, the Confederation of British Industry warning of the shut-down of large parts of the economy, cancelled operations and funeral directors warning of 'far-reaching' health implications. It could be the 1970s instead of the first year of the new millennium.
fields.body:
Oil prices close to their all-time high, rationing of bread and milk, the Confederation of British Industry warning of the shut-down of large parts of the economy, cancelled operations and funeral directors warning of 'far-reaching' health implications. It could be the 1970s instead of the first year of the new millennium.

But will it become like the Seventies for investors too? That was one of the worst-ever decades for shares. A £100 investment at the end of 1969 had fallen to just £46 a decade later, after allowing for the effect of inflation. Savers would have had to wait until 1986 to recoup the value of their investment.

So should you bail out of the market now? While oil prices have soared to near 1970s levels, that is where the similarity ends. Then go-slows, shortages and the three-day week were caused by strikes and the inefficiency of British industry. Last week, the problems were solely due to the success of a few farmers and lorry drivers in blocking oil refineries. While the disruption was real, it was easily reversible. The impact on the economy, and thus on company profits, will be slight and short-lived. Much more difficult to assess, however, is the long-term effect of high oil prices.

In the past 18 months, the price of crude oil has trebled and it now stands at more than $35 a barrel. The mar kets are still not that perturbed, however. The FTSE-100 is 5 per cent below its all-time high ,largely because the boom in technology stocks has run out of steam.

Still, investors in the US and the UK refuse to panic about an oil price shock. That makes some sense. In the Seventies, the market was dominated by industrial companies - chemical giants such as ICI or Chloride. Now half of the all-share index, and about three-quarters of the FTSE-100 index, comprises just four sectors: oils, banks, pharmaceuticals and telecoms. Oil companies benefit from high oil prices and the other three are largely immune to it. Unless, that is, the oil price spike is followed by a prolonged recession but few economists are predicting that. They point out that the much-vaunted new economy is not a big consumer of fuel so a high oil price is not likely to throw it off course.

So far, there is no sign of the boom ending and the high oil price is not yet feeding through to inflation. The test will come if that happens while growth slows. Where do interest rates go then? If growth is slowing you might want to cut rates, but if oil prices are still high, you might want to increase interest rates to curb inflation increases. There is no need yet for panic selling but likewise, it would be wise not to rush into the market.

fields.headline: Sitting pretty on the buses
fields.trailText: Paula Whitney lives on the island of Mersea, 10 miles from Colchester. Having relied on her car for 18 years, an accident six years ago prompted Paula to switch to public transport.
fields.body:
Paula Whitney lives on the island of Mersea, 10 miles from Colchester. Having relied on her car for 18 years, an accident six years ago prompted Paula to switch to public transport.

As well as complying with her environmental concerns, Paula has found her costs to be lower. 'I get quite cross when people see me at the bus stop and offer me a lift because they're taking away my reading time,' she says.

'The benefits are enormous. A bus journey may be slower but it ends in the centre of town. You're not restricted by parking tickets expiring and you can make circular journeys without needing to go back and pick the car up.' Paula insists that travel on trains and buses with the occasional taxi is far cheaper than running a car: 'If you look carefully you can find deals offered by operators which really do bring the cost down.'

Network South East offers an annual travelcard for £20 which allows a third off all journeys for Paula and up to three friends travelling with her. Any children accompanying her travel for £1.

Paula and her grandson can travel from Colchester to London and back for £11.65. 'You could only park for a couple of hours in central London for that,' she says.

There is an alternative...

fields.headline: My roots
fields.standfirst: A week in Monty's garden
fields.trailText: A week in Monty's garden
fields.body:
I love September. I love the chill mornings and the hot midday sun, and the garden loves it, too. We came back from holiday to find the garden in a surpsingly soft, benign mood - a little boring but a gentle place to be. I think of September as a month of fruit, box cuttings, sunflowers, fennel, leonotis, zinnias, cosmos, tobacco plants, Clematis viticella 'Purpurea Plena Elegans' and sweetcorn. The cabbages become bulky, and dew, hawthorne, willow and field maple are all yellowing and there's a dusty well-worn feeling, like an old shoe, that is somehow so much more attractive than August's tired valiance.

I left for holiday feeling disillusioned with the garden but have returned with fresh impetus. My main concern is to simplify the place. I want less of the cluttered, busy mass of English borders and more of the rigorous blocks and spaces which feel American or European to me. Pretentious? Who cares? The one place that you can pretend anything is in your garden. It is, after all, only a game.

The first stage will be to create new raised beds in the orchard for veg, and to use space in the existing veg garden for simpler blocks of crops. I will also remove all the woven hazel fences from around the vegetable beds and replace them with oak boards with a box hedge.

I have been blaming slugs and snails for the past two months for eating our tomatoes. Dozens have been gnawed into, starting with a hole which is then raggedly widened around the softer edges. The beefsteak tomatoes, such as 'Marmande', were worst hit. My hatred for slugs tightened another notch.

But I owe the slugs an apology. Yesterday I walked into the tunnel and discovered half a dozen of our hens happily pecking away at the tomatoes. A light clicked on in the dim recesses of my frontal lobes. It was them all along. The bastards! Seething, I went into full-blown Basil Fawlty mode, frogmarching them back to their run. As if my life wasn't complicated enough.

Anyone who keeps hens knows each egg costs about as much as a dozen prime, organic, free-range eggs from a supermarket and that they demand constant attention. At bottom they are vile, malicious creatures. So Tom and I made screens to go across the greenhouse and tunnel doors, to keep hens out, and to let the ventilation and lovely, harmless slugs in.

fields.headline: Six of the best...
fields.standfirst: Dark autumn berries for the season of mellow fruitfulness.
fields.trailText: Dark autumn berries for the season of mellow fruitfulness.
fields.body:
With the exception of elderberries (available only in the wild), dark autumn fruits are easily obtainable. Blueberries and blackberries have joined the ranks of cultivated fruits to provide a regular yet varied seasonal larder.

Waitrose sells blueberries from France and Poland (£1.89 for 425g, or 99p for 200g), Black Diamond plums from Italy (£2.39 per kg), black Italia grapes (£1.69 per kg), and purple Turkish figs (39p each).

Damsons inhabit a halfway house: although grown on a domestic scale, and with a short season, they are on sale (at £1.49 per 500g) in about 150 branches of Sainsbury's . Among their suppliers is Jill Mycock of Mockbeggar Farm in Kent, who grows Shropshire and Farleigh varieties at what is now the end of the season. Her annual 20 tons are picked directly into the punnet to avoid excessive handling. The fruit can be held for a couple of weeks at low temperature without spoilage, and can be frozen at home. Damsons come to little harm in the short term, so it is worth buying more than you need whenever you come across them.

Around 60 tons of blackberries are also part of Mockbeggar's output, with the tangy, monster-sized Loch Ness variety and sweeter Triple Crown now in season (£1.29 for 250g). Sainsbury's also sells Turkish figs (four for £1), purple plums from Spain and Israel (£1.99 per kg), and cultivated English blueberries from Kent and Herefordshire (99p per 125g).

Further north, John Cushing at Goldstone Hall, Market Drayton, Shropshire (01630 661 202) neatly combines a seasonal glut, a quiet time in the restaurant calendar and a local tradition in his Damson Feast. Market Drayton once had a damson fair in September, when mill owners would buy as much as they could transport in order to extract a dye for the textile industry. The fair has gone, but Goldstone Hall's five-course Damson Feast, held on 13 October (£22) and 14 October (£25), incorporates roast goose with damson chutney, damson ice cream, elderberry tart and blackberry crème brlée.

Further north still, if the weather has been kind in the past few days, there may still be some damsons available (for 65p per lb) at the the Lyth Valley Farm Shop, Dawson Fold, Cumbria (01539 568 248, closed Monday). Harvesting the fruit is not the easiest job in the word, but owner Christine Walling's 70-year-old picker has more than enough experience, and is able to collect 200lb on a good day. 'Heaven knows what I'll do if he pops his clogs.'

Other sources of purple fruits include PYO and farm shops, one of the latter being The Kitchen Garden, Oldown Estate, Tockington, near Bristol (01454 413 605). The damson and blackberry season is virtually over, but Robert Bernays expects to have some dark plums at around 70p per lb. What variety? 'It sounds pathetic, but I don't know,' he says: his Victorian walled garden was stocked with plums when he bought it 20 years ago, and they didn't have labels.

The most comprehensive collection of plums in the country is kept by Brogdale Horticultural Trust, Brogdale Road, Faversham, Kent (01795 535 286), a living archive dedicated to promoting the natural diversity of temperate fruits. It is open every day (£2.50 for a guided tour), sells fruit on site and supplies Waitrose.

Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide

fields.headline: Best cellars
fields.standfirst: Two tasty clarets and two New World alternatives
fields.trailText: Two tasty clarets and two New World alternatives
fields.body:
1999 Antares Merlot, Santa Carolina (£3.99, Sainsbury's)

This may or may not contain a percentage of Carmenère, but who's bothered about varietal purity if the wine tastes as good as this well-priced, plummy red. Chile at its value-for-money best.

1998 Chteau Haut-Limonier, Bordeaux (£4.99, Safeway)

Proof that claret doesn't have to be undrinkable under £5, this blend of equal parts Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot has plenty of colour, classic cassis and lead-pencil aromas, medium tannins and no obvious oak. A good find.

1998 Metala Shiraz/ Cabernet, Langhorne Creek (£7.49, Oddbins; Safeway)

Some branches may still be on the 1997 vintage of this spicy, liquorice and black fruits-dominated stunner from South Australia. If so, wait for the superior 1998. A delicious wine with well-integrated oak and lots of character.

1995 Chteau Tayac, Margaux, Cru Bourgeois (£16.50, Waitrose; Waitrose Direct on 0800 18881)

One of the best crus bourgeois, typified by this aromatic, stylishly oaked red from one of the top 90s vintages. Its subtlety grows on you with every sip.

fields.headline: The man who dressed a decade
fields.standfirst: Ten years after the death of Ray Petri, one of the most influential stylists of the 80s, we bring his Buffalo team together again. By Kathryn Flett
fields.trailText: Ten years after the death of Ray Petri, one of the most influential stylists of the 80s, we bring his Buffalo team together again. By Kathryn Flett
fields.body:
David Beckham almost certainly doesn't know this, but without the influence of the late Ray Petri he would never have worn that famous sarong. There was no Premier League when Petri was alive and football had yet to be fetishised (and Hornby-ised) by the middle classes, but the idea of a gifted, internationally famous, pretty-but-straight, fashion-obsessed, married gay icon of a young footballer wearing a skirt in the street? Ray would have loved it.

Had he lived, Petri would have celebrated his 52nd birthday yesterday. Instead he died in 1989, just shy of his 42nd birthday and at the tail end of the decade he helped to define by producing powerfully idiosyncratic images, under the pseudo-corporate 'label' Buffalo, for the pages of the then fledgling 'style' magazines, The Face , i-D and Arena .

In the early 80s, Petri coralled a pool of young model-muses (Nick and Barry Kamen, Tony Felix, Simon de Montfort, Howard Napper) and photographers (Jamie Morgan, Roger Charity, Marc Lebon), plus assorted, like-minded west London creatives: hair and make-up artists, musicians, designers, acolytes, allies, cohorts, and hangers-on for whom Petri, the cool, charming, funny, shy-but-gregarious nexus of the group was also a charismatic uncle confessor-cum-mentor-cum-role model. 'People tend to associate the word Buffalo with Bob Marley's 'Buffalo Soldier',' Ray once explained, 'but in fact it's a Caribbean expression to describe people who are rude boys or rebels. Not necessarily tough, but hard style taken from the street... a functional and stylish look; non-fashion with a hard attitude.'

Petri was born in Dundee and moved to Brisbane, Australia when his family emigrated there in his teens. By the mid-70s he was back in Britain, running a stall in north London's Camden Passage antiques market. Moving in creative circles among art students and photographers, he'd decided to become a photographer's agent, recruiting some raw talent in the form of Marc Lebon and Jamie Morgan. Still, he soon discovered he preferred a more hands-on approach to fashion photography: the casting and styling of images for which there was, at that time, only a very limited audience. 'It can be no surprise that Ray showed up at our door,' says Nick Logan, founder editor of The Face and Arena , 'Other than i-D , where else would he have gone?'

In the early 80s, fashion photography was still largely the preserve of the glossies, but at The Face and i-D , Ray's vision coincided with the very beginning of what has subsequently become the commercialisation and mass consumption of street style. Petri played skilfully with the iconography and mythology of the heterosexual modern hero and the homo-erotic muse. He created new breeds of free-range urban cowboys in Ray-Ban aviators and hats; a suited and booted beauty accessorised by a feathered Native American headdress; a smiling black boxer with a blowsy red rose tucked behind his ear; boys in highly polished brogues worn with tracksuits; Crombie coats teamed with shorts; sportswear and couture; kilts and diamanté_ and the definitive Petri Buffalo garment, the no-nonsense Nylon MA1 army surplus flight jacket, lined in bright orange, teamed with Levi's 501s: the look that evolved into the predominant urban male uniform of the 80s.

From expressing the style of a small gang of west London movers and shakers, Buffalo hit the big time when the heavily pregnant Neneh Cherry took her Buffalo stance from Notting Hill to the Top of the Pops studio and the charts. Funny, but just a few years before the Spices and All Saints bared their big-bellies-as-fashion-statements, the sight of an eight-month-pregnant Neneh gyrating, fecund-but-sexy, on TOTP was a small stylistic watershed - if not the first sign that the 80s were all but over and the in-touch-with-its-feminine-side 90s were on the way. Though necessarily identified with the 80s, Petri would have much preferred both the 90s and the zero-zeros, politically, emotionally, culturally, socially and visually - but then Ray was always ahead of his time.

Petri was a fashion stylist long before this was a coveted job description and another amorphous by-product of the global fashion industry. Indeed, in the early 80s, selecting and arranging clothes on models was still known, if it was known at all, as 'fashion editing', but he was an instinctive stylist, using his visual flair and magpie intelligence to produce elegant, unfussy and invariably sensual images of timeless modernity.

Petri didn't live long enough to get rich on the back of the fact that his visual influence has now been almost totally absorbed into fashion's mainstream, turned into a hugely successful, branded, marketable, logo-ised industry. Likewise, he never worked with many of the people in the business whom he has inspired directly - the gifted Austrian designer Helmut Lang, say, or, indirectly, the skilled marketeer Tommy Hilfiger, or David Beckham, or any of the tens of thousands of visually savvy teenagers and twentysomethings whose easy, confident mix of fashion and sportswear has been the predominant urban style over the past decade. But in high fashion circles, among names like Giorgio Armani and Jean Paul Gaultier (both of whom he knew well and collaborated with) to today's younger generation of career stylists on their fat, glossy-magazine salaries, advertising contracts and handsome retainers with the corporates, Petri's name commands awesome respect.

Ray Petri was a genuinely charismatic figure. The sort of man who, even if you had your back to the door, one still sensed had made an entrance. Tall, smiling and handsome with slightly sad eyes and a gently penetrating gaze, I first met him in the early 80s as a young fashion writer at i-D . He instantly brought out my inner, slavering groupie, but was always sweet enough to pretend he hadn't noticed. Then, in 1987, I moved on to become The Face 's first fashion editor and, for a while, learning on the job, I sometimes felt I was working under false pretences. In fashion terms, there was probably nobody whose approval I sought more than Ray's, but whatever he really thought about my wobbly fashion vision, he was never less than a gent and always treated me as a creative equal.

In 1988, I vividly remember Ray coming into the office for a meeting. Seeing his face bearing the unmistakeable stigmata of Kaposi's Sarcoma, I immediately fled the office in tears and angrily walked round the block, muttering 'not fair, not fair, not fair_' before pulling myself together and - mascara messily smeared - having the meeting. Ray didn't bat an eyelid, he was far too big - and too cool - for that. But he was no saint and was not without ego. Indeed, before his death, he had enough of a sense of his burgeoning influence and potential legacy to be editing pictures for a project that, 11 years down the line, has evolved into a beautiful book, Buffalo , edited, written and designed by the Buffalo boys and girls he considered to be as close, if not closer, than family. And as Life magazine's Buffalo reunion portrait reveals, they still are. Now there's a legacy to be proud of.
