fields.headline: Sales slump hits Littlewoods
fields.standfirst: Moores family hopes of flotation in jeopardy as catalogue firm lurches from crisis to crisis
fields.trailText: Moores family hopes of flotation in jeopardy as catalogue firm lurches from crisis to crisis
fields.body:
Littlewoods, the catalogue and stores chain, has been hit by a severe sales slump which threatens a stock market flotation expected by the controlling Moores family.

The problems, plus rock bottom staff morale, may also fuel a rebellion against the board, which is headed by chairman James Ross and chief executive Barry Gibson.

Retail trading conditions are tough, but the Liverpool-based group has been hit harder than rivals by changes of strategy, a poor spring/ summer clothing range, catalogue warehouse chaos and the departure of key home shopping executives, senior Littlewoods' insiders say.

Chaos at the company's main distribution centre has left catalogue customers waiting and hundreds of containers full of stock at Southampton and Liverpool Freeport, say Littlewoods' sources.

The Moores family gathers on Thursday for its annual general meeting and the board is expected to face growing criticism once the full extent of the problems are understood. 'The business is doing very badly. The background is dreadful,' one family member said. 'If we could muster enough votes, we would get a new chair and a new chief executive to change direction.'

Littlewoods is still owned by 32 members of the founding family, who have taken a hands-off approach since rejecting a £1.2 billion bid in 1995 and appointing Ross, a former chief executive of Cable & Wireless, in 1996.

The clan is riven by factions but, family sources say, 20 per cent of the shareholders are already hostile to the board. Most of the shares are now in the hands of grandchildren of founder Sir John Moores who are eager to cash in through a flotation.

Last week Gibson denied Littlewoods had any stock market plans. Insiders confirm, however, that the family expects a flotation by the end of 2002 at the latest.

'The grandchildren will stay on side as long as the board can point to M&S and John Lewis and blame problems on the market,' one senior source said. 'But once they realise they run far deeper, the family could get a nasty shock. I think they can forget about flotation now.'

Littlewoods' retail trading profits fell 20 per cent to £125 million in 1999/2000. However, the firm had budgeted for £168m following its new strat egy of integrating stores and catalogue operations, according to documents leaked to The Observer.

Last week, in an effort to boost sales, Gibson launched a fresh strategy - Better Value Retailing - introducing more low-priced items to Littlewoods' stores. He also told The Observer the catalogue warehouse difficulties were resolved by the middle of last month. But further leaked documents show that the problems continued, resulting in worse service, can celled orders and discounting to boost poor sales.

Two weeks ago, Littlewoods completed the sale of its football pools operations for £161m to local entrepreneur Trevor Hemmings, who owns Blackpool Tower.

That marked a further reversal of a strategy adopted in 1996, which was to focus on home shopping, keep the pools but sell off the stores. A part of the proceeds, however, is likely be distributed as a sweetener to the family.

fields.headline: Teddy bears, Union Jacks... and the music's pretty good too
fields.trailText: Last Night of the Proms |  Tosca |  Lebrecht Live
fields.body:
Last Night of the Proms Royal Albert Hall, London SW7/ BBC1 and 2, Radio 3
Tosca Royal Opera House/ Covent Garden Piazza, London WC2
Lebrecht Live Radio 3

Cheered on by 40,000 promenaders in Hyde Park, as well as crowds in Birmingham, Liverpool and the Albert Hall itself, Andrew Davis piloted his final Last Night of the Proms after 11 years as chief conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. The relief was that, hooting, tooting and teddy-bear waving aside, this was a musically rewarding finale. In addition, satisfying more than usually heightened audience expectation, he repeated his witty Gilbert and Sullivan take-off, first heard a few seasons ago and now part of Proms lore, in place of a traditional speech. Some of the gags and gruesome rhymes were new, but the refrain stayed the same: 'This is the very model of a modern music festival.'

Davis's versatility - his Elgar and Strauss are as convincing as his Mozart and Messiaen - was reflected in the choice of repertoire. The Last Night always ends with an Elgar orchestration (of Parry's Jerusalem ). On this occasion it also began with one, his splashy and luxuriant version of Bach's Fantasia and Fugue in C Minor. Hilary Hahn, a demurely assured 20-year-old American, made her Proms debut with a bright, clean account of Mozart's Violin Concerto in D Major, crisply accompanied by the BBCSO, who, as 'house orchestra', provides the backbone to the entire season, though the praise and attention they deserve usually gets swallowed by glamorous visiting ensembles.

Securing the British soprano Jane Eaglen, now based in Seattle, was a coup. Now one of the finest Brünnhildes around, her appearances in the UK are rare. Before stripping down to her Union Jack for the inevitable 'Rule, Britannia!' (with added Wagnerian ornament), she gave an enthralling account of the Final Scene from Strauss's Salome , drooling over the head of John the Baptist.

Grainger's version of 'Camptown [or rather camped-up] Races', full of highly operatic doo-dahing by Ann Murray, Robert Tear and others, also showed off the soloists of the BBCSO. Another witty diversion was the premiere of Gerard McBurney's reconstruction of Shostakovich's Jazz Suite No 2. McBurney, who also gave this year's evangelical Proms lecture on Shostakovich, came across the rough sketches two years ago. The result is a brief, three-movement suite, saltily scored for a small ensemble including banjos, guitars, multiple saxophones and vamping piano.

Out in Hyde Park, the Proms in the Park had its own competitive attractions, namely Angela Gheorgiu who sang a charming, soft-centred ballad by her husband, Roberto Alagna. Four days later, she was spotted at another People's Event, enthroned in the stalls of the Royal Opera House for Tosca , which was also relayed live on a screen to the piazza. With suspicious serendipity typical of international superstar timing, Alagna was singing Cavaradossi. He jacked up the excitement in a riveting performance by hanging on to high notes justa jot longer than musically necessary, eliciting audience whoops mid-aria. The breath control was amazing but more suited to Annie Get Your Gun than to Puccini. That he occasionally had to climb effortfully to these vocal peaks made the experience more questionable.

Yet his talent has always been to awaken sympathy. Here, his anguish in the face of torture and death was entirely credible. As Tosca, Catherine Malfitano, showed all the compassion, subtlety and expressive powers this role requires, but which few bring. Anthony Michaels-Moore relished Scarpi's cold, smiling lasciviousness. The much revived, Franco Zeffirelli staging, first seen in 1964 with Maria Callas as Tosca, still makes an impact, in an old fashioned sort of way - as long as you don't see it too often. Carlo Rizzi's conducting was well-paced and thoughtful, and the ROH orchestra responded in style.

Standing outside in the piazza, appropriately, for the last act - which itself takes place under the stars - the audience experience was entirely different but no less intense. Directed as if for television, with close-ups and long-shots, the over-emphatic gestures required for opera seemed in this context to have been borrowed from silent film. Thus Alagna with full-screen face set in a grimace, dripping blood and sweat, arms akimbo, caused brief discomfiture. Once he began to sing, any embarrassment quickly vanished. The sound was good, the image slightly grainy and mysterious but adequate, the crowd attentive. When the caviare is as well-served to the general as here, spirits are lifted, opera demystified and converts made.

The week's third democratic offering (lively dictatorial elements notwithstanding) was a daring new Radio 3 programme, Lebrecht Live . This fortnightly unscripted debate presented by Norman Lebrecht lives on its nerve, inviting audiences to participate by phone and email on a topic, this week whether we're being served by those who put on concerts and opera. It had a heady urgency, like a cultural Moral Maze on speed.

The test will be to keep up the pace yet still allow arguments to develop. Studio guests such as John Tusa responded sagely to an exhaustingly swift succession of queries on everything from programme starting times (7pm, please) to whether concerts should really take place in swimming pools and railway stations (seriously) instead of stuffy old concert halls. Such a grim prospect suddenly makes the Barbican look decidedly cosy.
fields.bodyText: Last Night of the Proms Royal Albert Hall, London SW7/ BBC1 and 2, Radio 3 Tosca Royal Opera House/ Covent Garden Piazza, London WC2 Lebrecht Live Radio 3 Cheered on by 40,000 promenaders in Hyde Park, as well as crowds in Birmingham, Liverpool and the Albert Hall itself, Andrew Davis piloted his final Last Night of the Proms after 11 years as chief conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. The relief was that, hooting, tooting and teddy-bear waving aside, this was a musically rewarding finale. In addition, satisfying more than usually heightened audience expectation, he repeated his witty Gilbert and Sullivan take-off, first heard a few seasons ago and now part of Proms lore, in place of a traditional speech. Some of the gags and gruesome rhymes were new, but the refrain stayed the same: 'This is the very model of a modern music festival.' Davis's versatility - his Elgar and Strauss are as convincing as his Mozart and Messiaen - was reflected in the choice of repertoire. fields.headline: Long to rain over us
fields.standfirst: Teenage Fanclub made lovelorn Scottish guitar pop long before Travis. They still do it better
fields.trailText: Teenage Fanclub made lovelorn Scottish guitar pop long before Travis. They still do it better
fields.body:
It's a rainy Wednesday night in Glasgow. In a poky club behind Mr Chippy in Sauchiehall Street, Teenage Fanclub clamber on stage. The group look hesitant. Homecoming gigs can be tumultuous affairs. Their mini-set is being filmed for BBC TV's pop show The Beat Room. A woman barks orders at the crowd. 'Ye have to clap when we introduce them,' she says. She wanders off to the bar with a cameraman in tow. The group shift uneasily.

Teenage Fanclub were once kings of the Scottish music scene. Back in 1991, the group's Bandwagonesque LP ensured their reputation as Glasgow's leading songwriters. Raymond McGinley, Norman Blake and Gerard Love were the musical heirs of the Beach Boys and the Byrds. After the white wine cocktail jazz of Hue & Cry, and Wet Wet Wet's anaemic Northern Soul, Teenage Fanclub's dorm-room pop resurrected the city's music scene. With their lovelorn lyrics and sweet guitar melodies, they were the forerunners for Travis, a band with half their talent but more than twice their sales.

The Grand Prix album of 1995 was a creative zenith, a gloriously sullen record buoyed by the group's distinctive three-part harmonies. The 13 songs - any of which would have made a great hit single - are a recording milestone of their old label, Creation. But Songs From Northern Britain in 1997 plunged the group into ignominy - a collection that hinted at a musical block.

Howdy! , out next month, underlines their reputation as the leading quirky songwriters of their era. Those rainbow voices still underpinned by maudlin lyrics - 'My life feels so worthwhile/ When I go where you send me/ When I can't find a smile/ You've got one to lend me.' Britpop, substituting compassion for stadium excesses, would have been better redrawn in Teenage Fanclub's image.

Live, the new songs are full of forlorn dedications to women tolerant of their moody menfolk, delivered in engagingly unprofessional style. One verse into the group's latest single, the mournful 'I Need Direction', McGinley pauses. 'Sorry about that - it's a complicated wee jazz chord.'

The show is a heartening reminder of their songwriting abilities and Howdy! deserves a nomination for next year's Mercury Music Prize. Afterwards, backstage, McGinley, Blake and Love sit nursing beers. 'Ye cannae tell with these TV shows,' says Love. 'I was trying to concentrate on the songs, but there was this cameraman hovering around that I felt I was going to bump into.'

After the show, Blake walks across Sauchiehall Street to a bar called Nice 'N' Sleazy. In the early Nineties it was, alongside The Cathouse, the sole Glaswegian haunt of metal-kids and goths after a night out at the university Union. While The Cathouse premiered US metal groups like Poison and Ministry, Nice 'N' Sleazy could only afford their British equivalents: the Almighty, Dogs D'Amour, Little Angels.

The club, like most of central Glasgow, has been refurbished to a cosmopolitan homogeneity. 'Yeah, this was a rock club,' says Blake. He looks at the clientele: designer denims and hipster pants, their owners squeezed into Fifties-style booths. 'To be honest, I don't get out that often these days,' he says. 'When there's kids to consider, you just don't get the chance. But yeah, this place has changed.'

Blake and his bandmates move further down the bar, edging closer to their friends. Pints are waved and the group laugh as local well-wishers congratulate them on their performance. Throughout the evening, Blake, McGinley and Love circle friends and sheepishly accept compliments, politely replying 'cheers' and 'ta'.

As I stagger back from the lavatory, I pass Blake, who stands chatting to a friend. 'This is Eugene from Eugenius,' he says, grabbing my arm. Back in 1992, the year grunge broke, Eugenius were hotly tipped by Nirvana. But the group failed to capitalise on their plaudits, and have since resigned themselves to the independent sector. 'You're the best,' says Blake. 'This is the man,' says Eugene, pointing at Blake. They smile, hug, and order vodkas.

Next morning, I sit in Fazzi's, an Italian delicatessen, waiting for the group to arrive. McGinley and Blake amble in a little past 11, both nursing hangovers. Love arrives last. The previous evening, he wandered off to a club night at The 13th Note. Wednesday night holds the club's Death Metal disco. 'It was called Deathlehem,' he giggles. 'I'm no kidding, there were only around 50 kids all in black, throwing themselves against the walls. And the music? All grunts and groans. At one point the DJ played some AC/DC - it sounded like someone had just thrown Abba on.'

Seated around the table, the group look nervously at my Dictaphone. Not that they mind talking. All three have wonderful, comic reminiscences of Glasgow and further afield. But the anecdotes disguise their unease with talking about their own material.

Love points to the window - insistent winds and light rains. 'The Glaswegian climate has a lot to do with who we are,' he says.

'It can be quite depressing. I used to look out my windows a lot and it was always raining. After a while, that starts to affect your outlook on life.'

I mention 'My Uptight Life', an outstanding track on the new album. It fades with a repetitive line strummed over acoustic guitars: 'All my life/ I've felt so uptight/ Now it's all alright.' It hints darkly at a Scottish masculine neurosis drowned in stoicism and alcohol.

'I don't know why I wrote that,' says McGinley. He shifts uncomfortably in his seat, ears flushed.

Directing his conversation at the table before him, he says: 'I guess everything is autobiographical to a certain extent: the words just seem to make sense at the time. You pluck them out of somewhere in your consciousness.'

He looks embarrassed. 'I guess I was trying to get across this idea that I can often feel alienated from everything,' he says, carefully. Both Love and Blake nod, but say nothing. 'It's difficult to explain, but you have these nagging doubts. I'm not talking about music; I mean human doubts. Doubts about the kind of man you have become.'

Love and Blake look on in relief and McGinley pours a glass of water down his throat. They're happier talking about their quirky stories - nights out in Glasgow, 'Mad Tom', who once stabbed a hunchback with an ornamental sword. We laugh for hours.

A little past three, Blake, McGinley and Love walk across the street, waving polite goodbyes. I watch them scurrying towards their cars and think about them in their flats, gazing out at the rain.

 'I Need Direction' is released on 9 October; Howdy! on 23 October

fields.headline: All revved up
fields.standfirst: Carmen transferred to a garage in small-town America? It can only be the work of Matthew Bourne
fields.trailText:
Carmen transferred to a garage in small-town America? It can only be the work of Matthew Bourne
Car Man | JazzXchange
fields.body:
Car Man Old Vic, London SE1

JazzXchange Clore Studio Upstairs (ROH), London WC2

Matthew Bourne's latest vehicle, Car Man , has pulled into the pit at the Old Vic, where it is due to run until Christmas. The show, which has been fine-tuned on the road since May, needs to be a capital success because the Old Vic has agreed a four-year residency in the theatre for Bourne's company, Adventures in Motion Pictures, which has never had a home of its own.

The plan is that AMP will launch its next six dance-theatre productions from Lilian Baylis's old stronghold, once the base for the Vic-Wells Ballet, forerunner of the Royal Ballet. Like Baylis before him, Bourne will reach out to the local community and help train the next generation of performers. If he can continue to attract new audiences, as he did with his male Swan Lake and wartime Cinderella in the West End, he will be doing a service to contemporary dance as well as breathing new life into the Old Vic.

But he could be trapped into a blockbuster format that stifles his quirky genius. At two hours , Car Man is overstretched - a melodrama that crams in references to American thrillers, British B-features and Italian films from the Sixties, as well as musicals, ballet and opera.

The audience goes in humming the score: Bizet's Carmen , in the 40-minute suite by Rodion Shchedrin, amplified by British com poser Terry Davies into a film noir soundtrack.

The action takes place in a clapped-out Midwestern town - Harmony, pop 375. Waitresses and garage-hands replace Carmen' s factory girls and soldiers. The story line is not so much Carmen Jones as The Postman Always Rings Twice : adultery results in murder, betrayal and revenge.

The clues to the plot and the characters' motives are given, silent-movie style, through heightened body language, lurid lighting and music that warns you what is about to happen. Most of the roles are caricatures. The cuckolded husband (Scott Ambler) is a Les Patterson lookalike, his frustrated wife (Saranne Curtin) a flame-haired temptress. The hunk who drifts into town (Alan Vincent) is a grease-monkey who jumps on tables and women.

As it turns out, he swings both ways, seducing the vulnerable victim-hero (Will Kemp). Tortured Angelo and his trusting girlfriend (Etta Murfitt) are the only fully developed characters, thanks to the dancers' acting skills. Bourne's choreography has no nuances - so much move ment is pumped out that the eye needs a rest.

Here's the problem. Bourne has evolved a musical theatre genre without words but every twist and turn is signalled with metaphorical subtitles. And his big dance numbers, the joy of so many musicals, tend to hold up the action instead of providing their own climaxes.

That said, Car Man is far better value than a limp West End musical. Let's hope that the Old Vic proves a safe house for Bourne to try out ideas without too much commercial pressure.

Time, space and support, moral as well as financial, are what every choreographer craves. The Royal Opera House's Back Garden Project aims to provide just such resources for indepen dent dancemakers without bases of their own. Sheron Wray's JazzXchange company is concluding an eight-month residency in the Opera House, benefiting from the Royal Ballet's rehearsal studios and the involvement of its members. The project also inducts cocooned ballet dancers into the mysteries of budgets, admin and marketing.

Wray has been able to work every day with jazz musicians, developing three programmes, including jam sessions. Her dancers have busked for spectators awaiting an opera relay in the piazza and performed an Aids 'ballet' in the Clore Studio Upstairs, with more to come next week. Live , Wray's response to the HIV crisis in Africa, is over-ambitious, but that's the point.

fields.headline: Fuel - what a scorcher
fields.standfirst: Irrespective of your political persuasion or the level in your petrol tank, the fuel crisis made great radio.
fields.trailText: Irrespective of your political persuasion or the level in your petrol tank, the fuel crisis made great radio. Wednesday saw the pickets' stranglehold on refineries from Plymouth to Grangemouth really start to bite and the drama of events as they unfolded minute by minute was seized with obvious relish by presenters. It's at times like this that Radio 5 Live comes into its own.
fields.body:
Irrespective of your political persuasion or the level in your petrol tank, the fuel crisis made great radio. Wednesday saw the pickets' stranglehold on refineries from Plymouth to Grangemouth really start to bite and the drama of events as they unfolded minute by minute was seized with obvious relish by presenters. It's at times like this that Radio 5 Live comes into its own.

One minute, Sarah in Plymouth was talking about the handful of protesters kicking a football by the refinery gates; the next, 10 police vans screeched up and disgorged 20 officers per van complete with body armour and riot shields to disperse the 'mob'.

'Two hundred police against a handful of peaceful protesters?' said Jane Garvey to the assistant chief constable of Devon and Cornwall. Had the raid been instructed by the Government? The ACC, who had clearly been on one of those courses that teaches you how to sidestep impertinent questions, said that he did not fully comprehend the terms she was using.

He and his colleagues had a responsibility to maintain the health, welfare and quality of life of the local people and had responded accordingly. But surely 200 police men was pushing it? persisted our Jane. That is not the issue, the ACC doggedly retorted.

In Cheshire, Jonathan was describing how desperate requests for fuel from local traders - one farmer said all his chickens would die if his fuel-driven automatic feeders weren't switched on - were dismissed by protesters picketing the Stanlow refinery. Forget Stanlow. Jonathan could as easily have been reporting the verdict of a French revolutionary court full of witnesses called Jacques with tumbrels instead of tankers trundling past. Then it was death to the le marquis and vive la république . Now it was death to the chickens and long live peaceful protest.

In the studio, Peter Allen was savaging shadow environment spokesman Archie Norman who was saying that it was time Mr Blair listened to the people. 'Are you suggesting a democratically elected government should give in to mob rule?' said Peter. That is not the issue, said Archie who was obviously on the same course as the assistant chief constable.

Radio 5 Live thrives on crisis. You could feel the excitement as the news flashes came in, as the Minister squirmed and as listeners' e-mails were read out. 'Help,' said one. 'I've got to have petrol for the lawnmower - the grass is so long we can't find the peg basket.' Vive le jardinier , death to petrol tax tyrants.

You could feel the excitement as the news flashes came in, as the Minister squirmed and as listeners' e-mails were read out. 'Help,' said one. fields.headline: Voyeurvision
fields.standfirst: After the daily antics on Big Brother, the turnip planters of Taransay seem decidedly dull
fields.trailText: Castaway 2000 | Big Brother | Jailbreak | Other People's Children | The Olympic Games Opening Ceremony
fields.body:
Castaway 2000 BBC1

Big Brother C4

Jailbreak C5

Other People's Children BBC1

The Olympic Games Opening Ceremony BBC1

You will remember that as recently as last spring, the castaways on Taransay were such a seductive television proposition that due to overwhelming public demand we were treated to a swiftly scheduled week of nightly updates.

This week, we returned to Taransay a more sophisticated and jaded viewing nation. Suddenly, titillation by turnip-planting isn't quite enough (the ground is very acidic, apparently, and therefore good for root vegetables), and even though the islanders have all gone pagan-shaped (a diet of root vegetables will do that to you) - burning a wicker man in the image of the ejected dissident islander, Ray, and dancing around maypoles - there is clearly a great deal of depressingly modern backstabbing, bitching, stamping of feet, door-slamming and the mass chucking of teddies out of metaphorical cots.

Everybody is the same, but more so. The formerly charming Ben Fogle seems to have lost some of his sheen and (unthinkable just a few months ago) developed an unattractive poor-me whine; Ron the psychotherapist is proving to be disruptive rather than merely maverick; the super-smug Dr Roger is now both metasmug and enthusiastically manipulative; while almost everybody else is obsessed with their rations of snouts and Tropicana orange juice, chocolate buttons and whisky.

The whole environment has developed that grubby, misanthropic air of bitter hippydom, just like all those post-Altamont Sixties drop-out communal dreams turned sour. But worse than this, unfamiliarity has managed to breed viewer contempt. This week, we were watching events filmed as long ago as May, and in the Big Brother era that's just not fast enough. In the space of a few short months, Castaway 2000 now looks like time-lapsed, old-fashioned docusoap 'reality TV'. Who would have thought it?

Meanwhile, the final days inside the Big Brother house saw a kind of semi-competitive ennui, and nights revealed that the three remaining housemates were so bored by each other's company (and their own) that it was invariably - yawn - lights out by 10. There were some last-minute, vote-grabbing tactics to be seen in the task of caring for Juanita, the spooky 'baby simulator'.

Father-of-three Darren looked the most convincing, but that may have been because Juanita matched his skin tone. Craig gave a good impression of a man keen to embrace fatherhood and thus win over any wavering female voters ('I really respect all those single mothers out there, looking after those little babies!' Oh give it a rest Craig!), but Anna won on points merely by using the 'breastfeeding' device. Happily, nobody tried to smother little Juanita or leave her overnight in the chicken coop, even though we could have done with some controversy.

Though Craig had a strong lead at the polls all week, I was still rooting for Anna right up until Thursday, at which point she let her fans down rather badly when, given the opportunity to select a favourite song to be played by Big Brother, she revealed an aspect of her personality we really didn't need to know.

Out of all the songs in the world , she inexplicably selected, without a trace of irony (indeed, she got a bit moist of eye), a truly dreadful piece of 1980s electro-pap, 'Electric Dreams' by Phil Oakey and Giorgio Moroder, thus pretty much throwing away the previous nine weeks of carefully-cultivated credibility. Darren's choice, meanwhile, was a transparently vote-grabbing dance track favoured by his kids, while Craig sang along (badly) to Rod Stewart, at which point one suspected it was all over bar the ticker-tape parades in Liverpool.

So as Big Brother settled down, Channel 5's big new reality gameshow, Jailbreak , kicked in. Having lost a heavily-pregnant Ulrika Jonsson as presenter at the last minute, the job fell to Craig Charles, who perhaps lacks the requisite va-va-voom factor. Admittedly, it's early days, but Jailbre ak looks like a confusing mess. The great success of Big Brother has been the fact that, weekly tasks aside, the contestants have had to make their own entertainment, and so we swiftly got to know the individual characters and see how the group dynamic was evolving.

Like BB , Jailbreak also features 10 contestants, this time competing to escape from a purpose-built jail constructed by 'the UK's leading prison architects'. But there is also a confusingly large supporting cast of slightly too sadistically real (though presumably resting) screws and a genuine governor, Jim Heyes, whose CV includes a clutch of Great Train Robbers, a Kray, 'Mad' Frankie Fraser and the Gartree prison riot of the Seventies, plus two roving reporters in the form of Charlie Stayt and Ruth England.

With all this lot competing for screen-time so far, there's been little opportunity to get to know the con testants, despite the pre-filmed inserts: 'Hi! My name is Laura and I'm an office manager and glamour model.' Cue footage of Laura writhing in her smalls but, strangely, none at all of her ordering in the office stationery.

It looks like a very daunting task to escape from the jail. It also looks unlikely to be achieved by one person working on their own. And, though doubtless accounting for a lot of the hits on the website, it appears spectacularly unlikely to be managed by Laura (in tears, for some reason, on day one: 'So, so sweet, but a little bit out of her depth,' explained formidable ex-RAF drill instructor Jenny) or the glamorous granny, Pat, who is rather distracted by having left her Carmen rollers at home. Keep 'em all locked up, I say, and throw away the key. Though if Channel 5 can tighten up the direction and editing, I'll probably be completely hooked by this time next week.

I'd never read a Joanna Trollope before, but I thought I'd do my homework before viewing Other People's Children . Much to my surprise, there were no Agas in the book, but I think I spotted one on the screen (though, of course, it could have been a Raeburn) and Trollope turned out to be far more clogged-kitchen-sink than pristine-designer-range, so the BBC's adaptation was a very watchable, dirty realist bit of domestic business. Exploring the fallout caused by multiple mar riages, dead parents and the unexpected creation of mutant step-families, it provided Lesley Manville with a peach of a part as Nadine, a freshly divorced mother-of-three on the verge of a partially self-inflicted nervous breakdown.

Determined to infect her family with her own bitterness and sense of betrayal after 17 years of marriage, she had relocated the kids to a rundown rural cottage (the home with the recalcitrant range) where they were free to indulge in a rich assortment of rages.

Railing convincingly against the unfairness of a life in such reduced circumstances, while also struggling to be a 'good' mother, the scene in which Manville shouted abuse at her kids (and her absent ex), before attempting to coax a smile out of her emotionally bludgeoned brood with promises of 'Hot choccy? Hot choccy-woccy?', will have sent shivers down the spine of anybody who has ever been on the receiving end of a bit of irrational and misguided motherly 'love'.

Shivers down the spine, too, at The Olympic Games Opening Ceremony . Sorry, I can't help it, but I love an Olympic opening ceremony - and I think I'd rather watch it on television than be there. How else do you get to see a 'ballet with lawnmowers' and then be told that Australia invented the lawnmower? Or find out that Hungary has more doctors per head of population than any other country on Earth and 'some very pretty ladies, too'?

Is there ever going to be another opportunity to watch Rupert Murdoch waving his pair of patriotic green-and-yellow glove puppets (Wendi looked unimpressed), or to get a bit teary when the two Koreas joined forces to carry one flag and the leaderless, smiling East Timorese danced into the stadium under the banner of 'Individual Olympic Athletes'?

Yes, for those four-and-a- half pretty hours, it was almost possible to watch thousands of shiny young athletes without being tempted to play Spot the Human Growth Hormones. Almost possible, but I'm sure I spotted a few.

fields.headline: And the winner's...cursed
fields.trailText: Damon Gough - aka Badly Drawn Boy - looked almost sheepish as he accepted his Mercury Music Prize on Tuesday. 'Good things don't always happen to good people,' he said. Dressed like a weekend busker, he appeared nervous. Just wait till he starts recording the follow-up.
fields.body:
Damon Gough - aka Badly Drawn Boy - looked almost sheepish as he accepted his Mercury Music Prize on Tuesday. 'Good things don't always happen to good people,' he said. Dressed like a weekend busker, he appeared nervous. Just wait till he starts recording the follow-up.

The Mercury Music Prize has a reputation for giving winners the follow-up album blues. In contrast to the Brits, the Mercury represents a validation of artistic worth rather than just an industry-led celebration of record sales. The winner has officially made the best British album of the year, in any genre. It must be hard not to think: where do we go from here?

A scan through previous winners only bolsters the argument that the cultural baggage attached to the prize frustrates all attempts at a successful follow-up.

The inaugural winners, Primal Scream - in 1992 for Screamadelica - re-emerged with Give Out But Don't Give Up , one of the most critically reviled albums of the Nineties. Suede won with their eponymous debut album, which went to No1 with record first-week sales. By the time their next album was released, Dog Man Star in 1994, they were struggling commercially and had lost their guitarist and songwriter, Bernard Butler.

Since then, the litany has continued: M People's career peaked with their winning album Elegant Slumming ; Portishead never matched the impact of their debut, Dummy ; Pulp's career nosedived after the success of Different Class .

Of the recent winners - Roni Size, Gomez, Talvin Singh - none has exactly become a superstar. Can Gough do better? Certainly, he seems unfazed. Laid-back with a sense of humour, he might just be able to pull it off. The Mercury Prize, however, has a nasty knack of exacting its own revenge.

fields.headline: Hare of the dog
fields.standfirst: Alcoholics Anonymous meets Casablanca in David Hare's new play about addiction
fields.trailText: Theatre: My Zinc Bed | An Die Musik | Conversations After a Burial
fields.body:
My Zinc Bed Royal Court, London SW1

An Die Musik Tricycle, London NW6

Conversations After a Burial Almeida, London N1

David Hare has written a searching new play. The first good thing about it is that its stern debates are delivered lightly, floated on the always colourful subject of alcohol. The second is that it plaits together the personal and the political in an unexpected way. The third is that it teases. Buried in the names of its characters - Victor, Elsa - and its theme of a triangular love involving an older man and a Scandinavian woman, is the glow of Casablanca .

My Zinc Bed is about the addictions - to drink, to cults and to each other - with which people comfort themselves when they have lost faith. A young poet and recent convert to Alcoholics Anonymous meets an older man, an ex-communist turned e-millionaire. Recognising in AA the lure of the cult, a lure to which he himself has succumbed, the older man (Tom Wilkinson) tempts the younger (Steven Mackintosh) to drink, and to a liaison with his wife (Julia Ormond).

There are all sorts of things to be argued with in My Zinc Bed , whose title refers to the bed on which we lie when we're dead. The play, which Hare directs himself, doesn't find a language, visual or verbal, which persuades you that it's inhabiting a dot.com world. A framing device in which the young poet addresses the audience directly is awkward, not least because its relation to an Alcoholics Anonymous confessional is never made clear. The dialogue, though often shrewd and humorous, is prone to fits of po-faced explicitness: 'I'm not,' the Ormond character is obliged to insist, 'a stranger to self-hatred.'

This play is less sleekly all-of-a-piece than Hare's most recent work, which makes it more interesting. It signals several liberating departures. It breaks with Hare's habit of depicting women with sentimental enthusiasm: there's nothing sanctified about the Julia Ormond figure here.

It shrugs off what was becoming a restricting naturalism in the design of his plays: Vicki Mortimer's set, though insufficiently claustrophobic and threatening, contains no knives-and-forks domesticity, just a backdrop of zinc-coloured squares which looks first like a Zen-style interior, later like the outlines of a high-rise office block.

The play's riffs about drink are buoyant. And it contains a fascinating performance by Julia Ormond who sets the tone of the play's discussions: damped-down desperation masquerading as chic.

At the Tricycle, actors from the Jewish State Theatre of Bucharest are performing a drama that puts to shame the flashy posturing of many artistic treatments of Nazi atrocities. An Die Musik was created 25 years ago by the director Pip Simmons as a response to what he considered sentimental treatments of the Holocaust. It serves as a les son on how the theatre can convey real-life tragedy.

The play has one flaw: its opening half-hour - a wordless operetta based on the diary of Anne Frank - is histrionic. But what follows is grave and hugely powerful. Concentration-camp inmates are ordered by a Nazi officer to produce an entertainment. The group of men and women - sunken-eyed, hollow-cheeked, with arms hanging down like broom-handles in their striped uniforms - are forced through a series of punishing keep-fit drills. Several are sluiced down with buckets of water; a young woman is ordered to strip, and hangs naked from a trapeze like a carcass on a butcher's hook. But mostly they perform, as if they were taking part in a concert party.

One man delivers a pantomimic version of Shylock, shrugging his shoulders and wringing his hands; one man juggles. A girl dances to music from Tannhäuser , wrapping herself in a band of cloth like a winding sheet; three men shuffle together to demonstrate a Jewish joke. And accompanying themselves raggedly but tunefully on clarinet and recorders, looking frightened, stunned and wild, the company sing the Schubert song that gives the piece its name, a song which speaks of the consoling power of art. The title is a black irony: the play suggests that art - such as this drama itself - has no power to console. It is desolating.

It's a relief to know that Conversations After a Burial is Yasmina Reza's first play, not her latest. It shows how quickly a dramatist can progress to crispness from a maundering start. Reza's Art, the first of her works to be produced in England, is about to move on to its six teenth cast, and its fifth year in the West End. Like the plain white canvas on which the argument between a trio of male friends hinges, the play has turned out to be a space waiting to be given significance by whoever plays in it. It opened with Albert Finney, Tom Courtenay and Ken Stott; it has given work to Jack Dee, Sean Hughes and Stephen Tompkinson. Next month, it will be performed by John Fortune, Ken Campbell and Warren Mitchell.

This earlier play at the Almeida is not subject, as Art has been - I think wrongly - to accusations of philistinism and self-conscious smartness. It is more obviously sensitive - and the worse for that. It teases the audience with its elusiveness, and bursts into a bewildering supernatural sequence towards the end. At the same time, its lan guage is clumpingly emphatic: 'Let me be your pain,' declares one lover as an enticement to making love on a grave. Its dialogue is unconvincingly stylised, too often composed simply of one banal phrase lingeringly repeated.

Rob Howell's beautiful set - creepers sprawling over crumbling stone - is dappled with an autumnal light which proclaims the play's Chekhovian aspirations. But after each significant moment, Dominic Muldowney's music - a compote of alllusions - crashes in as if it were supplying the soundtrack to a Forties melodrama. Reza's characters provide no surprises: there is one uncle (jovial); one unmarried sister (sour); one literary critic (full of self-important bile). Claire Bloom's performance - peculiar, modest and compelling - is the only solace.

fields.standfirst: The little local difficulty at Waterloo has failed to curb Nicholas Grimshaw's enthusiasm for station makeovers
fields.trailText: The little local difficulty at Waterloo has failed to curb Nicholas Grimshaw's enthusiasm for station makeovers
fields.body:
Anybody who has used Paddington Station recently owes a real debt to Nick Grimshaw. He is the architect who has transformed the flyblown squalor of a run-down terminal into a place where you might actually want to spend a little time between trains.

Brunel's splendid vaulted roof has been carefully cleaned. A mezzanine dotted with cafés and bars has been inserted at the front of the station under a new glass roof supported by a series of stainless-steel bowstring rods that are pretty in themselves and don't compete with Brunel's vaults.

On the forecourt, where a cramped, litter-strewn tunnel once dived into the Tube, there are new shops. The sun-filled, marble-floored space is a natural crowd puller, and Grimshaw has made Paddington an authentic entry to a civilised city.

Grimshaw's is not a name you would associate with the careful refurbishment of a listed building from the great age of rail. True, his practice was responsible for the Eurostar terminal at Waterloo, but the point there was to do something new, design its glorious, if not entirely gravity-defying sinuous glass roof, a roof that is currently swathed in canvas to protect passengers from falling panes and which is the subject of ongoing litigation.

Grimshaw is confident his practice will emerge unscathed. 'We did all that any responsible architect could have done to specify the proper glass for that roof.' The experience of being sued by a client trying to apportion blame for technical shortcomings has not diminished his enthusiasm for always trying to get the most out of materials. 'What I do find trying is the suggestion that if you do anything in a new way as an architect you are taking huge risks.'

Grimshaw made his name by being perhaps the most singleminded of all the English high-tech school in the Sixties. While other architects once associated with the style have moved on - Michael Hopkins, for example is happy to build in medieval-looking stone in Dorset, and Norman Foster is getting increasingly interested in experiments with form - Grimshaw has remained comfortable with naked aluminium and the imagery of the jeep, the airship and airstream caravan.

It was his determination to stick with only one end of the architectural spectrum that contributed to his break-up with his first professional partner. Terry Farrell ended up with custody of their office and was driven to import the American-style postmodernism of the MI6 building to distance himself as far from his former partner's singleminded architectural vision as possible.

The enthusiasm for Charles Eames and Buckminster Fuller that first got Grimshaw started in 1965, has continued to provide most of his intellectual nourishment. He certainly looks much the same as he did then. Approaching 60, he is as boyish as ever. He still has all the floppy hair that he wore when he was prowling the streets of Swinging London in flared velvet suits with improbably wide lapels. And he still appears to have the same spectacles, with frames as wide as goggles, in a range of lurid colours.

When you ask him about the high-tech label, he shrugs. 'Everybody should be building with the technology of their own age - the Edwardians were very high-tech. It's the way you look at how materials are put together that matters. To me, that is what makes for real architecture as opposed to scenery. Quinlan Terry once said he didn't care what his buildings were made of so long as they looked Georgian. That just the opposite of what I'm about.'

Grimshaw claims to be interested in substance more than style. 'I like to think our approach is one you'd get from a good boat builder. It's not the same boat every time but you recognise that it's from the same mind and hands.' It's a seductive idea, but boat builders are not necessarily the first people you would call in to design a house. Grimshaw is good at light, delicate sheds.

He has not always been so light on his feet with buildings that require more urbane qualities. The Berlin Stock Exchange looked impressive as a computer model but in the flesh was too heavy-handed for its setting and turns what look like a giant pair of concrete Mickey Mouse shoes to the street. In Camden Town, Grimshaw's supermarket for Sainsbury's squats like a giant piece of machinery amid nineteenth-century terraced streets. And the development's car park presents one almost entirely windowless façade to the street.

So would Grimshaw, with his prejudice toward metal and glass, countenance using low-tech stone, for example, to integrate a design with its context?

'Our project to rebuild Bath Spa actually has quite a lot of stone it. We put stone blocks in glass cubes a bit like a Russian stove. It's a very good material for a spa, it's not just a bit of cladding.'

But if Grimshaw has shown no inclination to take up with modish new architectural strategies, to judge by the range of his work on show in Equilibrium , an exhibition that opened at the Design Museum last week, he is showing no sign of stagnation or of running out of steam. Quite the contrary; he is now building some of the best things he has ever done.

The geodesic structure of the Eden Project in Cornwall, designed with the engineer Tony Hunt, is one millennium dome popular enough to attract a steady stream of paying visitors before a single exhibit has been planted inside one of its biospheres. Grimshaw has drawn up a plan to turn the eggshell-fragile Battersea power station into a glass-roofed entertainment centre before it finally falls down.

And the work at Paddington continues. The station could become almost as important a transport hub as Waterloo. But as presently configured, it simply pours arriving passengers into the surrounding streets. By turning the station around to face towards Paddington basin, touted as London's next Canary Wharf, traffic could be diverted straight to the Westway. But this would require demolishing one of Paddington's four vaulted roofs, and the construction of a 40-storey skyscraper to pay for it all. No great loss says Grimshaw. 'It was built in 1917, and is only a copy of Brunel.'

 Equilibrium runs until 8 October at the Design Museum, London SE1 (020 7940 8790)

fields.headline: A staggering work...
fields.standfirst: Gillian Wearing's subjects may be drunk but they still manage a nod to Brueghel and Holbein
fields.trailText: Gillian Wearing's subjects may be drunk but they still manage a nod to Brueghel and Holbein
fields.body:
Gillian Wearing Serpentine, London W2 to 29 October

In 'Drunk' a new video by Gillian Wearing, some street drinkers are going through the motions. They swig, mumble, stagger and shriek, opening their flies against the nearest wall. Aimless quarrels brew into ham-fisted fights, followed by lavish displays of reconciliation. The drinkers regroup, separate and subside into sleep, before the cycle of intimacy and boredom starts over. It could be exactly what you see on so many streets, except that it isn't - not remotely.

Drunk is shot in black and white on 16mm film and projected on a vast triptych of nearly contiguous screens. The drinkers appear against the stark white backdrop of a photographic studio and they are conspicuously framed and edited. The first capers across the right-hand screen - Wearing has been looking at Brueghel's rustics - before tumbling out of the frame. Another collapses in the centre and eventually stretches the length of all three screens - a nod to Holbein's Christ in the Tomb .

Painting, then, but theatre too - the piece looks like a promenade performance, drinkers lurching in pairs from left to right, forming tableaux, making their entrances and exits. Sometimes the action looks spontaneous, a melodrama generated by drink. Sometimes it seems stage-directed, as when the drinkers pose for the camera and you wonder who bought the booze. Do they know what is going on? How do they come to be here? Are they aware that Wearing is as likely to film them sympathetically as cage them in close-up, comatose and drooling, like animals exposed in a zoo?

Authenticity is crucial to Wearing's art - as crucial as overt artifice. Drunk makes an elaborate semi-fiction out of fact, tells a story about the way a spurned community survives - if it does - by recutting the actuality of this one. It's necessary to suppose that these people are genuine drunks - if they're just acting, then this abject dignity is no more than a mime. Yet you long for some sign that the whole thing is a fiction and not the skilful exploitation of drifters so drunk that they're unaware of the broken glass in which they have stumbled.

Veracity, intrusion, manipulation - all the old anxieties about television documentary are openly courted by Wearing in Trauma . In this video, running on a television screen in an intimate booth, adults have roughly four minutes to disclose a childhood trauma. They speak of regular beatings, sexual abuse, dreadful misery in orphanages and psychiatric wards. Some of them feel guilt, as if they were somehow to blame, others are angry, nonplussed or forgiving.

Wearing works entirely with cameras and knows how their presence distorts. One of the women who answered her ad even speaks of summoning up a suitable trauma for the occasion. All the speakers sound rehearsed and many of them conclude with a moral - as well they might, after contemplating these memories for so many years. But none of this interferes with the power of their testimony: that's achieved by the masks the artist has given them to wear.

Television, which prides itself on screening similar disclosures, tends to protect the subjects with concealing shadows. Wearing has supplied masks of children's faces, varying them accord ing to each speaker. A large woman struggles to speak behind a tight girlish oval with arch little brows; a rosy mask fringed by his own grey beard turns another into a garden gnome. Perhaps they chose from the supply themselves. Either way, the masks are an impediment, a perversely bathetic effect.

Humanity is commonly described as both the subject and the character of Wearing's work. That is certainly true of Prelude , her poignant commemoration of another street drunk currently showing at Tate Britain.

Wearing filmed this handsome woman in slow-mo, giving her strength and dignity the full screen-star treatment and adding only the voice of her twin describing the woman's sudden death. Authenticity and artifice were in perfect balance there. But it's somewhat hit and miss with Wearing's work.

I'm not sure, either, that she wants to seem humane. At the Serpentine, pride of place has been given to Sacha and Mum , a video from 1996 now projected on a giant screen. Everything about this piece is unnervingly weird, from its jerky rhythms and irrational violence - Mum repeatedly dashes Sacha's head to the floor - to its falsely cosy title. Clearly acted, as formal as any Noh play and accompanied by alien cries - spooled in reverse, Twin Peaks style - this is a highly artificial scenario. As a work of fiction, it may have roots in the external world, but it comes entirely from Wearing's mind.

What goes on in other people's minds is the more usual subject of her work. At the Serpentine, you can see the much-plagiarised photographs of people holding signs inscribed with their inner thoughts - 'I'm Desperate', 'Mary come back'. Wearing must have an instinct for these folks - nobody ever says anything moderate or bland. Or perhaps she just discards those shots. Like a child tentatively prodding a wounded animal to see if it's still alive, her curiosity gravitates towards anguish.

At her best, Wearing resolves that swither between the actual and the artful with real ingenuity. In 2 into 1 , she has recorded a mother talking about her 10-year-old twins, and vice-versa, then switched the monologues and had each lip-synch the other's voices. As the words are uttered, the family truths they reveal are unexpectedly corroborated by the body language witnessed on camera. 'Lawrence is gorgeous, I love every inch of him,' declares Lawrence, smirking at his mother's praise and easing back in his chair. Silently, Lawrence's twin grits his teeth alongside.

 Gillian Wearing's exhibition is sponsored by Selfridges & Co in association with The Observer

webTitle: And as the rabbi said to the priest...

fields.headline: And as the rabbi said to the priest...
fields.trailText: Other films: Keeping the Faith | Shaft | The Cell | Human Resources
fields.body:
Keeping the Faith (129 mins, 12) Directed by Edward Norton; starring Edward Norton, Ben Stiller, Jenna Elfman, Anne Bancroft
Shaft (100 mins, 18) Directed by John Singleton; starring Samuel L. Jackson, Vanessa Williams, Christian Bale
The Cell (110 mins, 18) Directed by Tarsem Singh; starring Jennifer Lopez, Vince Vaughn, Marianne Jean-Baptiste
Human Resources (100 mins, no cert) Directed by Laurent Cantet; starring Jalil Lespert, Jean-Claude Vallod, Chantal Barr

More than 78 years have passed since Anne Nichols's play Abie's Irish Rose opened on Broadway to scathing reviews and ran for a record-breaking 2,327 performances. A sentimental, comic version of Romeo and Juliet , it turns on a Methodist minister marrying a Jewish boy to an Irish-American Catholic girl, who then, with the connivance of a priest and a rabbi, pretend to their prejudiced parents that they have married co-religionists.

The latest version of this now familiar formula is Keeping the Faith , a bright comedy with which the charming Edward Norton makes his directorial debut.

Norton himself plays Brian Kilkenny Finn, a Catholic, whose two closest childhood friends are the fellow Catholic Anna Reilly (Jenna Elfman), and Jake Schram (Ben Stiller), a Jew. Brian and Jake have grown up to be the hippest priest and the coolest rabbi on Manhattan's Upper West Side, attracting large middle-class congregations with their smart repartee, New Age theology and swinging services.

Back into their lives comes childhood sweetheart Anna, now a confident, super-successful, power-dressing businesswoman, and an old rivalry springs up again.

It's often very funny, rarely unintelligent, pretty contrived, and at least 30 minutes too long. The stage directions for both senior rabbi Eli Wallach and middle-aged priest Milos Forman probably read, 'Enter gruffly twinkling'.

John Singleton has done little of consequence since his impressive debut Boyz N the Hood in 1991. His reputation will not be greatly enhanced by Shaft , a much-hyped revival of the tough, libidinous private eye impersonated by Richard Roundtree in a series of blaxploitation thrillers in the early Seventies.

Though clumsily plotted, the movie is well enough staged and stars Samuel L. Jackson as the maverick cop John Shaft, who has to keep an eye on bent NYPD colleagues while pursuing a rich, racist murderer (Christian Bale reprising his American Psycho character) and a Hispanic gang boss.

Gordon Parks, the first black photographer to work for Life and director of the original Shaft , has a walk-on role in a Harlem bar and with his snow-white moustache looks in great shape at the age of 88. One of the actors playing a Puerto Rican pistolero glories in the name of Fidel Vicioso.

The feature debut of a prize-winning director of commercials and music videos, Tarsem Singh's The Cell is a flashy SF thriller, a variation on The Silence of the Lambs , in which the FBI have only a few hours to discover the secret whereabouts of a serial killer's latest female victim.

Unfortunately the killer has flipped and is in a coma. But using a technique developed at a Californian neurological centre, psychologist Jennifer Lopez enters his mind and finds some strange things there.

This idea was used to better effect in Dreamscape (1984), in which Dennis Quaid had the ability to enter other people's dreams and came face to face with an assassin inside the head of the US President.

A better, more sober debut than the The Cell , Laurent Cantet's Human Resources is a French movie in the Ken Loach style with a largely non-professional cast. Its young hero, Franck, is an idealistic academic high-flier from a Paris university who before graduating returns to his home town for a brief period as a management trainee at the factory where his dad has spent 30 years on the production line.

Cantet convincingly shows how Franck tries to straddle the industrial fence and reconcile bosses and workers.

But then he's forced to reappraise his own role and his parents' sacrifice when his father is made redundant and there's a strike. A thoughtful picture that ends glibly.

fields.headline: Praying for a power failure
fields.trailText: Not the film of the week: Dancer in the Dark
fields.body:
Dancer in the Dark (139 mins, 15) Directed by Lars von Trier; starring Bj ö rk, Catherine Deneuve, David Morse, Peter Stormare

When the end credits of Dancer in the Dark began to roll at Cannes, I at first thought the applause and cheering for this Scandinavian musical, made in Sweden and Denmark in a form of English, to be ironic. How could anyone have admired or been moved by this tedious, banal, incompetent movie? When its writer-director (several of whose films I've admired) was later awarded the Palme d'Or and Björk named the festival's best actress, I was stunned. When I read that the projector broke down or the power failed during the gala screening at Edinburgh, I thought, yes, there is a God up there or an electrician down here, and he's saying enough is enough.

As with that other Cannes prizewinner L'Humanité , which also left me reeling in disbelief, I gave Lars von Trier's movie another shot to see if the scales would fall from my eyes. No such luck. The experience begins with five minutes sitting in the dark listening to a portentous sub-Wagnerian overture before grainy images introduce Björk as Selma, a Czech immigrant in Washington State in the Fifties. She's brought her 12-year-old son to a small town for the operation that will save his eyesight, and herself works overtime to pay for it, exacerbating the congenital condition that is making her prematurely blind. In finding this laughable, I'm reminded of George C. Scott's line as the trainer in Movie Movie who tells the young boxer who's fighting to pay similar hospital bills: 'Your sister's eyes are below the belt.'

Selma loves musicals and is rehearsing for an amateur production of The Sound of Music . 'I used to dream I was in a musical because in a musical nothing dreadful happens,' she says in an accent more redolent of the Thames estuary than the Danube basin. However, apart from a few bars of 'My Favourite Things' there isn't a song until the picture's been running some 40 minutes. What we have instead are stilted glimpses of Selma with her best friend (Catherine Deneuve), her devoted suitor (Peter Stormare), her policeman-landlord (David Morse) and fellow employees at the factory where she runs a press making kitchen sinks.

The hand-held camera hosepipes around, uncertain whom to observe, and everyone giggles in the embar rassed manner of a home movie. Björk gives a simpering non-performance; an uncomfortable Deneuve constantly reminds us of Demy's Umbrellas of Cherbourg and how a small-scale musical can be drawn from everyday provincial life.

Then comes the first of the movie's seven songs, sung and danced by Björk and her fellow workers in a frenzied, energetic style. The choreography, by an experienced American Vincent Patterson, brings to mind something embarrassingly spontaneous at Baskin Robbins rather than something carefully contrived by Jerome Robbins; the lyrics (by Björk, von Trier and Sjön Sigurdsson) make the words of their fellow nordic bards Abba sound like Cole Porter at his wittiest. All the songs are prompted by repetitive sounds that Selma hears (not a bad touch) and are fantasies she uses to keep the horrors of everyday life at bay.

The worst of those horrors comes when the policeman neighbour steals her savings and provokes her into killing him. 'Why did you kill him?' the vindictive prosecutor asks the blind Selma at the ensuing trial. 'He asked me to,' she replies, repeating a celebrated exchange from Horace McCoy's They Shoot Horses, Don't They? , a tougher, rather more convincing story of a social victim going to the gallows. The trial is not merely the travesty of justice von Trier intends it to be. It evidences as total a disregard for American courtroom procedure as L'Humanité does for the French criminal justice system. But, of course, this isn't supposed to be reality, despite the fact that the movie credits the advice of the Washington State correctional facilities for its staging of the scenes on Death Row. But a certain kind of psychological and emotional conviction would be useful.

In the climax, a singing Björk sweeps in and out of the cells of condemned men (the only other woman in the jail is a wardress) bringing them spiritual succour and leaving a vapour trail of self-pity. Clearly von Trier intends us to appreciate the injustice of an oppressively patriarchal penal system and to experience catharsis.

A lifelong opponent of capital punishment, I left feeling unsympathetic and unmoved.

fields.headline: Hi, honey, I'm Homer
fields.standfirst: The Coens get all postmodern on us with a mock epic in the Deep South
fields.trailText:
Film of the week: The Coens get all postmodern on us with a mock epic in the Deep South
O Brother, Where Art Thou?
fields.body:
O Brother, Where Art Thou? (106 mins, 12) Directed by Joel Coen; starring George Clooney, Holly Hunter, John Turturro, Tim Blake Nelson

Invariably, some literary or cinematic source quirkily lurks beneath the original screenplays of the Coen Brothers, Ethan and Joel. Miller's Crossing , for instance, is a conflation of Dashiel Hammett's The Glass Key and Red Harvest ; the central character of Barton Fink is based on playwright Clifford Odets and the film's plot derives from Deadline at Dawn , a movie Odets scripted in 1946; their previous film, The Big Lebowski , reworks Chandler's The Big Sleep .

Their new movie, O Brother, Where Art Thou? has several sources which are part of the film's meaning. On the surface, it's a picaresque comedy set in the Deep South in 1937 and stars George Clooney, John Tur turro and Tim Blake Nelson as three convicts who escape from a Mississippi chain- gang. Clooney is the charming, loquacious shyster-lawyer Everett, with a Clark Gable moustache and the kind of flat cap and bib-front overalls Henry Fonda wore in The Grapes of Wrath . Turturro is Pete, a surly redneck with a mean streak. Nelson is kind-hearted Delmar, the simple-minded hick. They're a splendid comic trio.

Everett has smart-talked them into joining his quest to find the loot he's allegedly buried beneath a shack that will in four days time be submerged to create a dam. His real purpose, however, is to reach his ex-wife Penny (Holly Hunter) before she re-marries.

Along the way, they meet a black musician and cut a gramophone record at a remote radio station run by a blind manager. This blue-grass song makes them accidental radio stars, and they get involved in the re-election campaign of a corrupt state governor (Charles Durning), who's being challenged by an equally corrupt racist. As photographed by British cinematographer Roger Deakins, the bleached summer landscapes look a treat.

But the film announces at the start that it's based on The Odyssey and is prefaced by the opening lines of Robert Fitzgerald's translation: 'Sing in me, Muse, and through me tell the story of that man skilled in all ways of contending, the wanderer.'

Like Joyce's Ulysses , O Brother is a mock epic with a somewhat shorter time span than Homer's, and the classical allusions are fairly jocular. The Clooney character's full name is Ulysses Everett McGill; his wife Penny is, of course, Penelope, and on their journey the convicts meet a variety of Homeric figures. A blind railroad worker warning of trouble with cows is presumably Tiresias; the lotus eaters are Baptists having their past obliterated by full immersion in a swamp; three sirens lure the travellers and appear to destroy Pete; the Cyclops turns up as a massive, one-eyed preacher (John Goodman), who first robs them and is later confronted at a nocturnal Ku Klux Klan rally, a brilliantly choreographed sequence that moves from funny to frightening to fantastic.

In addition to Homer, the film wittily invokes twentieth-century American legends. Tommy Johnson, the musician the wanderers play with, is based on Robert Johnson, the black blues composer who allegedly sold his soul to the Devil. While being pursued by the police, they're given a lift by a manic-depressive Baby Face Nelson, the gun-happy gangster who succeeded Dillinger as the FBI's Public Enemy Number One, though in fact (not that this is important) Nelson had been dead three years by 1937.

Hovering quietly ready for the film's climax is the epic of the Tennessee Valley Authority, Roosevelt's project to transform the rural South by providing cheap electricity, an event celebrated by grandiose poetic documentaries sponsored by the New Deal.

Most significantly, however, the Coens celebrate the ideas and films of the great Preston Sturges, who after a decade writing screenplays emerged as the writer-direc tor of the political satire The Great McGinty in 1940.

The surname of their protagonist, McGill, is presumably intended to echo that of Sturges's anti-hero, McGinty, who threw in his lot with crooked politicians the way Clooney does. But a more important reference is to Sturges's dazzling meditation on his craft, Sullivan's Travels , in which a successful comedy director demands that he be allowed to make a film that 'teaches a moral lesson, has social insight'.

Sullivan's film is to be called Oh Brother, Where Art Thou? , but his exploratory odyssey through Depression America, which gets him sent to jail and put on a chain gang, convinces him that he's better employed combating human misery by making people laugh.

Moreover, Sullivan concludes: 'I never will have suffered enough to make Oh Brother, Where Art Thou? Besides it's already been done, they made it a couple of thousand years ago and I don't believe in remakes.'

Was Sullivan thinking of Homer when he said that? And are the Coens engaged in the delightfully postmodern activity of remaking a famous movie that never existed?

fields.headline: How do I keep my divorced parents happy?
fields.trailText: Moral muse: A year ago my mother left my father for the man she is now going to marry
fields.body:
A year ago my mother left my father for the man she is now going to marry. When she left, my 17-year-old sister, who is two years older than me, stayed in London with my dad. I spend every other weekend with my mum and we talk a lot on the telephone. The problem is that my sister doesn't want to have anything to do with my mum and thinks I should do the same. She keeps saying I am being disloyal to our dad. Dad himself never talks about mum but he did say in the beginning that I should do whatever I felt was right.

I feel pulled this way and that and sometimes feel tempted to go and live with my mum. She said I could but I know my sister would never speak to me again. Do you have any ideas how to make life easier for me?

S.D of London

I am sorry you are an unhappy and bewildered victim of a family break-up. Your top priority should be to maintain good, affectionate relations with every member of your family. At the same time you should be able to stay wherever you feel most comfortable. When your mother is living with her new husband you may not find her home quite so congenial, but only time will tell, so keep your options open.

When a family is fractured as a result of wayward loving, there is a huge sense of betrayal, resentment and, most destructively, of blame on the part of the innocent members. It is much harder to engage than to condemn. But try to understand your mother.

Humans are programmed with strong passions which ensure pairing off and producing children. Regrettably those passions don't ever get neatly turned off after the wedding ceremony, and are easily misdirected, so that infidelity even among women is amazingly common, though mostly happens in secret. You may catch a glimpse of how overwhelming your mum's new love must be, that she is prepared to put you through all this misery in order to have her way. Arguably she has been more honest than many, who would go on deceiving their families. I am not justifying her actions, merely trying to explain them.

Your attitude is more mature than your sister's and though she may try to push you into an antagonistic position, avoid quarrelling with her. Do not let her force you into acknowledging two camps, them and us. Your father is more traumatised than you, and you should assure him of your loyalty repeatedly, most especially when your mother is married. Affirm that the stepfather will never take his place. In his multiple losses - his life-partner, his integral family, his sense of self-worth - he needs explicit evidence of your love and attachment.

If your sister sees you making this effort with him, she will be less prone to condemn. If you can do so without bitter words, discuss your different attitudes, and though her opinions now polarise into black-and-white, maybe she will soften and adopt a more forgiving stance towards your mum. This should make life easier for you.

Readers' replies

My husband left me for someone else nearly 30 years ago; my son was 17. One of the first things I said to him was: 'Go and see him; he's still your father.'

You and your sister still have two parents and at some time you loved them both. He doesn't stop you going to see your mum. It would help if your dad was able to suggest that both you and your sister had some sort of contact with your mum; it would make it easier, in the long run, for you, your sister, your mum and him.
 J.E. of Leeds

In a similar situation I once said, like your dad, 'You must do whatever you feel is right.' At the same time, I'm afraid I didn't try too hard to conceal the fact that I'd be very hurt if she (in my case, my mother) decided to go to the wedding.

Couples frequently feel guilty or rejected when their marriage breaks up and tend to look to those close to them - often their children - for reassurance. Naturally, many young people find this a difficult burden to bear. Others, like your sister, see themselves as having been rejected by the parent who has left. What your sister is saying to you is, of course, unfair, but she is hurting too, so we can forgive her. I think you should tell your dad you love him, but could he please explain to your sister that if anything is going to hurt him now, it will be the sight of his daughters falling out because of him.
 B.S. of Ely

Next week's dilemma is from A.S. of Oxfordshire

My friend and I both have girls aged 18 months. We always meet on a Monday afternoon for a coffee and to let the children play together. However, I am becoming reluctant to visit her as her child is always unwell with a cold or a cough. Recently her little girl caught thrush of the mouth but she didn't tell me until we were already there and the kids were playing together - sharing toys, putting things in their mouths. She has also visited when her daughter had a stomach bug.

I understand children catch ailments, but I don't want to expose my daughter (or myself) to infections unnecessarily. However, it would seem rude to end the visit on learning her daughter was ill. How do I tell her I don't want the children to mix if they are ill?

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on problems to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for 'Woman's Journal'

webTitle: Observer Review: True confessions: Scenes from real life

fields.headline: That Tommy Steele's got a lot to answer for
fields.trailText: True confessions: I confesss... in seconds, I turned into a hideous stage mother.
fields.body:
I confesss... in seconds, I turned into a hideous stage mother.

I blame Tommy Steele. To get on stage with him at a panto, I elbowed my way to the front at the London Palladium to lisp into a microphone and be rewarded with an Everton mint. It was an uncharacteristic burst of aggression but a harbinger of things to come.

It was mid-afternoon when I got the call from the headmistress at my children's school. A film company had visited and wanted to cast a seven-year-old girl in a forthcoming movie. They'd seen Harriet and were taken with her. A fax from the agent was waiting for me in Mrs D's office. In the nanosecond that it took me to get to the school, get the fax and get back home, I tried to talk myself down. They'd be auditioning lots of children. They probably weren't particularly interested in Harriet. I was barely through the door before I called the agent.

'It would mean 12 weeks filming in the Mediterranean,' said the enthusiastic young woman who answered the phone. 'Do you think she'd mind?'

'It's all a bit academic. I expect you've got lots of kids to see.'

'Well... we are interested in Harriet.'

It was at that moment that my stagemumometer went from nought to 60. They wanted her. My Harriet. I was going to be abroad for 12 blissful weeks. I was going to be lounging about with film stars - rather, chaperoning Harriet. It was going to be the start of a huge career for her - no, an educational experience; remember that bloke in the Partridge Family , remember Macaulay Culkin. We were going to be rich or, rather, it was all going into a trust fund.

I had to talk to Harriet. 'If you do get the part, it's not very likely, but if you do, it would mean going abroad and being off school for three months. You don't mind, do you, darling?'

'Hmm... well, I dunno. I spose not.'

So that was sorted then.

Audition day dawned and we set off on our journey into cinematic history. Only Harriet didn't want to go.

'I've changed my mind. I want to stay with Auntie K.' Oh Christ. 'Come on, Harriet. Don't be silly. They'll all be waiting for you. It's going to be fun.'

'No, I don't want to go.' Harriet burst into tears and continued to wail as I attempted to cajole her and the minutes slipped by. Now, I can't say I'm proud of what follows, but this is a confession, right, so here goes.

'Harriet, if you don't go, I am taking you home and you can stay in your room for the rest of the day. Now come with me and you'll get some sweets.'

Harriet did cheer up but I felt miserable. She was hopeless at the audition and I suppose the bit of me that hadn't morphed into a hideous stage mother was quite glad she was hopeless. A seven-year-old spending three months away from her friends and school in a foreign country? I even said sorry and bought her some sweets.

I haven't given up yet, though. I've got another one at home - Emma. Her grandmother thinks she's got real potential . Anyone know a good agent?

If you have a true confession, email< A HREF="mailto:kim.bunce@observer.co.uk">kim.bunce@observer.co.uk
