fields.headline: It's a split decision
fields.standfirst: Jerry Hall thinks divorce is good for you; a new glossy mag agrees. But breaking up is never easy
fields.trailText: Jerry Hall thinks divorce is good for you; a new glossy mag agrees. But breaking up is never easy
fields.body:
There's a joke Woody Allen used to tell in his nightclub act. He and his wife were talking about what they should do: go on a holiday or get a divorce. In the end, he says, they decide on the divorce. After all, a holiday is a one-off, but a divorce is something you always have.

And there's another old joke, about a couple who eventually separate when they are both in their nineties. What made you do it now, asks the judge in court; after all those years, couldn't you have stuck it out together? 'We wanted to wait until the children died,' they say. And there's a brand new divorce joke now: Jerry Hall says that more parents should put their children first - by leaving each other, just like she and Mick Jagger have done. In an interview last week on ITV's This Morning , she claimed that her children were more content since the pair separated because her new happiness was rubbing off on them. 'I think more people should try it,' she advised - as if she were recommending jogging, or fruit for breakfast.

Once divorce was virtually non-existent and marriage often a lifelong prison sentence - especially for women. Even when it was allowed, it was a terrible stigma, and the cost of escape brutally high. Careers were wrecked by it; lives catastrophically overturned. Divorcees were socially excluded - again, especially the women. They became outsiders. It certainly wasn't usually good for the children. I talked to one woman recently whose parents were divorced in the Fifties. She was, she believed then, the only child she knew to come from a broken family, and she never told anyone at all until she left home and went to university where she finally broke down and 'confessed' her shameful past to her boyfriend. It was literally unspeakable: a crime and a sin and a dark secret. Marriage had to be very bleak indeed, to choose a way out that was so grim.

You don't have to want to return to the bad old days, where misery raged behind locked doors, to find Jerry Hall's comments jarring. As a spokesperson for Relate wryly said: 'Not every family is the same. If Miss Hall's children are fine, then that is great. But I wouldn't say that applies in every case.' No indeed. For a start, Miss Hall is rich in her own right, and has received a £7 million payout and their house in Richmond, Surrey. The four children have had trust funds set up for them.

Most ordinary couples face acute hardship when they divorce - the women in particular, whose finances usually nosedive. And for a woman who has been married to the philandering Mick Jagger to talk about the problem with arguing in front of the children is rather like a woman fleeing a burning house and saying she left because she didn't like the décor.

During their long and turbulent relationship, Jagger repeatedly and publicly humiliated her with his infidelities. When tests proved he had fathered a child with a Brazilian model Hall tried to divorce him, but Jagger successfully argued that they weren't legally married anyway.

The marriage between Hall and Jagger was a celebrity marriage. When they parted, it was a celebrity separation. We should recognise that celebrities just aren't like us. They might say they are, and be photographed in homey poses, wearing old clothes, talking about takeaways in front of videos and how fame really doesn't mean anything to them. They might want to be 'ordinary', and long for the good old days before the blinding spotlight of stardom, when they knew who they were. And of course, celebrities endure the same unhinging feelings as the rest of us: rage and shame and envy and jealousy and lust and wretchedness and regret and tenderness and love. But they live in a different landscape from the one that most of us inhabit. They have piles of money. They have constant attention. They are flattered and fawned on and seduced (Jerry Hall said that she had to give Jagger 'some specific compensation' because he had been continually propositioned by women desperate to have sex with him, poor man).

Recent statistics show that the divorce rates have dropped slightly in the last decade, from 152,633 in 1988 to 145,214 in 1998, but that's only because fewer people are getting married; and those who are, marry later. Divorce is still an epidemic in the Western world. In London, for instance, almost half of marriages end in divorce, and more than 50 per cent of children now live outside of the nuclear family that used to be regarded as normal. But that's nothing compared with the divorce rate among stars. When you read the tabloid papers or pick up the glossy magazines, you could be forgiven for thinking that everyone is thin, beautiful, and getting separated. Take the last few weeks: we read about Meg Ryan and Dennis Quaid splitting, Patsy Kensit and Liam Gallagher, Meg Matthews and Noel Gallagher, Hugh Grant and Liz Hurley, Mel B and Jimmy Gulzar (whose vicious bickering about her breast implant and his low sex drive has been spread all over the front pages of the tabloids). In Hollywood, it is extremely uncommon, almost bizarre, for a marriage to endure.

And you could be getting the impression that, because a Spice Girl does it, or a model, or an actress, or a footballer; because Liz and Hugh have split, because Patsy Kensit has done it for the third time and oops, there goes Demi Moore and Bruce Willis, then it's OK. It might be heartbreaking (that's good these days, to be emotionally ravaged all over the front of the Sun ), but it's not a failure; it is not something to feel regretful about. No, no, it's a stage and a rite of passage and something that will make you stronger. And not just you - it will be good for the children, as Jerry Hall blithely says. Nobody need suffer. Nobody should feel badly. Things happen. Relationships end. Life hurts. Time heals. Violins play. Another marriage might be round the corner.

Next month, a new magazine will be launched called New Era . The title seems accurately to reflect what its contents will be. There will be a celebrity divorcee on every cover; lots of information about how to go about sundering the marriage; hints on how to date again. Above all the message will be 'upbeat' and about moving on to the new era the magazine heralds. 'Divorce is a time for change,' says Lesley Neil, its editor, brightly. 'We intend to approach it in a positive way.'

Presumably, it won't be long before couples not only sell their wedding pictures in the way that Anthea Turner and Grant Bovey did to OK! , but also snaps of their split. Ex-couples will be photographed dividing up the silver and bickering over ownership of the CDs. Far from being a stigma in the way that it cruelly used to be, divorce is socially acceptable. Fashionable, even - the endless subject of books and columns in which the divorcee is tragic, stylish, sorrowful, the heroine-victim of a gripping narrative which most of us can enter.

In many of these stories of parting, the protagonists are seen as asserting their individuality, being true to themselves, finding themselves after years of self-denial and unspoken misery. What divorce is not allowed to be about is failure. Failure has become unspeakable, the new F-word in our culture.

But for most people who go through it, divorce is certainly about failure: the failure of a marriage, and of an idea of the future. Many marriages are like Strindberg's plays or Sartre's hell, where what was once love and desire and affection turns to hate, repulsion, sadism.

People scorch each other. Children get caught in the crossfire, the innocent and primary victims. Divorce is almost always ugly, hurtful, scarring, and most people, when they separate, do not do so lightly; far from it.

But the new vocabulary of separation that we find in the media, and on the lips of the celebrity-divorcees ('More people should try it') is often light, glib, fake-tragic, feel-good stuff.

The columnist Chrissy Iley recently wrote that only unimaginative people were faithful. I'd put it the other way round. It doesn't seem to take much imagination to follow your wayward lusts. To stay faithful is by a long way the harder and more imaginative task.

It is also about stoicism, like that line in Rudyard Kipling's great and unjustly mocked poem, 'If': 'If you can force your heart and nerve and sinew/ To serve your turn long after they are gone,/ And so hold on when there is nothing in you/ Except the Will which says to them: "Hold on!".'

It doesn't sound much fun, does it? Sticking it out; holding on to the old love. But it's probably better for the children. And maybe for us.

fields.headline: It's in the balance...
fields.standfirst: Corin and Vanessa Redgrave are part of Britain's greatest theatrical dynasty.  David Benedict talks to them backstage as they act out their sibling rivalry in Chekhov's finest play
fields.trailText: Corin and Vanessa Redgrave are part of Britain's greatest theatrical dynasty.  David Benedict talks to them backstage as they act out their sibling rivalry in Chekhov's finest play
fields.body:
People who have never seen a Chekhov play think they know what they're about to receive. As children's TV comics Trevor and Simon used to intone, 'Mr Gloom is in the room'. Even the Gershwin brothers - sons of St Petersburg émigrés, so they should know - managed to put the boot in: 'With love to lead the way/ I've found more clouds of grey/ Than any Russian play could guarantee.'

It's all Stanislavsky's fault. He took one look at The Cherry Orchard and proceeded to direct it as a tragedy. Chekhov was appalled. While writing it he had written to Stanislavsky's wife making it clear that it was 'a comedy, not a drama - even a farce in spots'. Ever since the infamous ensuing row, directors have ricocheted between presenting his masterpiece as a comically absurd dissection of a dying generation unable to face the shock of the new, or the moving tragedy of a bankrupt fin-de-siècle family.

Truth to tell, it's both - and that's the key to its greatness. First staged in 1904, it is simultaneously a naturalistic portrait of a family and its fortunes, and aprescient drama about social change. The play's unusually rich range of viable interpretations is one reason why it attracts the likes of Trevor Nunn and the Redgraves. That said, none of them has exactly specialised in Chekhov.

'For a long time I didn't appreciate him,' admits Vanessa Redgrave in a break from rehearsals for Nunn's production at the National Theatre where he is currently artistic director. 'I couldn't understand why, but I just found it too gentle, too elegiac, too nostalgic. I preferred Ibsen because it was harder and more savage. But when I played Arkadina in The Seagull in 1985 I discovered a capacity I hadn't found in a playwright before, of taking you inside the anatomy of human beings with all their different states of mind, above all into the "opposites" which go on inside people.'

Such psychological acuity is hardly surprising considering that Chekhov had a day job as a doctor. Yet the strength of the writing - and the reason why actors so love his work - is that he never simply diagnoses or judges his characters. Lesser writers build personalities with characteristics designed to illustrate a position or viewpoint. Chekhov's characters may often symbolise ideas but they also vibrate with contradiction. They are opaque, which makes watching Chekhov an extraordinary act of complicity as we're forced to make our own decisions about his characters, rather than just passively soaking up a rigged argument with pre-ordained goodies and baddies.

Vanessa recalls doing Three Sisters with her sister Lynn and Corin's daughter Jemma. 'The director Robert Sturua told us if we didn't make everybody in the audience think of their own lives and what they were doing with them - and maybe feeling quite uncomfortable about that - then we would have failed.' Corin chips in immediately with his recollection of seeing the production in Guildford. 'I came out behind two ladies who'd obviously enjoyed it and one said to the other, "It's so like life", and the other retorted, "I hope not!"'

Brother and sister bat ideas and anecdotes back and forth with more than polite ease, which augurs well as Nunn has indeed cast them as brother and sister. Isn't that dangerously close to being a gimmick? In Chekhov, the truism about there being no small parts is, for once, true. The Cherry Orchard has a cast of 12 named characters, every one of whom could conceive of themselves as the lead at certain moments, and who will have spent at least part of seven rehearsal weeks learning to project family connection.

Nunn demurs at the suggestion of sentimental casting. He first worked with Vanessa on Heartbreak House eight years ago and, perhaps encouraged by Shaw's subtitle, 'A Fantasia in the Russian Manner on English Themes', suggested they do The Cherry Orchard together. Only now have circumstances and commitments allowed their diaries to coincide. Casting her alongside another member of the clan may have grabbed headlines but Corin and Nunn have been friends since being students together. Most recently, Nunn cast him very effectively in Not About Nightingales , a forgotten Tennessee Williams social drama about a prison riot which Vanessa unearthed and Nunn staged at the National and in New York.

Nevertheless, Nunn is alive to potential charges of nepotism which also arise whenever he casts his wife, Imogen Stubbs. 'There's a general sense that it smells wrong,' he observes, a shade ruefully. 'Imogen feels it more than I do, I think. There are two occasions where she's turned down roles with me here for that reason.' Ultimately, however, Nunn regards the sibling element of the Redgrave casting as a bonus. 'It has never come up in rehearsal. We never did improvisations about their real childhood together.'

'Casting directors assume too much similarity in families,' observes Corin, warily. Certainly, these two are interdependent but temperamentally miles apart. Rehearsals for Noël Coward's Song at Twilight in which they played ex-lovers were tempestuous to say the least, one screaming match in particular emptying the room. Even in gentle conversation, their differences are evident. Corin, the 61-year-old younger brother, is naturally circumspect and thoughtful. He leans back, tilting his head to one side, carefully considering his responses. Two years older, Vanessa is more spontaneous and volatile, pouncing on ideas with almost alarming zest. When her energy flags, you can actually see the light go out from behind her eyes.

Those characteristics define their acting. Over the last few years, Corin has emerged from behind his sisters' shadows by harnessing his growing physical gravitas to that very quality of careful consideration. The results, in roles as diverse as Roger Casement or Sir Walter in the film of Persuasion , have been seriously powerful. Vanessa's power, on the other hand, springs from her immediacy, which, on film, the camera absolutely laps up. On stage, at her best, there's seemingly no distance between her, the writer's ideas and the audience. She somehow fuses all three elements and transmits pure, inescapable energy.

SO IT'S ALL the more exciting that Nunn is staging the play in the intimate, 300-seat Cottesloe with no distancing proscenium arch and the audience seated on three sides. It's a ploy he used in his spellbinding RSC production of Three Sisters in the late Seventies. The company toured a three-sided platform for community centres and halls without raked seating. That, in turn, dictated the style. Furniture would have blocked audience sightlines so a famously naturalistic play was staged almost without props, a style which Nunn believes chimed perfectly with the Russian view of Chekhov as primarily a poet.

He's revisiting that but with a difference because in The Cherry Orchard physical presence - and absence - are crucially important. Two of the play's most vital characters are never seen - Ranyevskaya's lover in Paris, and her son who drowned - while, conversely, the house and the orchard have enormous significance.

That crucial symbolic strain runs in tandem with Chekhov's argument for naturalism. 'In real life,' he wrote, 'people don't spend every minute shooting each other, hanging themselves, making confessions of love. They don't spend all the time saying clever things, they're occupied with eating, drinking, flirting, and talking nonsense. These are the things which ought to be shown on the stage. A play should be written in which people arrive, go away, have dinner, talk about the weather, play cards. Life must be exactly as it is and people as they are.'

If The Cherry Orchard were a film it would be classified as an 'inaction movie', but if the activity is mundane, the inconsequential dialogue masks a subtext of conflicting hopes and passions. Furthermore, the big ideas that Chekhov and his characters are handling are as urgent now as ever. 'Chekhov had this constant humanist belief,' says Nunn. 'The characters talk about life "one hundred years from now". And here we are. And we too are on the brink of bigger changes than at any time in the last one hundred years. As the student Trofimov says, "The road's been dug up, you can't go back".'

The Redgraves recently publicly countered attacks on Nunn's stewardship of the National. Nunn isn't there to hear it but, as opening night looms, they reaffirm their confidence. Corin cites Arthur Miller as a defence witness. 'When he was being produced here but not in America, he said: "By all means criticise the National, criticise the RSC and the Royal Court, but please remember that subsidised theatre is the most important thing you have. Should you ever lose it, you'll realise what you had and it will all be too late".'

To reverse the tide of criticism, Nunn has to encourage more first-rate work throughout the repertoire. Directing a play of this calibre with as strong a cast as this will help, but the strain is beginning to tell. As I leave, he says, 'The one thing we didn't talk about was just what a treat this is. Working on Chekhov is about the best fun you can have in the theatre.' He frowns. 'The trouble is, people have such high expectations_ that's the one thing I don't enjoy.'

 The Cherry Orchard opens at the Cottesloe, London SE1 (020 7452 3000) on Thursday

The results, in roles as diverse as Roger Casement or Sir Walter in the film of Persuasion , have been seriously powerful. Vanessa's power, on the other hand, springs from her immediacy, which, on film, the camera absolutely laps up. On stage, at her best, there's seemingly no distance between her, the writer's ideas and the audience. She somehow fuses all three elements and transmits pure, inescapable energy. SO IT'S ALL the more exciting that Nunn is staging the play in the intimate, 300-seat Cottesloe with no distancing proscenium arch and the audience seated on three sides. It's a ploy he used in his spellbinding RSC production of Three Sisters in the late Seventies. The company toured a three-sided platform for community centres and halls without raked seating. That, in turn, dictated the style. Furniture would have blocked audience sightlines so a famously naturalistic play was staged almost without props, a style which Nunn believes chimed perfectly with the Russian view of Chekhov as primarily a poet. He's revisiting that but with a difference because in The Cherry Orchard physical presence - and absence - are crucially important. Two of the play's most vital characters are never seen - Ranyevskaya's lover in Paris, and her son who drowned - while, conversely, the house and the orchard have enormous significance. That crucial symbolic strain runs in tandem with Chekhov's argument for naturalism. 'In real life,' he wrote, 'people don't spend every minute shooting each other, hanging themselves, making confessions of love. They don't spend all the time saying clever things, they're occupied with eating, drinking, flirting, and talking nonsense. These are the things which ought to be shown on the stage. A play should be written in which people arrive, go away, have dinner, talk about the weather, play cards. Life must be exactly as it is and people as they are.' If The Cherry Orchard were a film it would be classified as an 'inaction movie', but if the activity is mundane, the inconsequential dialogue masks a subtext of conflicting hopes and passions. Furthermore, the big ideas that Chekhov and his characters are handling are as urgent now as ever. 'Chekhov had this constant humanist belief,' says Nunn. 'The characters talk about life "one hundred years from now". And here we are. And we too are on the brink of bigger changes than at any time in the last one hundred years. As the student Trofimov says, "The road's been dug up, you can't go back".' The Redgraves recently publicly countered attacks on Nunn's stewardship of the National. Nunn isn't there to hear it but, as opening night looms, they reaffirm their confidence. Corin cites Arthur Miller as a defence witness. 'When he was being produced here but not in America, he said: "By all means criticise the National, criticise the RSC and the Royal Court, but please remember that subsidised theatre is the most important thing you have. Should you ever lose it, you'll realise what you had and it will all be too late".' To reverse the tide of criticism, Nunn has to encourage more first-rate work throughout the repertoire. Directing a play of this calibre with as strong a cast as this will help, but the strain is beginning to tell. As I leave, he says, 'The one thing we didn't talk about was just what a treat this is. Working on Chekhov is about the best fun you can have in the theatre.' He frowns. 'The trouble is, people have such high expectations_ that's the one thing I don't enjoy.'  The Cherry Orchard opens at the Cottesloe, London SE1 (020 7452 3000) on Thursday

webTitle: Help - Can I complain about an endowment policy that I think I was mis-sold years ago?

fields.headline: Help - Can I complain about an endowment policy that I think I was mis-sold years ago?
fields.trailText: You certainly can complain, although whether your complaint is accepted depends on why you think the policy was mis-sold. Many homeowners are having second thoughts about their endowment policies because insurance companies are contacting them to warn that the policy is unlikely to produce enough money to pay off the mortgage. They suggest that homeowners increase their monthly premiums to meet the shortfall.
fields.body:
You certainly can complain, although whether your complaint is accepted depends on why you think the policy was mis-sold. Many homeowners are having second thoughts about their endowment policies because insurance companies are contacting them to warn that the policy is unlikely to produce enough money to pay off the mortgage. They suggest that homeowners increase their monthly premiums to meet the shortfall.

You can complain that an endowment was mis-sold on the following grounds: you already had sufficient insurance; you were sold a second policy when you could have increased payments to the first; or you had no dependants to benefit from the insurance on your death.

The first step is to contact the company that sold you the policy and state clearly you are making a complaint because you think you were mis-sold an endowment. If the company does not address your complaint to your satisfaction you can then go to the ombudsman. Next month the chief financial ombudsman is giving insurance firms guidelines on dealing with endowment mis-selling complaints, explaining how he might deal with those that reach his office.

It does not matter how long ago you bought the policy. What matters is when you realised you might have a problem. You have six years from purchase in which to complain. But you can complain about endowment mis-selling within three years of the time you could reasonably have been expected to discover that something was wrong.You can still complain now, even if you tried complaining some time ago. Your complaint was not taken to deadlock if the company's reply was unsatisfactory, and particularly if the letter ended: 'Should you wish to discuss this matter any furthe ...'. Start afresh with a new complaint.

Once you have reached deadlock with the firm, or eight weeks have passed without a reply, you have six months in which to contact the ombudsman (020 7216 0016).

fields.headline: Talking cheap on poverty
fields.standfirst: If this protest has taught us anything, it's that helping the poor costs and it's a cost we must pay
fields.trailText: If this protest has taught us anything, it's that helping the poor costs and it's a cost we must pay
fields.body:
The poor are the new rich. Or so you might assume from some reactions to last week's report by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, which disclosed that a quarter of all Britons are living in poverty. 'Being poor means you can't afford a dinner party,' scoffed one report, conjuring up the vision of a dearth of Krug and roasted quail as the determinant of deprivation. In fact, being able to invite friends or family round, even for baked beans on toast, was low on the survey's list of basic necessities, which included beds, a damp-free home, a warm coat and a dictionary.

The final item, the Daily Telegraph implied, might be of benefit to the Rowntree Foundation, accused in the paper's leader column of 'an assault on what words mean'. How dare researchers be 'shocked' at the finding that 17 per cent of British adults believe they are living in 'absolute poverty' as defined by the United Nations? What an insult to the poorest children in the world that citizens of the tenth richest country on the planet should muscle in on their status.

Leaving aside the fact that the Telegraph rarely directs its ire towards, say, the fate of Iraqi children condemned to hardship and death by Western sanctions, it is hard to accuse the Rowntree researchers of undue hyperbole. Under their methodology, two million children - or one in six - lack the necessities of life. This is relatively conservative, compared with Unicef's total of 4.5 million or the latest Office of National Statistics estimate of three million, based on a poverty line of less than 60 per cent of median income. But however you stack up the figures, the picture remains similar.

On the Rowntree assessment, poverty - as defined both by low income and multiple deprivation - increased by more than a tenth between 1983 and last year. The poor, emphatically, are not the new rich. On the contrary, the rich are the new poor. One of the more surreal aspects of the petrol blockade was the right-wing assertion that the campaign for cheaper fuel was undertaken on behalf of the 'poorest in society'; always a useful totem in times of crisis. Since the poorest do not drive, the only likely winners were the better off - those Middle Englanders who submitted to the ordeal of taking to the roads on brand-new mountain bikes in search of the last chilled coronation chicken in Waitrose, hopeful that their impoverishment would at last be recognised.

And so it might be. Never mind that the moderately well-off, beneficiaries of a 1p cut in income tax and among the lightest overall taxation in Europe, have a shaky claim on deprivation. They are self-styled victors in round one of the battle for lower petrol duty, and the Prime Minister, for all his professions of obduracy, will have to listen. And where does that leave the destitute? Already there is speculation that the pre-Budget report in November, expected to focus on poor pensioners, may instead be skewed towards balm for irate drivers. Blair is in a bind. To some extent, it is one of his own devising.

In June 1997, he issued his pledge to the dispossessed. His stage set was the concrete walkways and stinking stairwells of the Aylesbury estate in Southwark, south London, and his message was unequivocal. 'For 18 years, the poorest people in our country have been forgotten by government. There will be no forgotten people in the Britain I want to build.' Of course, even the most stone-hearted of administrations bear in mind Aristotle's tenet that 'poverty is the parent of revolution and crime' and must be, where possible, minimised. In an age when Germinal -style insurrection seems the monopoly of the well-heeled wishing to skim a penny or two off the price of a litre of super-unleaded, the poor retain the sanction of inflating crime statistics, clogging up the NHS and depressing school league tables.

Though the charge of cynicism may be unfair, the Government has certainly been guilty of a plethora of fatuous tactics. If only the poor would lock up their delinquent children after dark, eat their broccoli, keep their squeegees off the windscreens of impoverished motorists, eschew divorce and follow the David Blunkett DIY guide to assisting with homework, they and we would all be better off. Such nanny statism tends to ignore evidence that discrepancies in health and education are not merely the result of lifestyle choices or even poor income. Inequality itself is the killer. Fat-cat bosses, beneficiaries of a 72 per cent pay rise since 1994, are less prone to stress than their worst-paid workers. A labourer on 40 cigarettes a day runs a greater health risk than a chief executive. The less-privileged worker is, as a correspondent once wrote to Harry Truman, 'an eight-ulcer man on four-ulcer pay'.

Blair is aware of all that. Hence his raft of worthwhile policies for the poor; a sincere attempt to redress the balance. The trouble is that reducing inequality has always been a subversive crusade in which New Labour, despite evidence of voter support for welfare spending, has shirked saying that higher taxation is the price of a fairer society with benefits to all. Instead it has preferred a patchwork of indirect taxes and backdoor redistribution designed to spare Middle England any suspicion that it is being clobbered. But now Mondeo man is at the barricades; partly because he has been propelled there by the right-wing press but also because Blair has allowed the myth of the something-for-nothing society to flourish. Meanwhile, convenient sources of cash for social projects - tax treatment of pension funds, the windfall levy on the privatised utilities - diminish. The Government is running out of road.

In a paper published last week, John Hills, a professor of social policy at the London School of Economics, says that 'inequality clearly rose at the start of Labour's time in office'. Its record after the first 18 months bears two interpretations, according to Hills. The first is that its programme, though cheaper than an 'Old Labour' policy of uprating benefits with incomes, has delivered as much to low-income groups while also improving work incentives. The alternative view is that 'tax and benefit reforms have only barely delivered enough to the lowest income groups to prevent inequality rising. By themselves the measures may stem the rising tide of inequality but not reverse it'. Either way, Hills argues that more money will have to be ploughed in to prevent back-sliding on any progress so far.

While not a wholesale indictment, such an assessment - coupled with the Rowntree Foundation's bleak audit of very recent figures - does not suggest that the DSS's own survey on poverty, out in a few days, will be entitled 'Mission Accomplished'. Nor does a chronicle of, at best, creeping progress and, at worst, mounting inequality echo Blair's ringing putsch on poverty, delivered on the Aylesbury estate.

Since then, the very rich have thrived alarmingly. A combination of lavishly-trumpeted initiatives and grand, if distant, targets, such as eliminating child poverty by 2020, has fostered the idea that the worst-off are faring a lot better than they are. This comfortable misconception has lulled the affluent of Middle England into the barely-challenged notion that they are the ones deserving of a break: this time on petrol prices and, if that ploy works, perhaps a whole lot more besides.

Of course it is easy, and correct, to rail against piratical oil companies and arrogant Ministers. But Blair's problem is not bullishness but timidity. It is time now to acknowledge that if we want better public services and a substantial erosion of poverty, we shall have to pay for them upfront. If that lesson is learned, then the petrol protesters, unalluring as they are, will have done us all a big favour.

fields.headline: Irani sees Essex up
fields.trailText: Warwickshire 400-8dec & 8-0dec lost to Essex 208-5dec & 202-4 by six wickets
fields.body:
In a last desperate throw of the dice, Warwickshire, who had had the better of this match until rain intervened to wash out all of Friday's play and lop off another 27 overs yesterday, made a declaration that could only be described as suicidal. They set Essex a mere 201 from 56 overs, and the home team got there with six wickets to spare, securing promotion to the first division.

At the start of the last day of the Championship, Essex and Warwickshire were two of five Division Two counties scrapping for two remaining promotion places. Of the two, Essex were better placed. In fact, had there been a countrywide wash-out yesterday, they would have gone up regardless.

As it transpired, however, the sun shone in Bristol, where Nottingamshire and Gloucestershire not only started play on time, but sought to contrive a finish because both sides needed to win. In the circumstances, Essex and Warwickshire, kept waiting by the weather until 20 minutes after lunch, were left with no alternative but to go for a decisive outcome.

So Essex declared 192 runs in arrears and then Warwickshire, after being forcefed eight runs from three balls, put them in again. As if the target was not generous enough, Alan Richardson bowled two wayward overs in which he conceded 16 runs in extras of every variety and at the end of three overs, Essex's requirement was reduced by 27 runs.

Warwickshire were carrying the handicap of being able to use only four bowlers as their possible fifth, Mark Wagh, was ruled out after the umpires, John Hampshire and Barry Dudleston, had warned the captain, Neil Smith, during the first innings, that they had doubts about the legality of Wagh's action.

Fortunately for Warwickshire, the pitch had been freshened somewhat from having sweated under the covers and enabled them to fight back. They looked likely winners after 14 overs when Essex were reduced to 64 for four.

The swing of fortunes began in the seventh over when Paul Prichard, trying to pull Douggie Brown, put up a steepling catch to mid-on. Then Charles Dagnall, who had waited until the last fortnight of the season to get a first-team outing, struck twice in consecutive overs.

First, David Hemp, throwing himself forward at second slip, took a brilliant one-handed catch to get rid of Dar ren Robinson, whose magnificent 92 was one of the pillars of Essex's first innings. Robinson challenged Hemp's claim for a clean catch and the umpires, after consultation, sought the verdict of the TV umpire.

Then Paul Grayson, driving on the rise, edged a catch to Keith Piper. Worse was to follow when Stuart Law departed two overs later. Smith summoned the courage to bring back Richardson, and his third ball, a slower one pitched at yorker length, had Law leg before.

Ronnie Irani, Essex's captain, is nothing if not a fighter. He has pulled Essex out of tighter corners and, partnered now by Stephen Peters, put the innings back on the rails.

fields.headline: Russell chases in vain
fields.trailText: This is the time of year when the MotorMop, the calculator and the TV zapper that operates Ceefax work overtime. Yesterday there was a desperate scramble for points among the six sides who could still gain promotion from the second division along with the champions Northamptonshire.
fields.body:
This is the time of year when the MotorMop, the calculator and the TV zapper that operates Ceefax work overtime. Yesterday there was a desperate scramble for points among the six sides who could still gain promotion from the second division along with the champions Northamptonshire.

At Cardiff, where my day began, Glamorgan adopted the low-key, low-risk route. They recognised that if they secured three bowling points, which would take them to 160 for the season, that would be sufficient.

Once it was established that Justin Langer, the Middlesex captain, whose sole purpose was to prevent the indignity of his county finishing bottom for the first time, was not going to declare, thereby denying his opponents precious points, the focus moved to Bristol and Chelmsford. For amid scenes of much jubilation, Glamorgan bowled Middlesex out despite a fine final innings from Langer - I doubt he will play for them again.

But at Bristol, more creativity was required. Gloucestershire declared overnight despite a deficit of 143; Nottinghamshire smashed 104 for three - against proper bowlers, including Jon Lewis, who took his seventy-second wicket of the season - leaving the home side 248 to win from a minimum of 59 overs.

They must have spotted the development at Chelmsford, where Essex and Warwickshire sensed the pursuit of bonus points would not be enough. Holding most of the cards, Essex seemed to have obtained a good deal.

All this meant that if there was a winner at Chelmsford, that team would be promoted. Meanwhile, Glenn McGrath was trying to concoct an unlikely victory for Worcestershire. Confused? Why not?

The advent of divisional cricket has been the death knell for the old-fashioned run-chase, regarded as an unnecessary risk now that points are available for draws. But that obviously does not apply to the last game of the season. Moreover they are now all optimists at Bristol.

Coach John Bracewell and captain Mark Alleyne have instilled remarkable self-belief to a bunch of players that do not appear very threatening on the scorecard. They even managed to win the NatWest trophy, a straight knock-out competition, despite losing their first game to Worcestershire. So the prospect of Gloucestershire snatching a first-division slot could not be discounted.

For Nottinghamshire it would also be something of a coup since they have won only two of their 15 Championship games. But both teams were dependent on a draw at Chelmsford.

Gloucestershire set off in pursuit of their target with typical vigour. Kim Barnett's perambulations at the crease often ended with him cracking the ball square of the wicket over a sluggish outfield. Nottinghamshire's Paul Franks looked innocuous and was soon replaced by Mark Bowen, playing his last game before taking up a job at Sellafield - so much for the attractions of the county circuit.

Bowen checked the chase. First he bowled Dominic Hewson; then one of Barnett's off-side swishes ended in the gloves of Chris Read. Ian Harvey announced himself with a crisply struck six off David Lucas but had to drag himself from the crease when he was judged to be caught down the leg side. I got the impression he disagreed with the decision.

At 90 for three, there was some rebuilding to do. Matt Windows looked secure until brilliantly caught at mid-on by Bowen while Jack Russell essayed a variety of cover drives. Several raced to the cover boundary, just as many scuttled to fine leg or third man.

The cricket was tense and invigorating and a fine finish was in the offing - there should be more of these in county cricket. But with Essex winning at Chelmsford it was a good game of cricket in isolation. Gloucestershire have to make do with three one-day trophies.

fields.headline: Saluting a brave new world
fields.standfirst: Two divisions and central contracts have changed the game - but is English cricket better off? Yes, believes Vic Marks
fields.trailText: Two divisions and central contracts have changed the game - but is English cricket better off? Yes, believes Vic Marks.
fields.body:
The sports news bulletins have been peppered with the latest on the promotion and relegation issues - and they've been talking about cricket. I'm still not sure to what extent the average punter is bothered whether his side go up or down, but I can report that those intimately involved - the players and coaches - have thought of little else over the past couple of months. The standard may not be any higher but there has been an intensity to county cricket in September that was unknown until 1999 when sides first started scrapping for their status.

This is obviously a good thing. The experiment should continue and any tinkering should be kept to a minimum if only to allow the punters to come to terms with the divisional system. Indeed, the ECB want to give it three years to bed down before considering the next overhaul.

Likewise the introduction of central contracts has been a success; in the short term this has had a much greater impact on the national side. It is a pity the best players in the country have not been involved in the climax to the season, which is why the ECB must be strong in discussions about the future timing of the ICC Trophy. But even without central contracts our international players were going to be increasingly divorced from their counties once an international programme of seven Tests and a one-day triangular tournament in the English summer was agreed. If central contracts mean Gough, Caddick and Atherton last the season, they are worthwhile.

So the new format deserves a cautious welcome. But there are some drawbacks. The scramble for late season points may hamper the development of some of our youngsters. Traditionally the last few matches of the season have provided an opportunity for clubs to blood young players since nothing much was at stake. Now the chances are that they will stick with the gnarled old pro, who, in the short term, might eke out a few more vital runs.

Likewise county captains have become less enterprising. The cricket may be harder but the legitimate run chase is now scorned and that, along with a lot of rain, has made for some dull games. There was nothing wrong with an uncontrived target of 300 from 75 overs on the last day, which gave both sides a chance of vic tory. Few teams are now prepared to gamble.

One solution might be to increase the incentive for victory (12 points now as opposed to four for a draw). Some sides have survived in the first division (like Somerset) or come close to promotion from the second (like Warwickshire and Nottinghamshire) by not losing - or winning - very often. In the ideal world the differential between a win and a draw would be greater, but there is one important factor to consider - the pitches. They are still not good enough and the points system has been structured to encourage better ones. I'm not sure the counties have been sufficiently re-educated to change the system just yet.

The introduction of pitch liaison officers is contentious; they may have helped a little; they have certainly caused much bitterness among the counties (especially those who have suffered penalties such as Derbyshire and Yorkshire) since it is so hard to achieve consistency in their judgments. And they are expensive.

County groundsmen employed by the ECB have been suggested, which sounds good but would be beset by countless practical problems. Increasingly I'm taken by the simple idea of giving the toss to the visiting captain. This would be easier to implement now that the counties play each other twice a season and would go a long way towards stemming the doctoring of pitches. It's worth trying.

Whatever the state of the pitches, Surrey are worthy champions. They won most games because they have the best balanced, most potent of bowling attacks. Alex Tudor and Ian Salisbury perform to a standard that eludes them in international cricket. The old order has been restored for they were pushed hardest by the sleeping giants of Lancashire and Yorkshire. In one-day cricket, Gloucestershire, making a virtue of their lack of star quality, reign supreme.

Off the field, will first or second division status affect membership numbers? Will coaches and captains increasingly be sacked with soccer-style severity (Gatting swapping dole queue notes with Vialli)? Will the cheque book prevail? For this is the time of year when there is constant gossip about players moving counties for a fresh start or a bigger pay packet. They have more freedom to move now. Will they crave to play in the first division? In the short term I think the answers to these questions are No, Yes, Yes , No, which sounds like Inzamam ul Haq and his partner running between the wickets, the next cricketing delight that awaits us.

Will they crave to play in the first division? In the short term I think the answers to these questions are No, Yes, Yes , No, which sounds like Inzamam ul Haq and his partner running between the wickets, the next cricketing delight that awaits us.

webTitle: Throwing woe for Flower as Zimbabwe fall

fields.headline: Throwing woe for Flower as Zimbabwe fall
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe captain Heath Streak is backing the left-arm spinner to be bowling in the Second Test that begins in Harare on Tuesday.
fields.body:
Zimbabwe captain Heath Streak, who was stunned when Grant Flower was called for throwing in the first Test against New Zealand, is backing the left-arm spinner to be bowling in the Second Test that begins in Harare on Tuesday.

Standing at square leg in the eighth over of New Zealand's second innings, Australian umpire Darrell Hair ruled Flower threw the second, fourth and sixth deliveries of his second over.

In accordance with Test match playing conditions, Flower, who also opens the batting, was suspended from bowling for the rest of the innings.

'Obviously it was a loss to us,' Streak said at a news conference after the match which New Zealand won by seven wickets. 'Grant has done a job for us and picked up wickets, and it's something we'll have to work on.

'People have looked at his action and if there is something wrong we will have to make an adjustment. Hopefully, we'll have the issue resolved by the start of the second Test and he will be able to bowl for us again.

'He's also one of our top one-day bowlers, so it would be a big blow to us not to have him bowl.'

Asked if he was shocked when Flower was called for throwing, Streak said: 'I was, to be honest, because he's bowled more than 200 overs in Test cricket and he's not been called before.'

Streak believes Flower is mentally strong enough to overcome the setback.

'Grant's a tough guy,' Streak said. 'Obviously he'll be disappointed, but he's good at coming back. He's a dedicated professional and if there is a problem, he'll be in the nets grafting away to sort it out.'

Flower is the second Zimbabwe bowler to be called for throwing, paceman Henry Olonga having been called against Pakistan during the first Test in Harare in 1995.

Olonga was at that time the first recognised bowler to be called in a Test since Ian Meckiff for Australia against South Africa in Brisbane in the 1963-64 series.

Streak said: 'Henry had the same problem in his first Test and he came back to be one of the top bowlers in Zimbabwe, so I'm sure Grant will come back. I'll bet he will be back doing the job for us in the second Test.'

Umpire Hair called Sri Lanka off-spinner Muttiah Muralithran for throwing against Australia during the Melbourne Test of the 1995-96 series.

Meanwhile, Zimbabwe vice-captain Guy Whittall, who withdrew from the first Test in protest over a selection controversy, has confirmed his availability for the second Test.

'The Zimbabwe Cricket Union has spoken to everyone concerned and they've sorted it out,' Whittall said.

New Zealand lead the two-match series 1-0.

webTitle: On the road and out of step

fields.headline: On the road and out of step
fields.trailText: Norman Harris on the fuel crisis, the question of lighting, law changes and curious memorabilia.
fields.body:
Have the tanks run dry for our pros on the road? With the season ending with today's games, perhaps it doesn't matter too much if they don't all make it back home. But the past few days have raised questions about county cricketers' love of the car.

Warwickshire's men all travelled to Chelmsford by car. Likewise most of Middlesex to Cardiff, only three of them taking the train that provides a perfect connection. Many Yorkshire players, having just gone to Canterbury, motored south again to Southampton. Somerset, who do the most driving, set off by car on 5 August for a northern mission to Lancashire and Derbyshire.

In the past, some worries have been expressed about the strain of driving and the likelihood, on the law of averages, of serious accidents. Some counties have used coaches for an extended period on the road. But it seems that the car is again king.

Yorkshire say that a coach trip would mean some players having to drive considerable distances just to meet at Headingley. Somerset's thinking is even more hard-headed. 'What's the point of supplying players with cars and then paying for a coach?' says chief executive Peter Anderson. He does add, though, that the coaches - the human ones - want all the players together, while the players want to be free.

Some of these arguments may be sound. Yet, somehow, cricket again manages to look out of step with other professional sports.

 A wet summer, and Warwickshire's failure to get planning consent for permanent lights (they've decided they have no grounds for an appeal) has struck a cautionary note with other counties. It has also been noted that the games played under auxiliary lights at Edgbaston, following a spectacular introduction there three years ago, have attracted increasingly moderate crowds, indicating a big novelty factor.

On the other hand, a day-night match can still be a big success for a county trying lights for the first time - like Northamptonshire. 'It was very, very successful,' says chief executive Steve Coverdale. 'A crowd of 5,000, and the extra corporate and sponsorship revenue, more than justifies the cost of the lights. We will probably look to do just one a year, and put a lot of marketing into it. It has to remain a novelty. And it has to be played when the nights are dry and dark - between mid-July and late August - so that it really is floodlit cricket.'

 So great are the latest changes in the laws - which come into effect here next summer - that the Association of Umpires and Scorers have called all their senior instructors to a meeting at Keele University on 7 and 8 October. They'll then spread the word in regional seminars. Despite previous law revisions - the last major one was in 1980 - none of these is thought to have prompted such a reaction. The most radical changes, of course, concern the 'Fair Play' law, especially the possibility of awarding five penalty runs. 'The thinking,' says a leading official, 'is that this will be a deterrent that won't be used much.'

 The meorabilia website set up earlier this summer by Charles Colville, sportsmemo.com has at last had a success with the sale of a Martin Speight painting - of the Arundel ground - for £3,500. Still awaiting a buyer, however, are the two John Emburey blazers and a tie from the rebel tours to South Africa in 1982 and 1990.

fields.headline: Ramprakash: victim of change
fields.trailText: Fred Trueman does not believe the game is in better health, and sees Mark Ramprakash as one victim of recent changes.
fields.body:
You won't fool the children of the revolution, someone once said. Well if cricket's 'revolution' of two county divisions and central contracts is anything to go by, we've been suckered.

I'm not saying that there are no virtues at all in the way the game has moved in the last year, just that, on balance, there are more negatives than positives.

First and foremost, I think it is undoubtedly unfair on the counties contesting the new first and second divisions to be stripped of their finest players for much of the season. It is true, of course, that the ECB are now picking up much - if not all - of the tab for these top-flight England players, but that is scant consolation if it means the difference between winning a title or cup or even succumbing to relegation.

Certainly one or two counties might suggest that if all their players had been available, the final reckoning for their season might have been very different.

There is merit to the argument that two divisions curry more interest for much longer in the season. But the downside is that we may be about to see players in transfer scrambles and a dash to more successful teams, which is such a feature of professional football.

Let me cite the example of Mark Ramprakash of Middlesex and England, a very talented batsman for whom I had such very high hopes a few years back. Ram prakash's stock is low at the moment; he had a miserable time with England in the summer and Middlesex have just sacked coach Mike Gatting, having finished at the foot of the second division.

No one doubts, regardless of his dreadful form, that lurking inside the battered shell of Ramprakash is talent. What can he do now to revive his career? Under the current system he may well feel that he 'needs a new challenge' as footballers say, to move to a new county - preferably in the first division. That would sadden me but it would not surprise me. After all, why play against second division players for a county low on confidence when he could move and play first division cricket?

This rush for points and favourable league placings, pushing for titles and avoiding relegation has already seen agitation - from so-called supporters. Yorkshire's Darren Gough, centrally contracted of course, has received poison letters suggesting he should never bowl for the county again because of his lack of involvement in Yorkshire's vain push for the title. Some Yorkshire fans have taken to calling him Darren Gough OBE - no honours you understand, simply Only Bowls for England. And there is no doubt that Gough and Craig White were badly missed by my old county.

The argument that England would have claimed their players for much of the summer anyway - regardless of central contracts - is fair enough. Seven Tests and a three-way one-day international competition adds up to too much Test cricket in my view. Time was when Tests were special, their relative rarity was part of the mystique of top-class cricket. Not any longer.

So the calendar needs inspection, as do our rotten pitches. If we want our players, especially batsmen, to develop, the wickets have to improve dramatically. I'd say 85 per cent of our county strips have deteriorated badly.

Our pitches should not be in this condition. I remember Sir Don Bradman saying to me: 'The best wickets to bat on anywhere in the world are good strips in England where you get a little more time to play your best shots.'

Not any more. Our best players won't develop into great players until those pitches improve and remember, spectators want to see batsmen hit big scores. Batsmen are the craftsmen and bowlers are the labourers in this great game of ours - and that's something coming from me.

webTitle: Next generation face stern island test

fields.headline: Next generation face stern island test
fields.standfirst: Vic Marks on a real challenge for England A
fields.trailText: Vic Marks on a real challenge for England A as the selectors prepare to announce the touring party that will be competing in the Caribbean's Busta Cup in the new year.
fields.body:
Tomorrow the selectors will announce the England A touring party that will be competing in the Caribbean's Busta Cup in the new year. Their deliberations may well take longer than when they were picking the senior sides. That process was a breeze: just one or two contentious decisions and probably no more than 20 names on the list. For the A side it's possible to pluck out many more especially since the selectors are in this case permitted the odd quirky choice dependent more on a hunch than a weight of runs or wickets.

The expedition to the Caribbean should be an interesting one. One of the criticisms of recent A tours has been that too often the opposition have either been a) uninterested or b) sub-standard or occasionally both. Hence it has been difficult to gauge the worth of the performances of our youngsters overseas. The A team have not lost a first class match for six years. At least the cricket should be competitive this winter as they take on all the Caribbean countries in a series of six four-day matches. To top that league would be a major achievement.

First the policy must be decided. If the A team were to represent England's second XI then the likes of Peter Bowler, Mark Ramprakash, Martin Bicknell and Ali Brown should all be included. There doesn't seem much point in that, however. The selectors must surely pick players whom they think can play for England within the next five years, not those who might have done in the last five. The one exception might be the captain.

Last year the admirable Mark Alleyne did a fine job, but he has his duties with England's one-day squad and is therefore unavailable. A flick through the current county captains opens up two possibilities. Adam Hollioake captained the A side five years ago in Australia. He's unlikely to play for England again (though he must be above brother Ben in the pecking order at the moment), but in Championship cricket he has over seen the best, if not the most popular, side on the county circuit for the last two years and that must count for something.

The other candidate is Lancashire's John Crawley, who has a much better chance of playing for England again and who has done a sound job since taking over the captaincy of Lancashire. In both cases the selectors had better check that these two are keen on the job. Crawley, in particular, has not always been the most enthusiastic of tourists.

The conditions in the West Indies should influence the balance of the tour party. Even though the Caribbean has been the cradle of pace in recent times, the spinners tend to do a lot of bowling in domestic cricket so it would not be absurd to take three on tour. The other caveat about cricket in the Caribbean has been the decline in the standard of their pitches (the Kensington Oval in Barbados being the exception) but I don't suppose they can be much worse than some of ours; nowadays at Worcester, once a haven for stroke-makers, you are fortunate to see cricket on the third day.

The greatest head scratching will occur when choosing the opening batsmen. With the elevation of Marcus Trescothick there do not seem to be many good young ones around. The greatest confusion will be when the name of MJ Powell is announced. There are three playing county cricket; two of them, both named Michael, are strong candidates for the A tour. Glamor gan's Powell has obvious ability, though has not had been as productive this season as he was in 1999. Warwickshire's Powell has been in the runs and usually opens the batting. Northamptonshire's Powell (Mark), though promising, will board the plane only if there has been an administrative cock-up.

The Powells would be newcomers to representative cricket; so might Mike Smethurst and Gary Keedy, who have both impressed for Lancashire this summer. Curiously there is no one from the Yorkshire pace battery in this squad since Ryan Sidebottom is so frequently injured and Chris Silverwood is fading. Chris Read is the likeliest keeper, though the progress of Essex's Jamie Foster is worth monitoring.

Possible A squad

John Crawley (Lancs, captain)

Ian Ward (Surrey)

Mike Powell (Warwickshire)

David Sales (Northamptonshire)

Vikram Solanki (Worcestershire)

Aftab Habib (Leicestershire)

Mike Powell (Glamorgan)

Chris Read (Nottinghamshire)

Paul Franks (Nottinghamshire)

Chris Schofield (Lancashire)

Alex Tudor (Surrey)

Steve Harmison (Durham)

Gary Keedy (Lancashire)

Mike Smethurst (Lancashire)

Jason Brown (N'hamptonshire)

fields.headline: Counties' team of the season
fields.standfirst: Selected by Norman Harris, and based on championship and one-day performances
fields.trailText: Selected by Norman Harris, and based on championship and one-day performances.
fields.body:
MICHAEL VAUGHAN
(Yorkshire)

Perhaps the only opener in England, apart from Atherton, to consistently look the part. Made 155 in his first championship match but also broke his finger. On returning he was straight back into his steady stride.

PETER BOWLER
(Somerset)

With five centuries and 1300-plus runs he surpassed all other English batsmen. At 27 he's an old pro with a technique that clearly works for him, and great concentration.

DARREN LEHMANN
(Yorkshire, captain)

Formidably reliable, he was top run-maker with an aggregate of 1477. However, he wasn't a man for huge innings when the going was easy: again and again it was a gritty, resourceful half-century that buoyed Yorkshire when they most needed him.

MARK RAMPRAKASH
(Middlesex).

He may have averaged just five in the Tests, but no English batsman matched his strokes in domestic cricket. In the championship only Bevan and Lehmann bettered his 64 average.

MICHAEL BEVAN
(Sussex)

Incredibly, his batting went to an even higher level. An average of 74.9 was the highest in the championship, and in the National League it was very nearly twice anyone else's at 130.8. At one point he scored four consecutive championship innings of over 150.

IAN HARVEY
(Gloucestershire)

The best all-rounder of the season, bowling with mesmeric variation and economy and with the bat able to break the stranglehold of opposition bowlers. At his most influential in the one-day format.

PAUL NIXON
(Kent)

Always a fighter with the bat, his undefeated 134 against Warne and Mullally was one of the high points of a season that ends with an England tour at the age of 30. Both in runs and catches he just keeps out the indefatigable Jack Russell.

IAN SALISBURY
(Surrey)

He was the leg-spinner who was sure to bowl at least one 'four-ball' every over, and to shed that reputation was a triumph of character. The reward was over 50 wickets at 18.5, the best average by any English spinner, and a winter tour.

SAQLAIN MUSHTAQ
(Surrey)

Not for 14 years has anyone taken as many as seven wickets for so few as 11runs - Saqlain's return when he bowled out Derbyshire. His mystery ball remains undetectable. Jason Brown of Northants challenges him for wickets, but not for an average of 15.

MARTIN BICKNELLl
(Surrey)

Bicknell's steady wicket-taking had been unobtrusive until the spotlight swung on him at Guildford: 9-47were the best figures of the season, and 16-19 the best match figures for 44 years. Narrowly gets the nod over Alan Mullally.

GLENN MCGRATH
(Worcestershire)

Everything Worcestershire hoped for. With nearly 80 wickets at 14 he led the way in the championship and, being too dangerous to try and hit, his 30 wickets on Sundays have come at a mere 7.7 runs each.

At his most influential in the one-day format. PAUL NIXON (Kent) Always a fighter with the bat, his undefeated 134 against Warne and Mullally was one of the high points of a season that ends with an England tour at the age of 30. Both in runs and catches he just keeps out the indefatigable Jack Russell. IAN SALISBURY (Surrey) He was the leg-spinner who was sure to bowl at least one 'four-ball' every over, and to shed that reputation was a triumph of character. The reward was over 50 wickets at 18.5, the best average by any English spinner, and a winter tour. SAQLAIN MUSHTAQ (Surrey) Not for 14 years has anyone taken as many as seven wickets for so few as 11runs - Saqlain's return when he bowled out Derbyshire. His mystery ball remains undetectable. Jason Brown of Northants challenges him for wickets, but not for an average of 15. MARTIN BICKNELLl (Surrey) Bicknell's steady wicket-taking had been unobtrusive until the spotlight swung on him at Guildford: 9-47were the best figures of the season, and 16-19 the best match figures for 44 years. Narrowly gets the nod over Alan Mullally. GLENN MCGRATH (Worcestershire) Everything Worcestershire hoped for. With nearly 80 wickets at 14 he led the way in the championship and, being too dangerous to try and hit, his 30 wickets on Sundays have come at a mere 7.7 runs each.

fields.headline: Charmless Chelsea
fields.standfirst: They're pretentious, envious, impatient and they have an image problem from top to bottom
fields.trailText: They're pretentious, envious, impatient and they have an image problem from top to bottom
fields.body:
The things they don't teach you at Football Management School - No 1: Working for Ken Bates.

These days, the most sophisticated of European coaching courses encompass such new-age subjects as physiology and nutrition but appear to contain little tuition about handling whimsical, over-demanding owners, presidents or chairmen. There is a glaring gap in the market and you can almost picture the ad in the educational supplements now:

The University of Fairlop (UNFAIR) is pleased to offer a five-year degree in the art and science of political manoeuvring and machinations within a football club, with a view to keeping one's job. Students will be expected to have thick skins but may experience thinning hair.

Who knows, perhaps the Chelsea chairman could offer his services as visiting tutor emeritus?

It was the week when English football finally went crazy - make that the week when its craziness was confirmed - with the sacking of a manager for being successful. All over this country now, managers are ashen-faced at the prospect of winning the FA Cup. After all, such a piffling pot no longer seems good enough for a club who until three years ago went 27 years without a major trophy.

Gianluca Vialli - the overseer of five trophies in two-and-a-half years in fact - got Chelsea's boot because they wanted a 'change of direction', according to their managing director, Colin Hutchinson. He and Mr Bates (who shows that you do keep a dog and bark yourself) could get their wish. After all, new coach Claudio Ranieri walked out on Atletico Madrid after leading them towards relegation.

I once put it to Mr Hutchinson that his club aspired to be the Manchester United of the South. He bridled at the suggestion. It is clear, though, that is exactly what they want to be. Simply, Chelsea see United heading into the distance to championships and European Cups and they want it - and they want it now. The impatience has blinded them to several significant factors, though.

First, that United stuck with Sir Alex Ferguson for four years before he won a trophy, and then it was the FA Cup. Under him, United also had a near-miss before their first title for 26 years. In addition, Sir Alex put his imprint on the club by being allowed to ship out troublemakers.

It is said that at Chelsea, Vialli had lost the confidence of some players. A manager always loses the confidence of those he leaves out and it was inevitable with so many talents assembled at the Stamford Bridge Import House buy-and-bring sale. It must make being the director of Chelsea's youth academy one of the least rewarding jobs in the world, but is no reason for a sacking.

Imagine, for example, word coming out of Old Trafford that Sir Alex had 'lost' some of his players. Didier Deschamps described Vialli as not the man he had liked so much as a player, but do we believe that all Sir Alex's players like him? One suspects that when he has gone the players he made so successful will talk of respect rather than affection.

Pretentious, nous? Chelsea most certainly are. 'We are a continental club playing football in England,' said Mr Hutchinson this week. The thought occurred after their narrow victory over St Gallen in the Uefa Cup last Thursday that if they are not careful, in 11 days time they could be an English club not playing football on the continent.

Take their attendances. Just over 18,000 against the Swiss. Petrol problems? Almost 63,000 descended from Cornwall and Essex on Old Trafford the night before and would have done so had St Albans been the opposition. One recalls before the 1994 FA Cup final, Mr Bates complaining about Chelsea's ticket allocation a few days before they attracted fewer than 9,000 for a home game against Coventry City.

Deflating the grandiosity of the club is irresistible sometimes, as is poking fun at the most recent quotes. 'The players don't know whether they are coming or going,' said the co-caretaker coach Ray Wilkins. Well, some of them can take it from this admittedly removed source that they will definitely be going.

The fact is that Chelsea, despite the dignity of such as Vialli and Wilkins and some kindly employees in the press room, are a charmless club with an image problem. And that comes from the top, as a week that has stretched their credibility has shown.

The location of Chelsea's press box behind visiting fans who naturally want to stand up and thus obscure the view - technically in breach of the law although nothing is done - matters not to the public. But Chelsea should not then complain that the press get things wrong.

Or do they? Consider last season. Chelsea denied that an incident occurred in the tunnel after the Wimbledon match, which was presumably why the FA charged both clubs. And, no, it was untrue that Deschamps would leave at the end of the season, unhappy as he was.

As we do in the press, though, Vialli undoubtedly got some things wrong. The rotation system has fermented discontent, comparing unfavourably with Sir Alex's policy of not tinkering with key positions and fielding his strongest team for the biggest games.

It was probably Vialli's withdrawal of Gianfranco Zola against Arsenal 10 days ago, when he and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink were looking a promising pairing, then Zola's omission at Newcastle three days later, that hastened the manager's departure. Vialli's unwillingness to contemplate an extension to his contract may also have indicated a lack of commitment. Perhaps, too, there was a feeling that he may not be too unhappy at going, a victim of injustice, while his reputation was high.

Hasselbaink's signing remedied Chelsea's main flaw last season, a lack of pace in attack. Vialli, however, will not get to see what might yet flower. Instead, he will get the time out of the game he confided he wanted to his friend David Platt this summer. Do not rule out Vialli now taking his Italian coaching badge and resurfacing as Juventus coach, or part-owner of Sampdoria, and bringing an also then fully qualified Platt with him.

Some of us felt that it showed the inadequacies of the English game that an unqualified Vialli could be appointed in the first place. What a shabby episode has shown, though, is that after his trophy-winning aptitude, you wonder quite whether anything - even five years at UNFAIR - would qualify any European elder statesman, even those hardened in the political ways of Italy and Spain, to work at the Bates motel.

fields.headline: By fair means or foul?
fields.standfirst: A spate of on-the-field sharp practice has raised questions about just what is cheating
fields.trailText: A spate of on-the-field sharp practice has raised questions about just what is cheating.
fields.body:
The routine is familiar enough. Player goes down injured and doesn't get up, first person to appreciate the seriousness of the situation boots the ball into touch, possession is eventually returned via a tame throw-in once the injured man has received treatment.

The crowd usually applaud at this point, in appreciation of the sportsmanship involved. If you think about it, the reason they express approval is because spectators know there is nothing in the rules that demands a player return the ball to his opponents. There is a school of thought that says possession need not be handed back if the ball was kicked out by a player anxious to secure treatment for a team-mate, and another that insists the only sporting course of action is to return the ball in every case regardless of whose player went down, but the only rule is that there are no rules - apart from the one that says the throw-in goes to the opponents of the team who touched the ball last. The fact that the team taking the throw are free to do whatever they like with the possession they have been granted is implicitly acknowledged by the ripple of applause that normally breaks around the ground.

This is an important point, because there have been a couple of examples of normal procedure not being adhered to in recent weeks. In both cases, teams have profited by doing the unsporting thing, by retaining possession and scoring a goal directly from the throw. Both Derby County in the Premiership and Notts County in Nationwide Division Two salvaged a point from what might otherwise have been a defeat by doing so. And both Middlesbrough and Bristol Rovers, their respective opponents, are understandably miffed, to the extent where Bristol Rovers are now saying that unless referees are given firm guidelines to clear up this grey area, the whole practice will fall into disuse and football will lose one of its last vestiges of sporting etiquette as well as a useful safety mechanism.

Of the two examples quoted above, more people are likely to be familiar with the Middlesbrough case, since it was briefly covered on that night's Match of the Day . Boro managed to leak another two goals through conventional Derby attacks, however, and (grey area turns positively murky) were almost certainly time wasting anyway, so for several reasons what happened to Bristol Rovers at the County Ground last week is a more clear-cut injustice.

Rovers were winning 1-0 with two minutes to go. Their centre-half Steve Foster stayed down after a crunching tackle on the edge of his penalty area, at which goalkeeper Nick Culkin threw the ball out of play by a corner flag. With Foster off the field receiving treatment, Culkin then came to the edge of his area to facilitate an easy return, but having confirmed his intention to the referee County's Craig Ramage threw to a team-mate and Mark Stallard was able to equalise in the final minute with the goalkeeper sprinting to recover his position. Sharp work, undoubtedly. 'Cheating,' was the exact word Rovers manager Ian Holloway used, with perhaps a tad more justification than Bryan Robson, but what to do about it? No law had been infringed. There was no reason for the goal not to stand.

Rovers' request for a rematch, citing the famous Arsenal-Sheffield United precedent of two years ago, was predictably pooh-poohed by both FA and Football League, although the club claim they were principally interested in clarification on the issue. 'We understood all along that there were some aspects in which the Arsenal game was unique, and that the FA would probably never have consented to that rematch had not Arsène Wenger generously offered it,' said Ralph Ellis, Rovers' commercial manager. 'On that subject it was noticeable that while the Notts County directors were very apologetic afterwards they stopped short of offering to play the game again, but rematch or not we feel there is a broader issue that needs tidying up.'

This boils down to whether referees should be allowed any scope to prevent sporting behaviour - eg kicking the ball out of play - rebounding against a team. The FA, still smarting from the slap on the wrist they received from Fifa over the Arsenal rematch, claim there is no scope at all for even talking about unwritten rules. You either return the ball, which is sporting, or keep it, which is unsporting. Both alternatives are possible, and therefore permissible. The one thing you cannot do with an unwritten rule is enforce it, not unilaterally at any rate.

Football's governing bodies normally attract criticism for ignoring problems in the hope they will go away, but this is one that just might. If many more teams adopt a cynical policy, players will soon stop kicking the ball out of play in the first place and leave it to the referee to hold up the game for injury.

That might seem sensible, but there are occasions when the referee is too busy keeping up to notice an incident in back play, or when an injury requires immediate treatment. Bristol Rovers had a player swallow his tongue on the pitch recently, and Holloway can confirm he will continue to instruct his players to kick the ball out if they see a player in difficulty, regardless of what has just happened. 'I hope we don't get a situation where teams refuse to put the ball out of play, for the obvious reason that some injuries can be serious or even life-threatening and immediate treatment is vital,' Holloway said. 'This is not just about Bristol Rovers losing two points. This is an issue for all levels of football to consider, from the Premiership down to the Dog and Duck versus the Gasworks.'

Pity no one wants to consider it. Even the normally upbeat Professional Footballers Association are relatively coy on the subject. 'We expect to see sporting behaviour,' the PFA's Brendan Batson said. 'In fact we have circulated all our members to that effect, but that's about as much as we can do. I think it's worth pointing out that for every example of bad sportsmanship there are hundreds of examples of sporting behaviour. I see a lot of football games, and I've never seen one of these controversies, so let's keep things in perspective. We might just have had two in a week, but I don't think we'll see too many repetitions.'

Batson takes the old pro's view that these situations can be avoided with common sense from all concerned. It has probably occurred to most readers already that last week's unpleasantness would not have happened had the Bristol goalkeeper kicked the ball out near the half way line, or not anticipated his opponent behaving in a certain way. 'You've got to cover yourself,' Batson said. 'Most managers don't want to see throw-ins conceded near goal in any circumstances. I was always told that if I must put it out, put it out as far upfield as possible.'
