webTitle: 'If managers do not take a moral lead then no one will, quite frankly'

fields.headline: 'If managers do not take a moral lead then no one will, quite frankly'
fields.trailText: Alan Smith on the abuse one of the game's remaining vestiges of true sporting behaviour has been receiving.
fields.body:
To cheat or not to cheat, that is the question players have to ask themselves when the ball is thrown out of play to allow an injured opponent to be treated.

Cheating may be too strong a word for taking advantage of an opponent's courtesy and sportsmanship, but that is what it is in effect.

The debate has been stirred up by incidents in the Notts County-Bristol Rovers and Middlesbrough-Derby games, when players decided to go against the common practice of returning the ball to their opponents and went on to score goals that affected the result.

On both occasions, the clubs on the receiving end were furious that one of the game's remaining vestiges of true sporting behaviour was being abused.

I share that view, but I think we have to look beyond what the players do and ask questions of the managers involved. If we as managers do not take a moral lead, no one will, quite frankly.

I don't want to sound pious about this, but there are - or should be - clear boundaries between what is acceptable and unacceptable behaviour, and the vast majority of people in the game understand that and do the right thing.

At Crystal Palace we have a clear view on what to do if a player is injured - put the ball out of touch straight away. Of course, we expect to receive it back after the injured player has been treated, as happens 99 per cent of the time.

I imagine I would be as incensed as the players and staff of Bristol Rovers and Middlesbrough if we received the same response as they did - but it has not happened to us so far and I sincerely hope it never does.

I know there is an argument that there is so much money and pressure in football now that players and managers are only being ultra-professional in trying to gain any advantage they can, but that does not wash with me.

If you pursue that line of thinking, where do we stop? Should we make an exception for professionals but not in the parks and the schools, where the vast majority of football is played?

The professional game is so pervasive at every level of society now that people, particularly the young, see footballers as role models and take their moral leads from them. What sort of message are we sending out if we condone cheating?

There is another line of thought that referees should decide what to do in such situations. At the moment, they are obliged to stop play only if they consider a player to have a serious head injury. But the officials already have enough on their plate during a game, so it would only add to the pressure on them if they had to make instant judgments about whether a player is seriously injured or making a meal of it every time one goes down.

We all criticise them enough anyway - players, managers, fans, media. Perhaps it is time we took more responsibility ourselves rather than look for someone to blame.

The hard truth for most managers, players and fans is that games are not lost because of refereeing errors, but because of our own inadequacies.

Unfortunately the blame culture is too prevalent in this country, and people look to pass the buck or point the finger rather than address their own situations.

That is why I think managers should take the lead and adopt a strong moral stance. The League Manager's Association is a very good 'union', but we rarely use it as a talking shop for these sort of issues. Perhaps we should do so much more, but today's managers tend to keep their own counsel and not confide in each other as often as we could do.

We all say we want honest players, and in my experience the majority of players are extremely honest. You do get the odd one who looks to cut corners, but they are usually players who are not good enough to succeed without recourse to cheating. And let's face it - if a player is prepared to cheat on the field, he is also likely to do it in training or away from the pitch.

The good players don't do it because they don't have to. I have to admit we were recently awarded a penalty which looked dubious. When I saw the incident on video, it confirmed my suspicions and I told the players what I thought of it. Perhaps it was significant that we failed to score from the resulting penalty - was that some sort of natural justice?

We all criticise them enough anyway - players, managers, fans, media. Perhaps it is time we took more responsibility ourselves rather than look for someone to blame. The hard truth for most managers, players and fans is that games are not lost because of refereeing errors, but because of our own inadequacies. Unfortunately the blame culture is too prevalent in this country, and people look to pass the buck or point the finger rather than address their own situations. That is why I think managers should take the lead and adopt a strong moral stance. The League Manager's Association is a very good 'union', but we rarely use it as a talking shop for these sort of issues. Perhaps we should do so much more, but today's managers tend to keep their own counsel and not confide in each other as often as we could do. We all say we want honest players, and in my experience the majority of players are extremely honest. You do get the odd one who looks to cut corners, but they are usually players who are not good enough to succeed without recourse to cheating. And let's face it - if a player is prepared to cheat on the field, he is also likely to do it in training or away from the pitch. The good players don't do it because they don't have to. I have to admit we were recently awarded a penalty which looked dubious. When I saw the incident on video, it confirmed my suspicions and I told the players what I thought of it. Perhaps it was significant that we failed to score from the resulting penalty - was that some sort of natural justice?

fields.headline: Tales from the tabs
fields.trailText: Toon go Lua Lua Newcastle have made two final bids to land Colchester wonderkid Lomano Lua Lua and University of Chile midfielder Clarence Acuna. Bobby Robson has offered £600,000 up front for Lua Lua, rising to £2m based on appearance, and £2m for Acuna. He wants answers with a week.
fields.body:
Toon go Lua Lua Newcastle have made two final bids to land Colchester wonderkid Lomano Lua Lua and University of Chile midfielder Clarence Acuna. Bobby Robson has offered £600,000 up front for Lua Lua, rising to £2m based on appearance, and £2m for Acuna. He wants answers with a week.

Walk on by Ian Walker's decision to quit Spurs has alerted Southampton boss Glenn Hoddle. 'We understand Ian's frustration,' says David Pleat. 'It's been difficult for him - we've become victims of having two top-class keepers vying for one position.' Hoddle is looking to replace struggling Paul Jones.

Sort it says Sav Real Madrid's frustrated Brazilian winger Savio has told new Chelsea boss Claudio Ranieri to sanction his salary-doubling £8m move to London within a week. 'I can't stand this waiting any more - it's been going on three or four weeks. If there's no deal soon I'll just have to stay here.'

Arsène Wenger has given up on David Seaman: he's sent Arsenal scouts to check on Leicester's in-form Tim Flowers: Peter Taylor is ready to replace Flowers with Wolves keeper Michael Oakes. Wenger has also lodged a bid with Bayer Leverkusen for German international defender Jens Nowotny.

 John Gregory won't be rushing German wonderkid Thomas Hitzlsperger into the Aston Villa first team: 'Thomas is very exciting - he could be a regular in 12 months.'

 Bradford reserve keeper Gary Walsh has joined Middlesbrough on a month's loan: Mark Schwarzer, Marlon Beresford and Mark Crossley are all injured.

 Charlton are close to capturing Nigerian trialist Tijjani Babangida - the 26-year-old forward wants to quit Ajax. Alan Curbishley is also ready to battle Ipswich for the signature of Latvian international Olegs Blagonzdezdins.

 Young Chelsea striker Sam Parkin has left for a month's loan at Millwall.

 Coventry have denied moving to sign a third Honduran international to add to new boys Ivan Guerrero and Jairo Martinez - Bryan Richardson says Milton Reyes isn't needed.

 Derby are scouting for new strikers - Jim Smith will sell Dean Sturridge as soon as he's found a replacement.

 Everton's Thomas Myhre has confirmed he'll quit Merseyside as soon as his injury has cleared up: 'several clubs have shown an interest'. Walter Smith, meanwhile, says Montpellier's Eric Decroix is too expensive.

 Ipswich could land American defender Gregg Berhalter after he failed to agree personal terms with Norwich.

 Barcelona defender Frank de Boer has called young Leeds star Alan Smith 'mean and aggressive'.

 Wolves are chasing Leicester veteran Steve Walsh to replace injured Ludo Pollet.

 Liverpool have agreed a £500,000 fee with Montpellier for 19-year-old full-back Gregory Vignal.

 Man City defender Nick Fenton is set to join Notts County for £200,000.

 Mark Bosnich turned down a loan move from Manchester United to Middlesbrough as part of his 'cold war' with Alex Ferguson.

 Middlesbrough's Alun Armstrong has told Bryan Robson he'll quit if he's not given more first-team football.

 Newcastle's Alain Goma has taken up T'ai Chi: 'it's a way of channelling energies so I can have an injury-free season.'

 Southampton's Latvian winger Imants Bleidelis is set to quit: he's not played enough first-team football to secure a new work permit - Stuart Ripley could also leave for Brentford.

 Emerson Thome says Sunderland fans are obsessive: 'The game is all they live for.'

 Tottenham have take Arsenal's Latvian reject Andrejs Rubins on trial.

 West Ham's Gary Charles has joined Birmingham on loan - and Harry Redknapp has told Palace he wants £400,000 for Paul Kitson.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Ranieri: you looking at me?
fields.body:
Ranieri: you looking at me?

Early last week the bookies were offering 500-1 on Ken Bates appointing Voice of the People xenophobe David Mellor as the man to sort out Chelsea's troublesome foreigners - but new boy Claudio Ranieri could provide just as stern a shake-up.

Ranieri - whose arrival in SW6 was confirmed yesterday - has a long track record of no-nonsense man-management, particularly of self-appointed stars. In his most recent job at Atletico Madrid, his first decision was to tell Juninho to find a new club - 'I have different plans', he said - Juninho moved to Middlesbrough within weeks. At Valencia, Ariel Ortega told the press he was unhappy with tactics, and was quickly sold to Sampdoria. And in 1997, Ranieri - the Italian George Graham, famed for a hardcore training regime and no-frills, catenaccio approach - ignited a blazing row with Brazilian striker Romario by fining him for going clubbing two days before a match. 'In my private life I do what I like,' said Romario. 'The night is my friend. If I don't go out, I don't score.' Ranieri ripped into the fans' most popular player, and kicked him out. 'He isn't going to play ever again. Now it is the club president who has to decide what to do with him.'

And Frank Lebeouf thinks he's already had 'his most depressing experience in football'...

What a ghoul: Busby haunts car

'Soccer fan Ken Jones fears his car is haunted by Manchester United legend Sir Matt Busby,' reported the Daily Star on Friday, 'because it MOANS every time he takes it to Leeds matches.'

The 63-year-old Elland Road season-ticket holder, revealing the haunting exclusively to the Star last week, discovered what was wrong with his L-reg Ford Mondeo after asking mechanics to investigate the sinister noises it makes every time he drives to Elland Road. The garage sent away for the vehicle's log book to find out if previous owners had suffered similar difficulties, to discover the car belonged to Matt Busby until 1993, the year before he died aged 86.

Ken - a loyal Star reader - is now convinced the problem needs exorcism. 'Sir Matt is haunting it. He must be livid that his motor has ended up in the hands of a Leeds supporter of 50 years. Each time it's repaired it is OK for a while... but it's not long before he strikes again.' The retired chemical factory supervisor, from Selby, North Yorkshire, added: 'When I saw who was its first owner, I was tempted to set it on fire. But you'd think that after all Sir Matt's successes he'd give me a break and leave my Mondeo alone.'

Ken: divorce isn't so bad

Ken Bates, 6 August, in his Sunday People column.

'I find it worrying that so many clubs seem so quick to hire and fire and wonder what goes through the board's collective mind. The only certainty seems to be that the new season WILL bring casualties. But it would be nice to be proved wrong and find that the Premiership is a haven of forgiving fans and patient chairmen. Gianluca Vialli [is] our most successful manager ever. Maybe sense and stability will reign this season. After all, kicking out managers can be as traumatic as a divorce.'

fields.headline: Ranieri a sergeant with style
fields.standfirst: The Blues' new coach believes in tough training and the  catanaccio spirit
fields.trailText: You are Kings Road plc and when you claim on your brochures that you are dead sophisticated, you even spell it right. The trouble is that the football end of your business - one of your main sidelines - isn't going too well.
fields.body:
You are Kings Road plc and when you claim on your brochures that you are dead sophisticated, you even spell it right. The trouble is that the football end of your business - one of your main sidelines - isn't going too well.

There are problems with the staff, hardly any of them speak English (you just can't get them these days, it must be the wages). You'll need someone who is hard on them, but urbane, because they'll need to spin a good line with the media. Important that, because it's the media who ensure that your style never goes out of fashion.

You've tried promoting from within, because they appeared to speak the same language as the ones they had to supervise. But that didn't work, they didn't manage exactly what you were looking for.

Oh, and working with the chairman can prove tricky. Step forward Claudio Ranieri, virtually unknown in London (until Friday evening), but a nom de household on the Continent. Well, Spain and Italy, and that's where it matters.

Unemployed? He can't be that good. Who sacked him last? They didn't, he walked out on Atletico Madrid, departing every bit as stylishly as the manner in which he coaches.

More to the point, he has worked successfully with Spanish club presidents, one of whom, Jesus Gil, makes Ken Bates look like Ken Barlow.

Everyone who gets to rub shoulders with him will realise that he is a joy to deal with. He will do wonders for Chelsea Village, generally brighten up the place, and club employees and the media will love him.

Where the 'sergeant' name he has acquired comes in is where it's most needed, on the training pitch. As a coach Ranieri combines the four most vital qualities: getting the players in tip-top condition, as a tactician, a motivator and a team-builder.

Ranieri is reminiscent of a less prickly George Graham. He will come in, and boy, will the players know about it in training. Ranieri is theatrical, and he bawls, screams and generally cajoles until his charges get to do whatever it was that was demanded of them in the first place.

Ranieri is nothing if not Italian, and where as before the sons of Rome exported their military might, their modern-day versions build from the back. A team is built from the defence up, the midfield support the defence and press their opponents, and when on the attack, the defenders support the midfield.

Ranieri's teams do not speculate, men are behind the ball, and he is quite content to sit back and defend on the edge of the area. His sides threaten principally from the counter-attack, where training will have worked on speed, verticality and the players supporting each other.

After one game, when his Valencia team had shown defensive lapses, he was asked about imposing a more Italian style. 'If I could, I would love to impose a catenaccio. ' In actual fact, Ranieri regards that most Italian of innovations, the bolt-like defence, as old hat. He is, in every sense, a modern coach.

Style takes a very second place to results, a scrambled 1-0 win will suit him fine. The game is about winning, playing nicely is not his concern, late surrenders are unlikely under Ranieri, and a disinterested performance away to a Bradford or Watford a virtual impossibility.

Ranieri is always on top of things. The fans will get to love his expressive touchline persona, the players will not. Not for him the sitting impassively on the bench while events on the pitch take their course. Claudio is the admiral on the deck, but exhorting and pointing, and gesturing to the heavens above in that uniquely Mediterranean ' porca miseria ' affectation.

If word has not yet reached the players via Zola and Hasselbaink, then the Chelsea strollers are in for a shock. Training under Ranieri is hell. In will come a Mr Bean lookalike - Signor Roberto Sassi - the fitness coach, and regular sessions with the Conconi machine, a beeping endurance test, one of several designed to build up and periodically test the levels of fitness and stamina.

Pre-season is important to Ranieri and his methods, meaning that it may not be until 2001-2002 that the full fruits of his industry are appreciated. His training methods are important to the work on the pitch, but his selection of the personnel and the way the team blends are also his forte.

TO A GREAT extent he provided the base for the unfancied Valencia that reached the Champions League final. He made the great Mendieta the player he is, blooded Farinos and Angulo, and converted a second-rate Claudio Lope into a world-beater.

He left Valencia following a blistering demonstration of superiority in a 3-0 Spanish Cup triumph, much to the chagrin of all concerned, to work with Jesus Gil, because of his daughter's education in Madrid.

At Valencia he had worked under Paco Roig - an apprentice Jesus Gil - and ironically only had problems with his mild-mannered successor. Throughout his career, Ranieri appears to have thrived on working with strong personalities that match his own. There is, therefore, hope for the ménage à Ken after all.

The resulting product on the pitch may not be pretty to watch at times, but if it brings Milan in place of St Gallen you might not hear that many complaints down the Kings Road.

Ranieri fact file

Claudio Ranieri, born 20/10/51 (Rome)

1969-1986: Unspectacular playing career with Roma, Catanzaro and Catania.

Coaching career

Vigor (86-87)
Campania (87-88)
Cagliari (88-91)
Napoli - where he coached Gianfranco Zola (91-93)
Fiorentina (93-97) - won Serie B 94; Coppa d'Italia and Supercopa, 96
Valencia, Spain (97-99) - wins Copa del Rey, 99
Atletico Madrid, Spain (99-00) - quits in March, club relegated later.

Honours
Italian Cup (1996), Italian Supercup (1996), Spanish Cup (1999)

fields.headline: Now football goes panto
fields.trailText: Will this be the future of football? A double-header that starts with Australia's women taking on Sweden; and is followed by Australia's men playing Nigeria. Both games played in exquisite, sparkling clean stadium with plenty of fine food - Honey Soy Drumettes, anyone? - and cappuccino for all. Football repackaged as the global family game, wholesome fun for the soccer mums and dads and sons and daughters. It's possible.
fields.body:
Will this be the future of football? A double-header that starts with Australia's women taking on Sweden; and is followed by Australia's men playing Nigeria. Both games played in exquisite, sparkling clean stadium with plenty of fine food - Honey Soy Drumettes, anyone? - and cappuccino for all. Football repackaged as the global family game, wholesome fun for the soccer mums and dads and sons and daughters. It's possible.

It was a bad night for Australia. The Olyroos are definitely out of the Olympics, the Matildas are long odds-on to follow them. (No apologies for the monikers for they are obligatory at the Friendly Games with even newsreaders using nicknames rather than surnames).

It wasn't, however, necessarily a bad night for Australian football with the men's game against Nigeria being a belter. Both sides needed to win after Australia had been somewhat unfortunate to lose their opening game to Italy 1-0 and Nigeria somewhat fortunate to draw 3-3 with Honduras. The Australian defeat had been caused by a blunder by West Ham's Hayden Foxe described by his manager as being 'like Beethoven'. A bit deaf? No, 'a man who wants to do things with class all the time'.

Within 22 minutes Australia were 2-0 down. Vince Grella gave the ball away in midfield, Garba Lawal stormed forward and Pius Ikedia walloped the ball into the net. Pius is a little gem; a Nigerian Jimmy Johnstone with pace if you'll allow me to get carried away. Their second was even better, Julius Aghahowa dribbling through on the break before lifting the ball over Danny Milosevic. He celebrated with five consecutive back-flips. Team captain Celestine Babayaro once attempted this trick in a pre-season friendly for Chelsea - he injured himself badly enough to delay his debut for many a month. Aghahowa was different class. Almost Olympic gymnast class.

The crowd loved it. They resembled a pantomime audience and it was a perfect panto moment. Oh how they cheered the goodies' rare successes and booed the baddies, referee Carlos Eugenio Simon, interventions. I'm almost certain I heard someone call out 'he's behind you'.

The problem was that the panto seemed over before it had really begun. Nigeria were sharp, inventive, fast. Australia were men-at-work-man-like. But never underestimate Aussie grit. Beethoven, aided by a deflection, scored from a free-kick and then Kasey Wehrman, who plays for Perth Glory, chipped the ball to Viduka who back-heeled it into his path and he scored magnificently.

Pandemonium. 'Ladies and Gentlemen that concludes the first part of this match, the scores are Australia two, Nigeria two,' announced the PA. And everyone went off for interval snacks.

The panto's best scene occurred 10 minutes into the second act. There was a fracas and Captain Emerton pushed Captain Babayaro who fell theatrically to the ground. Suddenly everyone was involved in the set-piece. Primarily Simon Colosimo who ran half the length of the pitch wagging his finger at Julius Aghahowa all the time. The crowd didn't know whether to cheer or boo, laugh or cry. And referee Simon wasn't too certain how to react either, finally deciding, in a spirit of compromise, to dismiss both Captains - an Olympic first?

Emerton, who had played well, could have no complaint, Babayaro, who had played abysmally, must have asked if he could be dismissed from the stage to save himself further embarrassment.

There is, of course, a moral to the panto. The finger-wagging Colosimo making the error that lost his side the match - Victor Agali profiting with the winning goal.

Earlier, the Australian women had played out a game that was nearer to mime than pantomime. Yes, it was that dull. The Swedes should have won it in the first-half. Instead, the Australians took a 57th minute lead through best player on the pitch Cheryl Salisbury. Ten minutes later Sweden equalised from the penalty spot. The result is unlikely to help either.

Afterwards, Cheryl said about a game in which they lost the corner-count 15-1, 'today we played the football'. The footballing women have learnt how to talk the talk and it won't be long before they start walking the walk.

It wasn't, however, necessarily a bad night for Australian football with the men's game against Nigeria being a belter. Both sides needed to win after Australia had been somewhat unfortunate to lose their opening game to Italy 1-0 and Nigeria somewhat fortunate to draw 3-3 with Honduras. The Australian defeat had been caused by a blunder by West Ham's Hayden Foxe described by his manager as being 'like Beethoven'. A bit deaf? No, 'a man who wants to do things with class all the time'. Within 22 minutes Australia were 2-0 down. Vince Grella gave the ball away in midfield, Garba Lawal stormed forward and Pius Ikedia walloped the ball into the net. Pius is a little gem; a Nigerian Jimmy Johnstone with pace if you'll allow me to get carried away. Their second was even better, Julius Aghahowa dribbling through on the break before lifting the ball over Danny Milosevic. He celebrated with five consecutive back-flips. Team captain Celestine Babayaro once attempted this trick in a pre-season friendly for Chelsea - he injured himself badly enough to delay his debut for many a month. Aghahowa was different class. Almost Olympic gymnast class. The crowd loved it. They resembled a pantomime audience and it was a perfect panto moment. Oh how they cheered the goodies' rare successes and booed the baddies, referee Carlos Eugenio Simon, interventions. I'm almost certain I heard someone call out 'he's behind you'. The problem was that the panto seemed over before it had really begun. Nigeria were sharp, inventive, fast. Australia were men-at-work-man-like. But never underestimate Aussie grit. Beethoven, aided by a deflection, scored from a free-kick and then Kasey Wehrman, who plays for Perth Glory, chipped the ball to Viduka who back-heeled it into his path and he scored magnificently. Pandemonium. 'Ladies and Gentlemen that concludes the first part of this match, the scores are Australia two, Nigeria two,' announced the PA. And everyone went off for interval snacks. The panto's best scene occurred 10 minutes into the second act. There was a fracas and Captain Emerton pushed Captain Babayaro who fell theatrically to the ground. Suddenly everyone was involved in the set-piece. Primarily Simon Colosimo who ran half the length of the pitch wagging his finger at Julius Aghahowa all the time. The crowd didn't know whether to cheer or boo, laugh or cry. And referee Simon wasn't too certain how to react either, finally deciding, in a spirit of compromise, to dismiss both Captains - an Olympic first? Emerton, who had played well, could have no complaint, Babayaro, who had played abysmally, must have asked if he could be dismissed from the stage to save himself further embarrassment. There is, of course, a moral to the panto. The finger-wagging Colosimo making the error that lost his side the match - Victor Agali profiting with the winning goal. Earlier, the Australian women had played out a game that was nearer to mime than pantomime. Yes, it was that dull. The Swedes should have won it in the first-half. Instead, the Australians took a 57th minute lead through best player on the pitch Cheryl Salisbury. Ten minutes later Sweden equalised from the penalty spot. The result is unlikely to help either. Afterwards, Cheryl said about a game in which they lost the corner-count 15-1, 'today we played the football'. The footballing women have learnt how to talk the talk and it won't be long before they start walking the walk.

webTitle: 'I think he had a problem with more than one player - and it is difficult to sack four' Paolo Di Canio on his friend Gianluca Vialli

fields.headline: 'I think he had a problem with more than one player - and it is difficult to sack four' Paolo Di Canio on his friend Gianluca Vialli
fields.trailText: Paolo Di Canio might have joined his great friend Gianluca Vialli across London last week, the subject of a £4 million bid from Stamford Bridge. Negotiations didn't last long - and nor did the manager. Di Canio is not impressed.
fields.body:
Paolo Di Canio might have joined his great friend Gianluca Vialli across London last week, the subject of a £4 million bid from Stamford Bridge. Negotiations didn't last long - and nor did the manager. Di Canio is not impressed.

'It's simply incredible, even if you have a dressing room against you, to sack a manager who won five trophies in two-and-a-half years and is the most successful manager in Chelsea's history. I don't understand.

'To win something important like the league in England you don't have to have only money. You are not a good club if you are only a rich club. You have to be a club like Man United or Arsenal, who buy many players but the club and the managers share one soul. I don't think he had a problem with one player because if he had a problem with [Frank] Leboeuf you can sell him and the problem is finished. I think he had a problem with more than one - and it's difficult to sack four players. But I don't think it was Gianluca's fault. I know him. He's a good manager and a good lad.

'I read an interview where Ken Bates said he spent £50m but it wasn't good business because they didn't win the league. Firstly, if the club think only of business it's not a good club. Secondly, I honestly don't think Gianluca had a squad good enough to win the league. Chelsea can't compare with Man United or Arsenal even if they have great players like Zola, Hasselbaink, Desailly. They have a good 11 but not enough depth in the squad. I watched Chelsea-Arsenal and in the second half Wenger put on Wiltord and Bergkamp from the bench, to join Pires, Henry and Kanu. They have five top world strikers. Chelsea have Zola and Hasselbaink and Flo on the bench. If Hasselbaink is injured you struggle for goalscorers. I think Gianluca made a very, very good job at Chelsea. So they have to thank him.

'Only time will tell if Chelsea made a mistake but at the moment I think so. They say he didn't make a good job because they think they can win the league. But this is incredible for me. Football is so good because at the end of the season I might have to say sorry, they were right, but I think they would have to perform a miracle to win the league. I've seen Man United and Arsenal, and Man United, especially, are a perfect machine.

'Gianluca will come back into management, of course. He lived in my house for two months when he moved from Sampdoria to Juventus, we won the Uefa Cup together, he is my friend, and if I know him, he will decide his future with calm. He's only 36 so why should he decide quickly? Many clubs in Italy want him but he'll take his time.'

fields.headline: A man of many moods
fields.standfirst: 'Some hate me, some love me, some think I'm crazy. Sometimes I'm kind, sometimes I'm angry.' The Premiership's great entertainer Paolo di Canio takes time out to talk to  Amy Lawrence
fields.trailText: 'Some hate me, some love me, some think I'm crazy. Sometimes I'm kind, sometimes I'm angry.' The Premiership's great entertainer Paolo di Canio takes time out to talk to Amy Lawrence.
fields.body:
A monsoon has hit Chadwell Heath, the sky is the colour of charcoal, and a deeply tanned Paolo Di Canio scoots around West Ham's training ground sporting buttercup-tinted sunglasses. It is impossible for his outlook on life to be grey so, hey presto, he finds a way to bring in an instant rainbow.

Scanning a compilation of Di Canio's greatest hits during his four-year stint in Britain it is necessary to take a deep breath every so often, because the list is so exhaustive. This son of the south of Italy does not comprehend the notion of doing things by halves. He does things by doubles.

Why simply feel miffed when the manager leaves your club (in this case Tommy Burns and Celtic) when you can huff publicly, abandon training, and gallop out of town on a £4.5 million transfer? Why merely get sent off when you can send a referee tumbling over (step forward Paul Alcock), provoke an 11-match ban, and go awol into the bargain? Why score a tap-in when you can caress the ball with a balletic mid-air flick to claim goal of the season? The list goes on and on.

So regularly is he the protagonist in some operatic melodrama, it must be darned hard work being Paolo Di Canio. Hear him open his heart, watch his extravagant gesticulations, listen to his boundless enthusiasm in full flow and you realise what an irresistible life it must be. Yes, his wild temperament courts controversy, but the pros render the cons almost insignificant. 'My character made many problems for me in football but without it I wouldn't play at the top level. If I had to weigh up the positives and the negatives I have to say thank you God, or whoever, because I was lucky.'

But surely, had he been luckier he could have enjoyed a more successful career. His spontaneous gifts would not look out of place in the colours of his country, or as a regular performer in the Champions League, or in a team capable of winning the Premiership. When ability and attitude are in perfect harmony, he can emulate Giggs, Bergkamp, Zola, Kewell - even Del Piero, Totti, Inzaghi.

'Everybody says when they meet me I deserve to play for a bigger team,' he says, surprised that they don't feel - as he does - that West Ham inspire his very best. 'Taxi drivers say, "Why don't you play for Man United?" What do you mean I deserve to play for Man United? I play well here because this squad give me the opportunity. Maybe at Man United I wouldn't play so well because here I get 50 balls per game and Man United you have to share 50 balls with players like Beckham, Giggs, Scholes. Here I have the opportunity to turn the game. The team believe in me, they trust me, they give me opportunities. "Come on Paolo!" they tell me every time. "Come on Paolo, you can win the game for us!" They give me energy, power, even when I am tired.' He becomes wonderfully animated merely thinking about it.

No topic inspires him quite like the old chestnut of referees. He's convinced they don't like him. He can't help implying that they come from the George Orwell school of all players being equal but some more equal than others. To illustrate the point he ends up dramatising a scene where he is shot in the back by a defender with a gun. 'Is that a penalty, ref?' he gasps, his dying words, before roaring with laughter at the twist when the referee books him for diving as he is carted off to the mortuary.

'I argue with referees a lot. I do this when I don't see a fair attitude from them. Sometimes I would like to say something in a more gentle way but you have snap decisions. It's difficult to say something like an Oxford student [he pops a plum in his mouth] "I'm sorry, why didn't you give me a penalty?" I'm jealous of players who can say it calmly but I can't do that.'

Even though Harry Redknapp is notoriously crafty in the transfer market, the £1.7 million he negotiated to bring Di Canio to West Ham has to be his best hustle yet. Had Sheffield Wednesday not been in such a predicament such a bid would have been dismissed as laughable. There was a small element of risk for the Londoners, given they were taking on a player with so much disciplinary 'previous', but Di Canio's lavish talent, coupled with a dedicated attitude to training and to winning, obliterates risk.

Redknapp is Di Canio's most vociferous supporter. When his showman is criticised he fumes in defence. Praise often prompts an equally prickly response, as if it bugs him that people who are so quick to castigate can suddenly take off the blinkers and admire the Italian's brilliance.

The lifebelt West Ham threw him when he was scraping the depths touched Di Canio deeply and he consequently developed a genuine affection for them. 'Every club I gave my best but there is a special situation here at West Ham and maybe I'm giving more because they helped me when I was very down. This club gave me a big hand. So, because of this I give everything I have, all my energy, because I feel the people, the club, the shirt are part of my life now. Honestly.

'Maybe people don't trust me when I say it but I'd prefer to score two own goals and win 3-2 than score four goals and lose 5-4. At the end of the season if we go down, I go down with the squad. That's no glory. I prefer to score 20 own goals in one season and win the cup than score 45 goals and be relegated.' West Ham's position at the foot of the table doesn't worry him because he believes in the quality around him. 'I want to tell the supporters not to panic,' he announces, 'because I'm sure we'll turn it around.'

Sure enough to resist overtures from Chelsea last week. When the £4m bid came in he met with chairman and manager and it didn't take long for all concerned to reject the offer. As Di Canio recalls: 'We said to each other: "We are a good marriage, why do we have to divorce?" There are no problems between us.' It might have been a different story for £15m. 'I would sacrifice myself for that price because I can help the club in a different way, to get big business.

'But £4m? Not good for them, not good for me, because I have to move to a new club. We'll stay together for the rest of my career. Then we'll divorce when I can't give more energy... Or maybe I can stay at West Ham in some other way. It could be good. Not manager [he chortles] because Harry is a good manager and I don't want to replace him.'

Anyway, he confesses, he's not sure he could supplant his joker's mentality in the dressing room with the required authority for management. 'We say in Italy to be a good manager you have to be a bit of a bastard. Fabio Capello was difficult with me because I felt he made some unfair decisions, but for me he is one of the best managers in the world. I don't have to confuse sentiment with honest opinion. He was a bit of a bastard with me but his management was fantastic. He won everything. With strong players he was ruthless.'

Having represented a clutch of the most prestigious clubs in Italy - Lazio, Napoli, Juventus, AC Milan - Di Canio emigrated in 1996 because no big Italian club wanted him any more. It was never a case of doubting his ability, but his mentality.

His notoriety as a hothead began years ago, when he was the match-winner in the Rome derby. Lazio were his boyhood club, the team he followed all over the country getting into occasional scrapes - 'but no knives' he's quick to point out - and having scored the goal to beat Roma for the first time in years, he was photographed celebrating with a middle finger raised in the direction of the opposition fans. A reputation was born. This, he believes, is part of the explanation for a closed door to the national team. 'In Italy they don't like it when people speak too much. We look like a democratic nation but we are not. We have to shut up. I tell people what I think. If we play crap, we play crap. Full stop. No excuses. Vialli had the same problem with Arrigo Sacchi, and Zenga the keeper was a bit crazy. They don't like that. They like you to say "Yes, Sir". This is not my job.

'Everyone says to me, Paolo, why weren't you ever called up for the national squad? I don't know why, maybe I am crazy. Not because I think I am the best but I think I deserve one opportunity. Not more. One! I told everybody I don't want to play in Euro 2000 or the World Cup 2002. Just one friendly game, one training session. I don't ask for the moon.'

At least Di Canio can talk for Italy. His passion on the field has its roots in an appalling injury suffered as a teenager. When an Achilles tendon became infected doctors told him he might not walk normally again and told him there was a risk he would lose a leg. After the operation, it took him 14 months to recover. When he became a professional footballer he vowed to give 100 per cent every day for the rest of his career.

Football, he preaches, is not football unless there is emotion. He is staggered that the authorities are clamping down on goal celebrations. First they banned breaching the touchline to hug the fans, now stripping off a shirt is illegal. 'This is terrible,' he moans. 'Scoring is the most exciting thing in football. You live your life in football for winning, and to win you have to score. It is the most emotional time for everybody!'

We are fortunate to have him here. Footballers with the dash, flash and magnetism capable of taking on the legacy of a Gascoigne or Cantona are rare. The question of how he feels perceived in England makes him ponder. 'Some hate me, some love me, some think I'm crazy. Sometimes I'm a very kind boy, sometimes I'm very angry.'

There is more tranquillity in his private life. 'I am a passionate man, a strong man, but outside of football with my family I am completely different. I have two girls and they changed me spiritually. You have responsibility in your life and I understand now what it is to be a father. It looks so far away when your own father tells you how you will feel about things when you are a father. You want to go to the disco with your friends. Now I understand.

'My parents gave me principles. My father was a brickie, but with principles. Even if I am crazy on the field this is the message I want to give to my daughters: Have respect for other people.'

fields.headline: QPR limp to defeat
fields.trailText: Gerry Francis's miserable season continued as his depleted QPR side lost 4-2 to Barnsley at Oakwell. Francis has spent much of his managerial career plagued by injuries and this year promises to be no different. With only seven games played QPR are already without 11 regular first team players and the recent injuries to Karl Ready and Chris Plummer will see both players out for up to six weeks.
fields.body:
Gerry Francis's miserable season continued as his depleted QPR side lost 4-2 to Barnsley at Oakwell. Francis has spent much of his managerial career plagued by injuries and this year promises to be no different. With only seven games played QPR are already without 11 regular first team players and the recent injuries to Karl Ready and Chris Plummer will see both players out for up to six weeks.

Earlier in the week Francis admitted that, despite his team's precarious funds, he will have to enter the transfer market if QPR are to salvage a season which has already seen them knocked out of the Worthington Cup by unfancied Colchester United.

'I think it's got to the stage where we have to do something,' he said. 'Our lack of resources is getting to a dangerous level and the only option is to enter the transfer market. At the moment I feel like I must have driven over a leprechaun, given the amount of bad luck we've had recently.'

That luck showed no signs of changing yesterday as Jerome Darlington sidefooted the ball into his own net before Neil Shipperley and Robbie Van der Laan added two more for Barnsley before half-time. Chris Kiwomya briefly gave the London side hopes of a revival when he scored twice but a Bruce Dyer goal finished the match in Barnsley's favour.

Elsewhere there was no change at the top of the First Division as Fulham made it seven out of seven, upping the pressure on Nottingham Forest boss David Platt in the process. Louis Saha scored his tenth goal of the season before Fabrice Fernandes and Barry Hayles added two more to ensure a comfortable victory.

But Platt's problems are nothing in comparison to those of Paul Jewell. The erstwhile Bradford boss saw his Sheffield Wednesday side slump yet again as they were overrun by a bright Tranmere side who finished 2-0 winners, leaving Wednesday second from bottom.

In the Second Division Walsall scraped a draw against Bournemouth to stay three points clear at the top after nearest contenders Reading lost 1-0 to Peterborough thanks to an 89th-minute penalty.

Meanwhile Third Division leaders Chesterfield continued their strong start to the season, overwhelming Mansfield 4-0.
fields.bodyText: Gerry Francis's miserable season continued as his depleted QPR side lost 4-2 to Barnsley at Oakwell. Francis has spent much of his managerial career plagued by injuries and this year promises to be no different. With only seven games played QPR are already without 11 regular first team players and the recent injuries to Karl Ready and Chris Plummer will see both players out for up to six weeks. Earlier in the week Francis admitted that, despite his team's precarious funds, he will have to enter the transfer market if QPR are to salvage a season which has already seen them knocked out of the Worthington Cup by unfancied Colchester United. 'I think it's got to the stage where we have to do something,' he said. 'Our lack of resources is getting to a dangerous level and the only option is to enter the transfer market. At the moment I feel like I must have driven over a leprechaun, given the amount of bad luck we've had recently.' That luck showed no signs of changing yesterday as Jerome Darlington sidefooted the ball into his own net before Neil Shipperley and Robbie Van der Laan added two more for Barnsley before half-time. Chris Kiwomya briefly gave the London side hopes of a revival when he scored twice but a Bruce Dyer goal finished the match in Barnsley's favour. Elsewhere there was no change at the top of the First Division as Fulham made it seven out of seven, upping the pressure on Nottingham Forest boss David Platt in the process. Louis Saha scored his tenth goal of the season before Fabrice Fernandes and Barry Hayles added two more to ensure a comfortable victory. But Platt's problems are nothing in comparison to those of Paul Jewell. The erstwhile Bradford boss saw his Sheffield Wednesday side slump yet again as they were overrun by a bright Tranmere side who finished 2-0 winners, leaving Wednesday second from bottom. In the Second Division Walsall scraped a draw against Bournemouth to stay three points clear at the top after nearest contenders Reading lost 1-0 to Peterborough thanks to an 89th-minute penalty. Meanwhile Third Division leaders Chesterfield continued their strong start to the season, overwhelming Mansfield 4-0.

fields.headline: Finn's finish lifts Hibs
fields.trailText: With the old Firm not playing yesterday, Hibernian seized their chance and went top of the Scottish Premier League after beating Motherwell 2-0.
fields.body:
With the old Firm not playing yesterday, Hibernian seized their chance and went top of the Scottish Premier League after beating Motherwell 2-0.

After a surprisingly good start to the season, confidence is high among Alec McLeish's side and they ended up comfortable winners, despite turning in a fairly poor performance, Finnish striker Mixu Paatelainen scoring both goals to give them 19 points from eight games.

In truth the Edinburgh side hardly deserved their victory. Motherwell, playing by far the more attractive football, dominated large parts of the game but paid the price for an inability to convert their chances. And, despite Hibs' soporific showing, Paatelainen came close to scoring a hat trick when his header grazed the crossbar with Motherwell 'keeper Andy Goram clearly beaten.

But while the green half of Edinburgh was rejoicing, Hibernian know their time at the top is limited. Martin O'Neill's arrival in Glasgow has revitalised Celtic - the Old Firm side have now won 10 matches in a row since the former Leicester boss arrived. They are unbeaten in the Scottish Premiership having taken 18 points from six games and are unlikely to find seventh placed Dunfermline much of a problem when the two sides meet tomorrow.

Kilmarnock were also celebrating after they joined Rangers, who play Hearts today, on 13 points after a 26th minute Ally Mitchell goal was enough to see off Aberdeen. Meanwhile Dundee United's miserable season continued as Stephen Wright was sent off in the 32nd minute against St Mirren. But, while Alex Smith's side were briefly rocked by the dismissal, they clung on to salvage a point after their opponents failed to take advantage.

First Division league leaders Livingston suffered a surprise setback when they lost 4-0 at home to Raith Rovers who, encouraged by an early fourth-minute lead, dominated the match throughout.

Inverness Caledonian Thistle remain rooted to the bottom of the league after losing 1-0 to Ross County. In the Second Division, Stranraer beat Queens Park 3-0 to go top while the surprise result of the day was at Berwick, where the fourth-placed side slumped to 4-0 to Queen of the South.

fields.headline: A year in the sunshine
fields.standfirst: Desmond Balmer, Joanne O'Connor  and Sarah Jacobs offer a comprehensive guide to the essential Caribbean festivals
fields.trailText: Desmond Balmer, Joanne O'Connor and Sarah Jacobs offer a comprehensive guide to the essential Caribbean festivals
fields.byline: Desmond Balmer, Joanne O'Connor  and Sarah Jacobs
fields.body:
January
January is the month of saints in Puerto Rico . Most of the celebrations date back to colonial times, but the Festival of San Sebastian in the city of San Juan is a street party with a difference. The tradition only began last century to commemorate the old city, and now people flock from all over the island to join in the salsa and procession of 'cabezudos' - huge character masks which represent favourite policemen and mayors of the old town.

February
For five days before Ash Wednesday the streets of Port of Spain in Trinidad are taken over by one of the biggest and noisiest parties in the world. The Trinidad and Tobago Carnival (24-28 February 2001) is the original Caribbean carnival with costumed parades, calypso music, steel bands and dancing in the streets. The pre-Lenten Carnival is celebrated on islands throughout the Caribbean.

March
Irish visitors will be bemused but beguiled if they visit the community of Sauters on 17 March. The parish on the northern nape of Grenada is named after St Patrick, the Irish patron saint, thanks to the lasting influence of an Irish order of teacher priests. And St Patrick's Day is celebrated with as much enthusiasm as in Dublin, though the flavour is of rum and reggae. Like many an Irish town, Sauteurs has more bars than shops: their shutters are propped open by giant loudspeakers pumping out music loud enough to knock the unwary sideways. There are food stalls and displays of agricultural equipment and at the top of the main street the Royal Grenadian Police play with a rhythmic big band sound.

April
Antigua's Sailing Week (29 April - 5 May 2001) attracts enthusiasts from all over the world for fun regattas, serious racing and the obligatory rum punches and 'jump-ups' at the end of each day. Last year's event attracted over 250 boats. The preceding week's Classic Yacht Regatta (19-24 April 2001) is a chance to see large wooden sailing ships in action, including some impressive Tall Ships.

May
One of the foremost musical events in the Caribbean, the St Lucia Jazz Festival (4-13 May 2001) takes place against a spectacular natural backdrop. Patti LaBelle, Gladys Knight and Los Van Van headed the bill at last year's event, so expect some big names. Free events, fringe shows, food, arts and craft stalls all add to the entertainment. (www.stluciajazz.com)

June
June is the windiest month of the year in the Dominican Republic. This is good news for windsurf enthusiasts who are invited to join in the Caberete Race Week (18-24 June 2001) Events are held for all levels and abilities, including those who want to turn up and splash about in the waves. Aside from the windsurfing there will be beach parties, and merenge lessons.

July
Cuba has several carnivals but the biggest and brightest is the one held on 25 July in Santiago de Cuba. Spanish, African and French influences have all added to the melting pot of this three-day extravaganza to celebrate the end of the sugar harvest. Every neighbourhood brings its own band to the carnival, and equipped with trumpets, metal tyre rims and frying pans, they lead an enormous conga parade through the city streets. The vibe is so magnetic that some dancers leave their homes still wearing hair curlers and house slippers.

August
If you're up for five nights of dancing and rum, head for Jamaica's Reggae Sumfest held in the first week of August. Each evening is different, with international reggae, dance-hall ragga and singing events following a big beach party on the first night. You can even buy a back-stage pass to meet the stars, who often include major bands such as UB40.

September
It may be hurricane season but the residents of St Kitts still turn out in their hundreds to celebrate the island's National Independence Day on the 19 September. Festivities continue for a week and include parades, picnics, dances and cocktail receptions. The day itself boasts a big military parade as well as horseracing on sister island Nevis.

October
Pirates will sail into George Town's harbour on board a replica seventeenth-century Spanish galleon at the start of Cayman Islands Pirate's Week (24 October - 31 October). Underwater and land-based treasure hunts, street parties, music and lots of swashbuckling make up the week's festivities.

November
A day of military parades and national costume, 3 November marks the date in 1978 the British moved out of Dominica and left the country to govern itself. It's not the wild street party you might associate with Caribbean celebrations, but it is spectacular none the less. A highlight of the Independence Day Celebrations is the traditional dancing which is accompanied by the government's 'music lover's band'. Barbados follows with its Independence celebrations on 30 November.

December
Sean Connery's James Bond dodged bullets in a spectacular chase through a junkanoo procession in Dr No. This was a specially staged mid-summer event. The real thing, held in the Bahamas in the early hours of Boxing Day and again on New Year's Day, is too serious an affair to be manipulated by a film crew. This is the Bahamian carnival, a raw celebration of traditional culture with the working class 'Over the Hill' districts seeking to upstage each with their elaborate dress and exuberant displays, whistles blowing and goatskin drums beating and cowbells ringing. The late premier Sir Lynden Pindling used to take part, though you would have been hard-pressed to spot him underneath a huge straw hat.

webTitle: Dundee flair fails to pay off

fields.headline: Dundee flair fails to pay off
fields.trailText: St Johnstone 1 - 1 Dundee
fields.body:
Perhaps the time has come for Ivano Bonetti, Dundee's player-manager, to call upon the services of a graduate of football's school of hard knocks to explain the harsh facts of life to his Foreign Legion.

Otherwise, Dundee may eventually be forced to reflect in the cold light of day that skill alone does not guarantee a successful outcome. Indeed, St Johnstone provided a timely reminder for their much more gifted opponents that hard work is just as important.

It seemed inconceivable that Dundee would fail to secure a victory, given the measure of dominance they enjoyed for the first half-hour or so. But, in the end, they found themselves hanging on grimly to share in the spoils.

Both managers pronounced themselves reasonably satisfied at the outcome, but one was left with the suspicion that Sandy Clark, the St Johnstone manager, was entitled to feel a little more satisfied with his players' efforts, all things considered.

This was St Johnstone's fifth draw in seven SPL fixtures and a measure of just how competitive Scotland's Premier Division can be outside the domains of Celtic and Rangers.

But the Perth side will feel, no doubt, that had they shown a little more composure and a greater level of accuracy, they would have earned greater reward in the form of three points.

For Dundee had to rely on the sterling services of their goalkeeper, Robert Douglas, to prevent them from suffering a defeat that would, on reflection, have been unjust when measured against the efforts of both teams over the course of 90 minutes.

Douglas nevertheless had to be in sparkling form in the closing stages to prevent Keigan Parker and Graeme Jones from snatching a winning goal. He also had to endure an anxious moment when Steven Tweed impeded Parker on the edge of the penalty area.

There was little doubt that the offence was committed outside the box. But a lesser referee than Mr Underhill might have been persuaded to have awarded a penalty in the face of such furious protests from the St Johnstone players.

For all that they lacked a cutting edge, Dundee could not be condemned for failing to provide a sizeable measure of entertainment for the 5,055 spectators. Some of their play was quite delightful to watch and Fabien Caballero, one of their Argentine recruits, is indeed a most talented individual.

Unfortunately, for Dundee, Caballero was unable to supply the necessary finishing touch to add to his tally of five goals so far. But he, more than anyone else, caused problems for St Johnstone, in the early stages at least.

One example of Caballero's ball skills came after 13 minutes, when he outpaced the defence down the right side before shooting narrowly past the target from the tightest of angles.

But it was indicative of Dundee's repeated failures to make more of their opportunities that St Johnstone very nearly stole ahead after 25 minutes.

Nick Dasovic's initial shot was blocked by the defence and Jones, following up, was denied only by the quick-thinking Marco De Marchi, who cleared off the line.

Dundee have a midweek date with their City rivals United in the first derby encounter of the season, and they will need to be more alert in front of goal if they are to add to their near-neighbours' current woes.

webTitle: Dons in need of the killer touch

fields.headline: Dons in need of the killer touch
fields.trailText: Wimbeldon 1 - 1 Wolves
fields.body:
Whenhis fitness and form are in tandem, John Hartson has few equals as a barnstorming, battering ram centre forward. A throwback to the days before touch and timing became so much a part of a leading striker's armoury.

Two goals in the rout of Sheffield Wednesday and another brace at Huddersfield in midweek represented the Welshman at his best as Wimbledon showed a distinct liking for the Yorkshire air.

Yesterday, the captain again led by example, linking attacking play consistently and proving the biggest danger to the Wolves goal. He also shouldered his share of defensive duties for set pieces at the other end.

It should have been enough for his team to make the most of home comforts for the first time this season after goalless draws in both their opening matches at Selhurst.

Certainly Wimbledon looked set for victory when Hartson muscled his way to meet a 63rd minute free-kick from Neal Ardley to power a header into the top corner. But they failed to fully grasp the advantage and a double substitution paved the way for Wolves to earn a point and ease some of the pressure on their manager, Colin Lee.

Saudi Arabian international Sami Al-Jaber immediately freshened up their forward play. Then Andy Sinton was introduced and almost immediately delivered the corner that brought 18-year-old Joleon Lescott his first goal for the club with a looping header that caught out Kelvin Davis as it dipped into the far corner.

Wolves were rewarded for their perseverance. They had earlier been favoured with two excellent chances, the first when Michael Branch struck a post and from the rebound Kevin Muscat forced Davis into a smart save.

Overall, Wimbledon had much more of the game, Hartson forcing Michael Oakes to tip his header over, and Trond Andersen failing to do justice to a cut-back from Damien Francis.

To prove serious contenders for an immediate return to the Premiership they will have to kill off teams like this when the chance presents itself.

Manager Terry Burton, however, will remain optimistic if Hartson can maintain prolific form.

webTitle: A lone foray down the isle

fields.headline: A lone foray down the isle
fields.standfirst: Nick Paton Walsh  discovers that the Caribbean is not really designed for singletons
fields.trailText: Nick Paton Walsh discovers that the Caribbean is not really designed for singletons
fields.body:
The Caribbean is not for single people. Package holidays are priced on the assumption that you are going with a friend; the sunbeds are laid out in pairs and the local dance routines require a partner you know fairly well. None the less, on the first night of a two-week holiday in Antigua, I was content with my own company as I sat jetlagged in a bar in the island of Antigua.

The sunset had turned the sky purple. My fellow holidaymakers were drunk, sunburnt and irresponsible, as portrayed in public health information films. But the illusory calm was shattered when confronted with a question I'd hear often over the next fortnight. A waitress, scoldingly slamming a gin and tonic down on my table, barked: 'What you doin' here on your own, boy?'

My solitude was breaking the unwritten rules of the Caribbean. Signs of togetherness were all around me: couples walking arm in arm; couples dribbling into each other's frozen cocktails; couples rowing over who had eaten the last olive from the bowl on the bar. But with 'you got mail' noises still ringing in my ears, a packet of duty-free cigarettes was more than enough company. Solitude was a good thing. I had booked a last-minute package holiday, intent on meeting complete strangers whom I would never see again and, of course, to see something of the island.

The level of romance in Antigua can begin to feel like a conspiracy after a while: the island is a popular wedding destination for Americans. The resorts are packed with the bride, groom and their respective families and friends. The ceremonies occur on small podiums on the edge of the shore - the groom putting a lavish tux over his beach shorts for a few hours. This atmosphere of connubial bliss can be contagious so, in order to keep yourself from evolving into a couple, observe a few simple maxims. Never spend more than one evening with the same group of people. Ensure your arms are long enough to apply sun cream to the farthest reaches of your back. When you find yourself trying to light the wrong end of your cigarette, go home.

I paid approximately £600 to hire a showy Jeep for 14 days and was able to escape the world of lazy resorts into a densely vegetated, playful island. The courtesy bus from the airport had shown glimpses of Antigua several decades of development distant from the holiday resorts. People carried their water from the taps in the street while corrugated iron was an integral part of each village, as indeed were cricket and stray dogs. But once you enter the resort gates, Antigua is a world where golf buggies whirr between villas, where the poolside concrete is sticky with the half-dried remnants of spilled fruit purees, and one of the bars serves pizza all day long. The Jolly Beach Resort, where I stayed for a fortnight, has just about everything a holidaying suburbanite could want, bar an uncensored experience of Antigua.

St John's, the island's shambolic capital, wears the island's penury better than you might expect. Down on the dock the cruise ships find a bay so their passengers may mill around the cigar and trinket boutiques before departing again. There is little nightlife here, and few restaurants. It is a quiet, dozy town. Typical of the disorder, the kerbs are built high enough to control the small floods of the rainy season, but are often ineffectual because of the litter piled across the drain grilles. Here the pace of life is slow and harmless and atrocities such as a 'Man badly scratched in casino brawl' are headlined in the island's newspaper. The police appear to carry firearms more as a counterbalance to the handcuffs on the other side of their belt, rather than because of any real danger. The closest I came to feeling uncomfortable was on driving south of the island to a residential area. Following a noise down a back street I discovered a half-built house that had been adapted as a nightclub. The bass notes from the music could be felt in the Jeep. My sunburnt skin and shorts identified me and aware of the stares I was attracting I felt unwelcome and drove on.

On the road to the island's most heavily colonised nightspot, Shirley Heights, is the Old English Harbour. Long, gold-trimmed boats line the docks, toys of those we know must be rich. On the docks the Southern Cross restaurant with its crisp linen and maritime decor offers a view of the harbour, but much of the menu I and my companions tried was shrivelled and salty. Go there for their goldfish-bowl gin and tonics and fancy bread, then get someone else to drive you back to the new restaurant at the Jolly Beach resort. There the lobster is tender and fresh, and the Sancerre worth the price tag.

Sundays are a day of rest, church and cricket for much of Antigua. In the resorts, life is as slow as every other day, but the evenings find a dynamism of their own on one of the highest hills on the island. Shirley Heights was formerly a colonial gun post, but now a steel band and reggae group enliven the bar once a week. From 6pm onwards a crowd bearing camcorders, homemade cigarettes and cans of Red Stripe gathers. To the left, the former British colony of Monserrat puffs ash into the sky, and to the right, planes carrying British and American tourists come in to land.

The steel band and reggae groups play until around 10pm. The music is stereotypical Caribbean, but most aficionados seem satisfied. The sounds are loud, libidinous and loose. By the end of the evening, you may find yourself caught up in the music with somebody with whom you are not as familiar as your dance suggests. And then you can say that, for a moment at least, you obeyed the rules of the Caribbean.
fields.bodyText: The Caribbean is not for single people. Package holidays are priced on the assumption that you are going with a friend; the sunbeds are laid out in pairs and the local dance routines require a partner you know fairly well. None the less, on the first night of a two-week holiday in Antigua, I was content with my own company as I sat jetlagged in a bar in the island of Antigua. The sunset had turned the sky purple. My fellow holidaymakers were drunk, sunburnt and irresponsible, as portrayed in public health information films. But the illusory calm was shattered when confronted with a question I'd hear often over the next fortnight. A waitress, scoldingly slamming a gin and tonic down on my table, barked: 'What you doin' here on your own, boy?' My solitude was breaking the unwritten rules of the Caribbean. Signs of togetherness were all around me: couples walking arm in arm; couples dribbling into each other's frozen cocktails; couples rowing over who had eaten the last olive from the bowl on the bar. But with 'you got mail' noises still ringing in my ears, a packet of duty-free cigarettes was more than enough company. Solitude was a good thing. I had booked a last-minute package holiday, intent on meeting complete strangers whom I would never see again and, of course, to see something of the island. The level of romance in Antigua can begin to feel like a conspiracy after a while: the island is a popular wedding destination for Americans. The resorts are packed with the bride, groom and their respective families and friends. The ceremonies occur on small podiums on the edge of the shore - the groom putting a lavish tux over his beach shorts for a few hours. This atmosphere of connubial bliss can be contagious so, in order to keep yourself from evolving into a couple, observe a few simple maxims. Never spend more than one evening with the same group of people. Ensure your arms are long enough to apply sun cream to the farthest reaches of your back. When you find yourself trying to light the wrong end of your cigarette, go home. I paid approximately £600 to hire a showy Jeep for 14 days and was able to escape the world of lazy resorts into a densely vegetated, playful island. The courtesy bus from the airport had shown glimpses of Antigua several decades of development distant from the holiday resorts. People carried their water from the taps in the street while corrugated iron was an integral part of each village, as indeed were cricket and stray dogs. But once you enter the resort gates, Antigua is a world where golf buggies whirr between villas, where the poolside concrete is sticky with the half-dried remnants of spilled fruit purees, and one of the bars serves pizza all day long. The Jolly Beach Resort, where I stayed for a fortnight, has just about everything a holidaying suburbanite could want, bar an uncensored experience of Antigua. St John's, the island's shambolic capital, wears the island's penury better than you might expect. Down on the dock the cruise ships find a bay so their passengers may mill around the cigar and trinket boutiques before departing again. There is little nightlife here, and few restaurants. It is a quiet, dozy town. Typical of the disorder, the kerbs are built high enough to control the small floods of the rainy season, but are often ineffectual because of the litter piled across the drain grilles. Here the pace of life is slow and harmless and atrocities such as a 'Man badly scratched in casino brawl' are headlined in the island's newspaper. The police appear to carry firearms more as a counterbalance to the handcuffs on the other side of their belt, rather than because of any real danger. The closest I came to feeling uncomfortable was on driving south of the island to a residential area. Following a noise down a back street I discovered a half-built house that had been adapted as a nightclub. The bass notes from the music could be felt in the Jeep. My sunburnt skin and shorts identified me and aware of the stares I was attracting I felt unwelcome and drove on. On the road to the island's most heavily colonised nightspot, Shirley Heights, is the Old English Harbour. Long, gold-trimmed boats line the docks, toys of those we know must be rich. On the docks the Southern Cross restaurant with its crisp linen and maritime decor offers a view of the harbour, but much of the menu I and my companions tried was shrivelled and salty. Go there for their goldfish-bowl gin and tonics and fancy bread, then get someone else to drive you back to the new restaurant at the Jolly Beach resort. There the lobster is tender and fresh, and the Sancerre worth the price tag. Sundays are a day of rest, church and cricket for much of Antigua. In the resorts, life is as slow as every other day, but the evenings find a dynamism of their own on one of the highest hills on the island. Shirley Heights was formerly a colonial gun post, but now a steel band and reggae group enliven the bar once a week. From 6pm onwards a crowd bearing camcorders, homemade cigarettes and cans of Red Stripe gathers. To the left, the former British colony of Monserrat puffs ash into the sky, and to the right, planes carrying British and American tourists come in to land.
